TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has raised aspects of these instruments relating to a possible failure to carry out expressed legislative intent, requirements for employers to provide detailed personal information about their employees to a government department and possible invalid incorporation of future foreign laws into Commonwealth legislation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the Committee's concerns.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: These regulations increased fees for searches in the Register of Foreign Marriages, for copies and extracts of entries in that Register, for copies of certain documents and for giving notice of an intended marriage.

The Explanatory Statement advised that the fees were last increased in 1990 and then stated that the increase "reflects the movements in the Consumer Price Index for the period under review (January 1990 to December 1991)". However, one increase was from $8 to $15, an increase of 87.5%; two are from $12 to $18, an increase of 50%; and one from $30 to $40, an increase of 33.3%. In fact, these increases do not appear to reflect the CPI increase during the period.

PARA.EMPHASIS: INSTRUMENT UNDER S.40AA(6)(CE) OF THE NATIONAL HEALTH ACT 1953

SPEECH.PARA: This instrument approved Form NH20 requiring reconciliation of 1991/92 nursing and personal care staff costs and other cost reimbursed expenditure.

Form NH20 appears to require employers to provide the Department with the names, awards and many personal details of service of individual staff in relation to their annual leave, sick leave and long service leave. It is assumed that this information is needed for reconciliation of reimbursement. However, the Committee has asked for further advice on the provisions which authorise the collection of such information, who has access to it, what safeguards exist for its protection, whether its collection accords with the Privacy Principles and whether it was necessary for such detailed information to be collected for the purposes of the Act.

These Determinations provide for conditions of employment of locally engaged Commonwealth employees in Malta, Czechoslovakia and Ireland. Provisions of each Determination appear to incorporate aspects of the law of those countries as in force or existing from time to time. Also, one Explanatory Statement advises of a provision "which authorises payment to LES of salary increases decreed by the Maltese Government".

The parent Public Service Act 1922 provides for only limited incorporation in Determinations of instruments as in force at a particular time or as amended. The Committee has asked for an assurance that this apparent incorporation in Commonwealth legislation of future unknown foreign laws is authorised by that Act.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Coulter) proposed:

That the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council be authorised to meet during the sittings of the Senate on 26 November 1992 from 9.00 a.m. till 1.00 p.m., for the purpose of taking evidence in camera.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Opposition has no objection, given the difficult circumstances under which we are all working in terms of time pressures, to the Senate agreeing to the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council meeting during sitting hours tomorrow, from 9 a.m. till 1 p.m. But Senator Coulter does ask in his motion that the meeting be allowed for the purpose of taking evidence in camera. The proposal that the evidence be taken in camera at the first hearing of this very important Senate select committee is a matter that does concern us. This is a very important inquiry. It is very unusual to start an official hearing on the basis of taking in camera evidence.

PARA.TAB: There are very few precedents, as I understand it, for select committees or standing committees of the Senate to commence an inquiry—certainly one of this importance—by taking in camera evidence as distinct from a private briefing. This is an official hearing. There will be a Hansard transcript and it is therefore a very important part of the inquiry as a whole. We believe that it is very bad practice for the first hearing to be held in camera.

The purpose of holding it in camera is certainly not clear to Opposition members of the Committee—nor, indeed, to the Opposition as a whole. I think it sets a very bad precedent. It smacks of starting off the inquiry in a cloak and dagger fashion. It means that the general public and other senators will not be able to know, until the report of the Committee is completed, the nature of this very important hearing.

On behalf of the Opposition, I would have liked to have sought Senator Coulter's agreement to change that part of his motion relating to the taking of evidence in camera so that it reads `for the purpose of taking evidence in public session'. I did discuss this with Senator Coulter. I understand he is not agreeable to that. Given the procedures of the Senate, there is little more I can do but make this public protest about the way in which the Committee is commencing its inquiries. I hope it is not a precedent for the conduct of the rest of the hearings of this very important Committee.
I want to put on the record the Opposition's concern that the Committee is starting the inquiry in this fashion. I ask why this should occur. I think it is a very unhealthy precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I assure Senator Short and other members of the Opposition that this is not a precedent. It is in the form of a briefing by Treasury officers. It is the first part of their submission, as I understand it, and the Treasury officers will be coming back for the public part of the inquiry later on. This is for the information of those members of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council who may not be fully across the functioning of the Loan Council. I understand that it was Senator Bishop who made the initial suggestion that this be an in camera hearing. I simply repeat the assurance that this does not set a precedent. The Treasury officers concerned will come back. It is my understanding that all further meetings of the Committee will be open to the public.
—by leave—I correct that point made by Senator Coulter. The proposal that this hearing be held in camera did not come from the Opposition. That is quite incorrect.

—by leave—As a Victorian, I take a very great interest in what has happened. The Chairman of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, Senator Coulter, has said that the hearing will be in camera to enable members of the Committee to understand the workings of the Loan Council. I point out that some other people in this chamber might also like the opportunity to learn about the workings of the Loan Council. When the hearing is held in camera, it means they are not allowed to do that. I find that unacceptable. I think Senator Coulter should think about that. It excludes other people from learning about it. Many senators attend committee meetings when they are not actually members of the committee. It is very useful for them to be able to do that. By having an in camera hearing, those people are precluded from doing that.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: RADIOACTIVE WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Sowada) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to the importation and export of radioactive materials and radioactive waste.
Motion (by Senator Sowada) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to prohibit the import and export of radioactive waste into and out of Australia and to further restrict the trade of radioactive materials.

The Bill was developed in response to the passing of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Amendment Act earlier this year. That Act accorded a greater commercial role for ANSTO and granted ANSTO the functions of conditioning, managing and storing radioactive waste on site, with immunity provided from certain State and Territory laws.

As I will explain later on, the present situation concerning ANSTO and the powers bestowed upon it under the Amendment Act gives rise to a completely unacceptable situation. If the Australian public were aware of the powers held by ANSTO and the direction in which both the Government and ANSTO are heading, they would be very alarmed indeed, and for good reason.

The Amendment Act was, in part, a response by the Government to orders made by Justice Cripps in the New South Wales Land and Environment Court in regard to the presence of radioactive waste at the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories in Sutherland Shire. The Act overrides an order made by Justice Cripps that ANSTO be restrained from bringing on to the Lucas Heights facility radioactive waste for the purpose of storing the waste on site contrary to the provisions of the planning laws of New South Wales. This means that the Federal Government has unilaterally assumed total control over ANSTO's activities and thereby flouted the recently negotiated Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment, effectively rendering it null and void.

ANSTO has now effectively been granted legislative protection in dealing with radioactive wastes. The only concession the Government was prepared to make to the Sutherland Shire community and environment groups was a guarantee in legislation that the premises on which the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories are situated will not become a national nuclear waste repository.

Although this was an important win for the residents of Sutherland Shire, the fact remains that ANSTO now has a mandate to engage in commercial ventures dealing with radioactive waste without any reference to State planning and environmental controls. These ventures could include the involvement by ANSTO in the international trade in radioactive waste. This is an extremely worrying development and set beside other nuclear related developments, clearly demonstrates that Australia is becoming increasingly involved in the international nuclear community, without any mandate from the Australian people. Further, it is the express wish of the Government's own party membership to oppose the importation of radioactive waste into this country.

It is no secret that a number of politicians within and outside Australia believe that the deserts of our country would make an ideal dumping ground for nuclear waste. Investigations into the suitability of geological formations within Australia, for radioactive waste disposal, have already taken place. Ostensibly such investigations have taken place in order to understand radioactive waste repositories overseas. It would be naive of us to believe that these activities have been undertaken purely for overseas application. One of the two participants in the study, the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation of Japan (PNC) is actively looking for offshore sites for radioactive waste dumps. So far they have concluded agreements with the former USSR and China for radioactive waste disposal investigations.

A moratorium on the dumping of low level radioactive waste at sea will be discussed at the London Dumping Convention in October this year. Some countries wish to convert the moratorium into a permanent ban, but this is being resisted by, amongst others, Japan, the UK and France. If a permanent ban were to be imposed, added pressure from land scarce countries would be placed on land abundant countries such as Australia to enter into seemingly lucrative deals to accept radioactive waste.

It is worrying that there is an increasing perception overseas that Australia would make an ideal dumping ground for the radioactive waste of other countries—a view also held by some supporters of the nuclear industry within Australia.

There have been suggestions that redundant uranium mine sites could be backfilled with radioactive waste. It has been mooted that the open-cut Ranger uranium mine could be used for this purpose. Only recently the Chamber of Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory called for an international radioactive waste dump to be sited in the Territory. The line being pushed is that Australia would earn more money from its involvement in the nuclear industry if it not only sold uranium, but offered a complete waste management service also.

The Minister insists that such an idea would never come to pass, and he has frequently sought refuge in his Party's policy on this matter. That he has singularly failed to put his own Party policy on radioactive waste—one of the few worthwhile environmental polices that the Party has—into legislation is worrying. He deliberately chose not to prohibit the import and export of radioactive waste, when amending the ANSTO Amendment Act afforded him the opportunity to do so. As I will explain shortly, within the Government itself there is a contradictory approach to radioactive waste, and a conflict most definitely arises from the Government's actions and its own Party policy.

At present the only constraints relating to the imports of radioactive wastes on the Government is the ALP Party policy. However, the Government has previously chosen to openly ignore its own Party's policy by approving uranium exports to France. ALP policy therefore counts for very little with the upper echelon decision makers of the Party.

It has been claimed that under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations Act, the importation of `radioactive substances' is prohibited. This is not strictly true. This particular piece of legislation does allow for certain materials to be imported if accompanied by the written permission of the Minister or an `authorised officer'. An `authorised officer' is defined as any officer or employee—of ANSTO—appointed in writing by the relevant Minister, in this case the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. This is a cosy relationship indeed.

ANSTO is now permitted to condition, manage and store radioactive waste and radioactive materials arising from the activities of `other persons' who are specified in the regulations. If the Government were to designate a foreign company dealing in nuclear power as a `person' under the regulations, an ANSTO employee could authorise the importation of the waste and ANSTO would be able to condition, manage and store the waste at the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories.

A corresponding matter to which the ANSTO Amendment Act relates is the proposed establishment of a national nuclear waste repository. The repository is to provide long term storage for low and intermediate level radioactive waste.

The Commonwealth has been attempting to identify a permanent site for the repository for a considerable period of time. These efforts have been clearly described in a paper by the Science, Technology and Environment Group of the Parliamentary Research Service. In 1980 a Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee was set up, partly in response to a 1975 recommendation by the National Health and Medical Research Council that a central `repository' for longer-lived radioactive wastes be established.

In 1985 the Committee recommended that a national program of site identification for shallow ground burial of radioactive waste be commenced. A list of potential sites was to be prepared within 12 months. However, very little progress was made, apart from the publication of a list of radioactive wastes stored throughout the country and a failed feasibility study carried out by the Northern Territory Government in 1988-89.

By February 1992, New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory had all refused to allow a national radioactive waste repository within their boundaries. Western Australia has established Australia's only state radioactive disposal site at Mt Walton, 130 kms north west of Coolgardie. It is not, however, intended for use as a national disposal site.

The Commonwealth clearly faces an impasse on this issue. However, as the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Ross Free, stated in his second reading speech on the ANSTO Amendment Bill, the judgment of the NSW Land and Environment Court has `focused attention more sharply on the need for a permanent repository for Australia's radioactive wastes'.

The Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council resolved at a meeting on 7 February this year to request the Commonwealth to commission a body to identify options for sites for the processing of a permanent disposal facility for low-level radioactive wastes. The Commonwealth has established a working group comprising Department of Primary Industries and Energy and ANSTO officials.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, is actively seeking the cooperation of State and Territory Governments to identify a site. In a media release dated 1 June 1992, Mr Crean stated that cooperation from the States has been disappointing. He then threatened that `the Commonwealth will have to identify, and may need to acquire, a site if co-operation is not forthcoming'.

Further, the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts has recommended that the Commonwealth take `urgent action' to select a site for and construct a safe and secure radioactive waste repository. Finally, the Working Party of the Radiation Health Committee of the NHMRC has recently issued a draft Code of Practice for the Near-Surface Disposal of Radioactive Waste in Australia. The paper, which updates a 1990 draft Code, recommends shallow land burial for low and intermediate waste in an arid area.

It is of some concern to note here that the specified permissible levels for certain radionuclides set out in the 1990 draft have been raised in the 1992 draft. For example, the limit for radium has been raised by 50 times while the limit for tritium has been removed altogether. A third category of waste, seemingly designed to accommodate mineral sands tailings generated primarily by private companies, has also been included in the 1992 draft. In addition, against international practice, the NHMRC, in its second draft, has failed to define low and intermediate level waste.

Although the Australian Democrats are yet to develop a detailed policy on the long term disposal of radioactive waste, we nevertheless have grave concerns about the shallow land burial disposal method being considered by the NHMRC. Both Greenpeace and the Friends of the Earth object to such a disposal method. In the United States, shallow land burial sites have come under fire from local communities concerned about waste contamination. Two of the six shallow burial sites for commercial low level radioactive waste in the US have leaked and another three have been closed.

In the United Kingdom, NIREX (the Nuclear Industry Radioactive Waste Executive responsible for making proposals to the Government for the safe storage of low and intermediate level waste) has decided to dispose of low level waste in the same repositories as intermediate level waste. Canada, France and Sweden are also adopting alternative technologies to shallow land burial, by moving toward a highly engineered and deeper land burial of radioactive waste. Greenpeace advocate above-ground dry-storage, partly to avoid the `out of sight, out of mind' mentality, but also as an interim measure pending the development of safer and more secure forms of radioactive waste management. Such a policy would also encourage waste minimisation or avoidance by industry. Above-ground, dry stores already exist and are in use for spent nuclear fuel, the most radioactive material known. Low and intermediate waste should also be kept in similar facilities.

Although Australia's store of radioactive waste is relatively small when compared to some countries, we nevertheless do have a major national problem. The main focus of this problem—the 1,500 spent fuel rods stored at Lucas Heights, is for the most part, not discussed within Parliament, scientific circles or the public arena. It is time this issue was properly addressed within the context of a national radioactive waste management strategy.

ANSTO imports approximately 50 fuel rods a year to operate the HIFAR reactor. If ANSTO continues to operate until the year 2000, there will be about 2,000 fuel rods on site by the turn of the century. The continued accumulation of spent nuclear fuel is dependent on whether or not the spent fuel is sent overseas.

According to the Safety Review Committee's Special Report presented to the Minister for Science and Technology last year, entitled Management of Radioactive Waste at Lucas Heights Research Laboratories, the spent nuclear fuel rods from the HIFAR reactor are not classified as waste because the Government hopes to recover the highly enriched uranium from them by sending them to the US for reprocessing.
ANSTO claims that it will receive a credit—of new fuel rods—for the HIFAR reactor in lieu of the highly enriched uranium that the US will obtain as a result of the reprocessing of the spent fuel.

For some years now, the Government has been hoping to send the spent fuel overseas. On 17 December 1985 the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, issued a press statement which said:

The Government has decided that 450 spent reactor fuel elements will be transported from the [then] Australian Atomic Energy Commission's Research Establishment at Lucas Heights to the United States for reprocessing.
Senator Evans went on to say that the transportation and reprocessing of the spent fuel will occur during 1986-87. Needless to say this did not occur.

The Democrats adamantly oppose the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel and thereby the export of spent fuel rods for reprocessing. Reprocessing separates unused uranium and plutonium from spent fuel and results in highly enriched uranium, plutonium and high level liquid radioactive waste. It is a dangerous, expensive, and unnecessary process. According to ANSTO, it is also more expensive to send spent fuel overseas than to seek to store it here in Australia.

One problem for the Australian Government is that there is increasing community opposition in the US to the policy of accepting radioactive waste from other countries. The Sierra Club, for example, has instigated litigation in the District Court of Columbia over the importation of foreign research reactor spent fuel.

The US Department of Energy is currently revising its policy on reprocessing `foreign' research reactor spent fuel and any arrangements to import waste from other countries is on hold. If the policy were to change, Australia may not be able to export the rods to the US or alternatively may be obliged to reimport the high level liquid waste from reprocessing, atom-for-atom. Again there is no facility in Australia for the permanent storage or disposal of such waste.

The Government's plan to export spent nuclear fuel to the United States is, again, in conflict with its own Party policy which states that the ALP should `promote the necessary level of research and development of promising technology for the handling and disposal of high level nuclear waste, in view of the absence of such safe disposal methods' (ALP Conference Book 1991).

The spent fuel at Lucas Heights is the only form of high level radioactive waste that is within Australia. It can hardly be said that plans to transport the fuel through Sydney, then on a long ocean voyage, and through American communities at sites already dangerously contaminated is a sensible waste policy.

For every cubic metre of spent fuel sent into a reprocessing plant 160 more cubic metres of waste, in bulk terms, is created. Reprocessing creates low, intermediate and high level liquid wastes and leads to the release of radioactive gas and water. As there is no safe disposal option for radioactive wastes within the US, how can we possibly contemplate sending spent nuclear fuel there as the present Government policy dictates we do?
It is worth noting that not all spent nuclear fuel is reprocessed. In a number of countries spent fuel is treated as a primary waste and treated and managed accordingly.

There are only two US facilities which reprocess research reactor spent fuel. They are the Savannah River facility in South Carolina and the Idaho Falls facility. In a letter to Greenpeace dated 22 April 1991, Mr John Rolland, the Director of External Affairs at ANSTO stated that:
The facility to which ANSTO's spent fuel would go to has not been decided.

I understand that the International Atomic Energy Authority does not have full inspection rights to the Savannah River and Idaho facilities. In addition, I also understand that it may be the intention of the US Department of Energy to use the highly enriched uranium from Australian spent fuel in a military reactor. The Democrats are implacably opposed to the use of any spent fuel from Australia in an American or for that matter any other country's military reactor.

The Government also hopes that the waste from the reprocessing will be retained in the US. To date, US policy on reprocessing has allowed waste from imported and reprocessed and spent fuel to remain in the country.

In 1963 the then Australian Atomic Energy Commission exported 150 spent fuel rods to the Dounreay reprocessing facility in Northern Scotland. At the time the UK allowed the waste generated by reprocessing to remain in the country. Since the 1970s the UK has insisted that waste be returned to the exporting country. This explains why the Government is keen to export the spent fuel to the US. It is feasible that the UK Government could pass retrospective legislation which would require the waste generated by reprocessing of spent fuel to be returned to the country of origin. After all, the immunity of ANSTO from State and Territory laws included in the ANSTO Amendment Act was applied retrospectively. This would mean that Australia would have to take back the high level liquid waste generated from the reprocessing of the spent fuel sent to Dounreay in 1963.

One must wonder whether a purpose of the ANSTO Amendment Act is to allow for the importation of radioactive waste generated from the overseas reprocessing of spent fuel rods. This proposition carries quite some weight when one considers that during the debate on the Amendment Act, I put forward an amendment to the effect that ANSTO should not be permitted to import or export radioactive waste.
The Government rejected the amendment. Senator Button explained that the Government did not agree with the amendment because:
that would mean that ANSTO would no longer be able to receive spent source material for recycling.

In response to Senator Button's answer, my colleague Senator Coulter asked whether this meant that ANSTO might import fuel radioactive waste that is spent for reprocessing. In reply, Senator Button said:

. . . this Bill is very wide in its ramifications and there may be circumstances where fuel rods have been sent overseas for reprocessing and, as I understand it, we may have to take back small quantities of waste to ANSTO from those rods. There is a possibility, not a likelihood, that that could be required of us.
Clearly, the ramifications of the Bill, as Senator Button said, are very wide—wide enough to allow the export of spent fuel for reprocessing and the import of high level liquid radioactive waste.

This is of concern as it ties in too closely with the wishes of the Synroc Study Group. The Study Group consists of ANSTO, the Australian National University, ERA (who are the owners of the Ranger uranium mine and Jabiluka uranium deposit—both in the Northern Territory), the Western Mining Corporation (who own a 51 per cent interest in the Roxby Downs uranium mine in South Australia), CRA (the owners of the Kintyre uranium deposit in Western Australia) and BHP, who have business links with CRA.

The Study Group is exploring opportunities for the commercial radioactive waste disposal sector in Australia. A pre-feasibility study undertaken by the Group has indicated significant commercial opportunities for Synroc.

Synroc, which is short for synthetic rock, can be used to immobilise the high level liquid radioactive waste which results from reprocessing spent nuclear fuel. The Study Group also hopes to expand this technology into other radioactive waste applications.

The September 1991 Progress Report of the Synroc Study Group listed five options for the commercial development of Synroc in Australia. Two of these involve importing radioactive waste into Australia either for encapsulation and then dumping in Australia, or for re-export for disposal overseas following treatment.

In the short term the Synroc Study Group is seeking to import small quantities of high level nuclear waste to further their research into applications for Synroc. The ANSTO Amendment Act represents one way in which legislation is being changed to increase the potential for Australia's involvement in the international waste trade, particularly in relation to the Study Group's activities. What is there to prevent the Synroc Study Group from importing high level liquid waste if, as I have explained, an ANSTO employee could be responsible for authorising the importation of such waste? So much for an impartial assessment.

The amendments contained in the ANSTO Amendment Act only serve to further the cosy relationship between those with a vested interest in furthering the aims of the Synroc Study Group. There is not legislation to prohibit the Study Group form embarking on a venture to import radioactive waste.

A further issue of major national significance is the eventual decommissioning of the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights. The Government is clearly bereft of any policy to deal with its inevitable shut down. The Director of External Affairs at ANSTO said in a letter to Greenpeace dated 10 April 1991:

The decommissioning of HIFAR has to date only been considered in general terms. No detailed assessments have been undertaken and there are no proposals to decommission either of the two reactors operated by ANSTO.

The decommissioning of HIFAR will result in wastes that will have to be dealt with. Some of the wastes will be medium and high level radioactive waste. Such waste will remain radioactive for tens of thousands of years.

Clearly, the Government faces some very important decisions in the next few years in relation to the nuclear industry and the waste generated by its activities. The legacy of its decisions will be felt for some tens of thousands of years to come. That is a fact that is almost impossible for us to comprehend, but one which is nevertheless the incontrovertible truth.

The Australian community is little informed about these issues, a fact which reflects badly on the Government. Decisions are made about Australia's future role in the industry with no attempt to engage the public. In fact, by passing the ANSTO Amendment Act, the Government and the Opposition which supported it, showed that are both intent on minimising public input and, at the same time, maximising protection for the nuclear industry in Australia.

In his presentation to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, the Minister for Science and Technology, Ross Free, dismissed concerns that ANSTO would be seeking commercial return for operating a nuclear waste storage facility.

The Democrats have become very sceptical of these types of reassurances coming from the Labour Party, the Party which has failed to deliver on the vast majority of its green promises given at the last election. I note that on the same day that the draft report of the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste was released by Mrs Kelly, recommending that no further toxic waste should be exported from Australia, she granted a six month licence to allow 1,000 tonnes of PCBs and pesticides to be exported to France.

This example hardly gives us any sort of comfort. If the Environment Minister is happy to enter into a toxic waste trade, it is not hard to believe that the Science and Technology Minister would be happy to enter into a radioactive waste trade agreement.

Many people would be horrified if they realised the ramifications of the ANSTO Amendment Act and the intentions of the Government to export spent fuel for reprocessing and to import high level radioactive waste. It is not in the realms of fantasy to envisage Australia becoming a dumping ground for radioactive waste from other countries. Countries such as Japan and Indonesia are embarking on an accelerated program of nuclear power production. Will Australia, with its vast outback, be pressured to accept their waste? Will people within the nuclear industry and the Government promote Australia as an ideal dumping ground for waste, in return for the supposedly vast sums of money this could bring to the country?

These deep concerns have lead me to table this Bill which seeks to ensure that Australia does not go down the nuclear waste road. It bans outright the export and import of radioactive waste. As I mentioned earlier, the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste has recommended that Australia cease to export intractable waste as it is an entirely unethical activity. Similarly, if Australia is to operate a nuclear research reactor, the merits of which I do not wish to debate here and now, then we must take responsibility for the waste produced and not dump it elsewhere. Conversely, we should not accept anyone else's waste.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

Senator Chamarette—Mr President, I ask that General Business notice of motion No. 1258, standing in my name and relating to the arrest of East Timorese resistance leader Xanana Gusmao, be taken as formal business.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion relating to the conduct of business, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 1258, standing in her name for this day, relating to the arrest of East Timorese resistance leader Xanana Gusmao.

SPEECH.PARA: I had hoped that I would not need to present this matter as a motion to be debated, but that it would be taken as formal. My reason for presenting it is the urgent concern that is presented by Mr Gusmao's arrest in East Timor, the failure of the Indonesian Government to allow access to him, the failure of the Indonesian Government to answer the questions that are being asked in the international community regarding his whereabouts, his health and his access to legal counsel and the refusal by the Indonesian Government to allow representatives of the International Red Cross or members of his family to visit him.

PARA.TAB: I have received representation from the Australian Council for Overseas Aid which urges me to press this matter and to gain the support of the Senate. I have received—as I am sure have other honourable senators—requests from many people who are concerned about the situation in East Timor, amongst them the Ambassador of Portugal. I have also received information through the Asia Watch information service that calls on us to support any efforts to press the Indonesian Government to allow immediate access by lawyers, international humanitarian agencies and the media to Xanana Gusmao in support of the independence movement and the human rights of that situation.

To my knowledge, the people who were giving refuge to Mr Gusmao and whose house he was taken from when he was under arrest have disappeared. Their whereabouts are unknown. There are genuine concerns for their well-being and that of the resistance leader. I call upon members of the Senate to support this motion. I believe that it is one way of making it known that pressure is being placed by the Parliament on the Australian Government and on our Foreign Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, to take seriously the situation in Indonesia and to call for some redress to be offered for Mr Gusmao. I urge people to support the motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly speak to the motion to suspend Standing Orders. Just to make it clear, that is what we are talking about at the moment—a motion to suspend the Standing Orders. In my view there is no doubt about the significance of the issue about which we are talking. I accept the genuineness of the concerns of, I suspect, every senator. Certainly everybody I have spoken to—and this includes a wide range of Australians of all different political viewpoints with different views about the situation in East Timor—is concerned at the very least about the civil rights of Mr Gusmao and, beyond that, about possibly wider issues concerning East Timor. It is an issue that warrants being taken seriously. But that does not establish that we should suspend Standing Orders now to debate and, if supported, carry this motion.

PARA.TAB: Former Foreign Minister Bill Hayden said in a different context that, in foreign affairs, words are bullets. We have to tread very carefully in this matter. We can take the issue with equal seriousness without all agreeing about a particular motion. The normal processes by which consultation takes place with the Foreign Minister and others whereby we get an agreed resolution should continue to operate here before we have special motions of this type. It is a very important issue, and I do not criticise anybody for raising it. But I do not think today we should be suspending Standing Orders to deal with this issue, notwithstanding its importance. We have a lot of other important issues to deal with. We all have the genuine concern that Senator Chamarette has about this matter, but the suspension of Standing Orders today is not the appropriate procedure for dealing with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some senses I agree with Senator McMullan that it should not be necessary to suspend Standing Orders today. Senator Chamarette felt very much the same way. Yesterday I moved a similar motion of concern about the situation in East Timor and, in particular, about the fate of Xanana Gusmao. However, I support Senator Chamarette's motion for the suspension of Standing Orders for the debate and passage of her motion because I believe it addresses the concern for diplomatic niceties and requirements that Senator McMullan referred to. The motion is couched in terms expressing concerns which I believe are widely held around this chamber and which would give strength to the arm of our Government and our Foreign Minister in his negotiations.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that in the motion I moved yesterday I acknowledged—even praised—the work that Senator Evans has done as our Foreign Minister on this issue since last weekend, when the news of the capture of the Fretilin leader came to us here in Australia. I do so again in my contribution here today. Senator Chamarette's very carefully worded motion should not require the suspension of Standing Orders because it should have been supported around the chamber. It is the sort of motion that a government that was really concerned about the fate of this political prisoner and about human rights for East Timorese generally under the Indonesian regime should welcome. Coming from one of the Houses of this Parliament, it should be seen as giving strength to the arm of a government negotiating on the issue of human rights for the East Timorese people.

I support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. I believe that all parties and all senators in this chamber who have expressed concern about this issue should find it simple and useful to support Senator Chamarette's motion. If the motion had been declared formal in the normal way, the suspension of Standing Orders would not have been necessary.

I suppose that I am calling into some question the commitment of this Government in this area. The recent exclusion of a visit to East Timor by an Australian parliamentary delegation in Indonesia is a example of the sorts of hurdles that have yet to be overcome. Now that this arrest has taken place we may have some of the answer as to why that delegation was not permitted into East Timor some weeks ago.

There is a need for this chamber to push issues relating to East Timor in the context of our relationship with Indonesia. After all, this week has not only seen the capture of Xanana Gusmao; it has also seen the first explorations for oil in the Timor Gap. This chamber was party—I might say that at the time this went ahead without my vote and without the vote of any of the Australian Democrats or of then Senator Vallentine—to the passage of the treaty which has allowed this country and Indonesia to divide up oil which rightfully belongs to the people of East Timor.

So I do think this chamber needs to debate this issue and, hence, I support the motion for suspension. I also want to say that I am conscious of the deep concerns of the family of Xanana who live in my home city of Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the coalition will be opposing Senator Chamarette's motion to suspend Standing Orders. We are satisfied to date with the actions that have been taken by the Australian Government after this arrest. It has sought assurances from the Indonesian Government at high levels. We have been told by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) that those assurances have been given. It is obviously a matter that the Parliament would want to monitor, certainly in view of an unfortunate record, I think, in relation to human rights in East Timor over a long time.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, the assurances that have been given and some actions that were taken by the Indonesian Government after the killings in East Timor give cautious reason for hope. Therefore it seems to me that debate on the issue at the moment is premature. I would not want that to be misinterpreted because, as with all parliamentarians here, I am concerned that this particular man be dealt according to proper process and fairly. But I would not want to prejudge that he will not be, particularly in the circumstances of the assurances that have been given by the Indonesian Government.

There is some suggestion that there may be an opportunity for consultation as to the detail of a motion that the Senate might consider some time in the not too distant future, and I would certainly be pleased to be party to such consultation. I actually have some difficulty with part of the drafting of the motion that would be debated today if Standing Orders were to be suspended. For obvious reasons, I think it is probably better that such issues of differences of language be dealt with out of the chamber rather than through the form of amendments here today. So, if such consultation is initiated by Senator Chamarette or others, I would be pleased to be a party to it and see whether a set of words could be agreed. But suspension at the moment to debate this issue in full is premature in view of the fact that I think the Australian Government has made the right representations and so far, at least, has received the right assurances.

TALK.START.PARA: —This chamber from time to time does a number of quite silly things but now and again it does something that is intelligent. I think it did something intelligent when it set half an hour for debate with five-minute speeches on the suspension of Standing Orders and allowed senators to range from the question of suspension to the substantive issue. I have to agree with Senator McMullan that this is a very important issue, but it is appropriate that it be accorded that half-hour debate.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to hear Senator McMullan quote the Governor-General's observation about words being bullets in foreign affairs. If words be bullets, well then let us fire some back at the Indonesians because, by God, they have fired enough at the East Timorese people. I think it is about time we stood up and took more note of things like civil liberties and the rights of the East Timorese people rather than the economic relationships that we might have with the Indonesians. Senator Powell noted a moment ago our overweening concern with the possible discovery of oil in the Timor Gap. Senator Powell pointed out that she, the then Senator Vallentine and the Democrats voted against the treaty.

Ever since our foundation the Democrats have taken the view that the East Timorese have a right to their own territory and that we should have stood up much more solidly for the rights of the East Timorese against the Indonesian people. There is nothing whatsoever in the history of the East Timorese people or, indeed, in the history of the people of West Irian or West New Guinea which gives the Indonesian people a natural right to occupy those territories. I am ashamed that Australia has taken the attitude that it has ever since 1975. If we had taken a more forthright attitude then, I believe that we may not be in the difficulty we are in now.

There is no doubt that Mr Gusmao is an extremely brave man. As Senator Powell has pointed out, his family have been living in Australia; they have been separated from him over a long period. He is a man who is fighting for the independence and the rights of the men and women of his country. There is nothing, particularly in the recent history of the Indonesian treatment of the East Timorese, to give us any confidence whatsoever that he will get fair treatment. We therefore, as a separate and sovereign nation with some relationships with Indonesia, have a responsibility to put very very strong pressure on the Indonesian people to ensure that Mr Gusmao's rights and safety are protected.

One need only reflect, of course, on the recent remarks of the new governor of East Timor that—and I think I am quoting him more or less correctly—more people should have been shot in Dili just over a year ago. A person who expresses those sorts of views is hardly somebody to be trusted when dealing with a man who, since the earliest days of the Indonesian occupation of East Timor, has been battling to overturn that occupation.

So I would strongly support the motion. Certainly, we did not object to Senator Chamarette's motion being declared formal. It should have been a formal motion of the Senate and then a motion of the Parliament. Indeed, it would have been a very useful bullet for this Government and this Parliament to fire back at the Indonesian people. We feel that the time allotted for debating the suspension of Standing Orders is sufficient to air these issues. We hope that the Indonesian people who are listening to this debate will take this matter very much to heart.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. As the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and, before him, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) have said, there is grave concern about the fate of Gusmao. This view is also held by people who would quibble about one aspect of this notice of motion. Nevertheless, this concern needs to be expressed not only by the Government through the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) but also by the representatives of the people—that is to say, this Parliament. I was very encouraged to hear what both the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and the Leader of the Opposition said and the indication by both of them that ultimately there needs to be an expression about this issue.

PARA.TAB: This is an urgent issue. At the present moment we do not know the fate of Gusmao and we should be asking for representatives of the International Red Cross and his family to visit. Our relationship with Indonesia is broad enough, strong enough and mature enough for it to understand a resolution by this chamber calling upon it to adhere to international standards of human rights and its own code of criminal procedure in this case, as well as in cases of persons who have been arrested in connection with Mr Gusmao's arrest. That is what Senator Chamarette has been saying. I believe that our relationship with the Indonesian Government is mature enough for it to accept that indication. It is a matter of urgency.

As has been indicated, this has been a fruitful exercise thus far. It is important that Senator Chamarette understand that, if the matter then comes back to us in a day or so, we can then get a unanimous resolution about the issue. It is obvious that at the moment we will not get a unanimous decision, even if the motion for suspension is adopted. I would like there to be a unanimous decision. That is not to say that we are likely always to achieve that; but on issues of human rights, over the years this chamber has stood up for individual human rights. That has been one of our major roles. Our roles have been to stand up for the rights of the States and for individual human rights. Most of us stand up for the rights of the States, either in this chamber or in party meetings, committees and so on. We should stand shoulder to shoulder for our States in this chamber more often. In this chamber we can exercise that function very firmly and stand shoulder to shoulder in support of human rights, not only within Australia but also elsewhere. That is another important function, and it is in the exercise of that function that we are likely to shine.

I indicated to Senator Chamarette my support for the suspension of Standing Orders. Following the speeches made around the chamber, it may well be that we should try to get this matter up when we can get a unanimous vote.
Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

TAB.TAB: (1)That, in view of the inability of the committee of the whole to consider adequately appropriations for the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy because of the operation of the guillotine on 17 November 1992, the following items of expenditure be referred to the standing committees specified, for inquiry and report by 7 December 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology—

PARA.TAB: Divisions 365-372—Industrial Relations, $162 159 000
Divisions 910,912—Industrial Relations, $9 445 000

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—

PARA.TAB: Divisions 490-495—Primary Industries and Energy, $479 432 000
Divisions 930-932—Primary Industries and Energy, $308 806 000.

TAB.TAB: (2)That, in considering those items of expenditure, the standing committees meet in public session.
(3)That, in considering those items of expenditure, the standing committees consider only matters which would have been open for consideration in the committee of the whole.

(4)That, during consideration of those items of expenditure, questions may be put to Ministers and departmental officers by members of the committees and other Senators attending the committees in the same manner as in Estimates Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a most important matter, Mr President. As you are aware, the Democrats and the Labor Party conspired on 17 November to force the guillotine on the considerations by the Senate of the Appropriations legislation. In so doing, almost $1 billion of expenditure was not subjected to the appropriate appraisal, scrutiny and checking by this Senate. In particular, the appropriations of the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy were not considered in the Appropriations debate.

PARA.TAB: It is very important to ask why the Australian Democrats in particular would have taken such an important decision and created such an important precedent. By forcing the guillotine and denying the Committee of the Whole the proper consideration, a number of very important issues were not addressed by way of debate, as they ought to have been from the reservations that had previously been considered. If one looks at the proposed running sheet for both the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, some very important issues were to have received the consideration of the Committee of the Whole. Under Industrial Relations, there were payments to members of the building industry working group, industrial relations activities in schools, the activities of the Australian Trade Union Training Authority, the activities of the Construction Industry Development Authority, particularly its business plan, and the remuneration structures and conditions of the Australian Public Service. Obviously, the Australian Democrats did not want to turn their attention to any of those very important issues.

Under the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, that approach is even more surprising when we consider that almost $800m of Federal expenditure to the resources sector—that is, the primary industries of Australia—was denied the accountability and scrutiny that ought to have taken place in this chamber. The Australian Democrats made a decision not to consider such important industry issues as petroleum, particularly the application of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. One would wonder why, given the proposals we have in Fightback to make sure that there will be tremendous cost savings not only to primary industries but also to all people and households throughout Australia.

The whole program of coal and minerals was to be considered, along with many rural adjustments and services, the appcation of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and, probably very importantly, the issue of the importation of live pigs, genetic materials and pig meat. Anyone would wonder why the Government and the Democrats conspired to keep this consideration away, particularly when Senator Michael Baume has put down in this place important considerations that have to be now pursued through the Australian Securities Commission but were denied proper appraisal through the Appropriations. We all know that the Prime Minister has a vested and personal interest in the issue of live pigs and genetic materials. The Government and the Democrats decided that they were not going to pursue that matter.

There was also the matter of the Government's misuse of over $2m of wasted money on an energy guide, a document that was floated out into the community under totally false pretences. The Australian Democrats would not have wanted this document debated. We all know that the energy policies of the Australian Democrats revolve around using gum leaves for dunny paper and not getting on with the damn proper issues that relate to energy.

The issues of geoscience research and resource and the important activities of the Bureau of Mineral Resources are important considerations. As I have said, it involves $960m of Federal Government expenditure which the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party, for their own party political reasons, did not want given adequate consideration.

The motion I have presented to the Senate would provide a mechanism whereby the Senate by referring this matter to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs could properly appraise this expenditure, the activities and the policies of the Government. I have not sought for those standing committees to go any further than the consideration that Senator Colston would have allowed as Chairman of Committees under the particular motions that would have been considered under the Appropriations Bill. I have covered that in my motion.

Similarly, I have asked that the Ministers and the departmental officers should present themselves. I would sincerely request that the Australian Democrats reconsider the draconian action of applying a guillotine to $1 billion of Federal Government expenditure that it just does not want exposed. I would hope they would reconsider the position they have taken and support my motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us a motion which could be the precursor of a significant extension of the review of the appropriations process and one which, if taken after due consideration, could even lead to an improvement. This is something that I think many people in the Opposition oppose and which I have supported. I refer to the issue of dealing with appropriations through legislative and general purpose committees rather than the special process of Estimates committees. It is a great pity that that interesting idea, that kernel of something that one day may turn out to be a useful reform, should be smothered in such a coverage of humbug.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is an absolutely, deliberately and wantonly misleading contribution by Senator Tambling about why the industrial relations—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator McMullan, I am not sure that it is really appropriate for you to say that it is an absolute deliberate misleading of the chamber. You might like to consider rephrasing your words.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying that, whether by accident or design, he misled the Senate. What he has said has given an entirely false impression to the people of Australia. It implies that there was no adequate time for consideration of either Industrial Relations or Primary Industries and Energy estimates and that, for some reason, this was because a time limit was operating.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, that statement fails to take into account that we had the full, normal Estimates committee process for both departments; they were both dealt with in the Estimates Committee process. This is the second version. The second thing is that the failure to deal with these matters is in some way considered to be the responsibility of the Government and the Democrats, who allowed 200 hours for the consideration of Estimates.

The Opposition, through its inefficiency or through its conscious choice—I cannot tell which—set priorities that used those 200 hours without getting to these areas. It is in no way our responsibility that the Opposition wasted all that time, that it had people standing up for 10 minutes reading into the Hansard record public documents. That was not our time. Those opposite could have used that time to deal with Industrial Relations and Primary Industries and Energy. But we had people getting up and asking the same question five times in a row. That was not a time limit that anybody but those opposite put on it.

If this motion is carried, what we are saying is, `Here is a reward for inefficiency. If you take 200 hours and waste it, we will give you a bonus. If you take 200 hours of the Senate's time and fail to do the things for which you are responsible, we will give you a reward'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is only your judgment.

—What I have said is a statement of fact. The Opposition has failed to use these 200 hours to deal with these matters which it now considers crucially important. It is for the Opposition to say whether it thinks it is more important than the things which everybody else in Australia who read the record would think the Opposition wasted its time on.

PARA.TAB: This motion is an encouragement to the Opposition to fail to organise its time, to waste time, not to have the guts amongst its leadership to discipline those people in the Senate who everybody knows abuse the process and waste time. The Opposition is saying that those people can have a free hand forever and that if other people in the Opposition are disadvantaged as a consequence, we will come in with a special process to give it a bonus for being inefficient, to give it a reward for wasting time.

There has never been an Estimates process that gave more time to the Senate to consider appropriations than this. There has not been a more generous allocation. It is simply that those opposite blew it. This is a resolution designed to satisfy the internal tensions in the Opposition, which knows that its members wasted the time. They blew it pursuing red herrings, going off at tangents and chasing irrelevant issues when they should have been concentrating on issues they now think are vitally important. They had the chance and they blew it. I hope the Senate does not give them a second chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting Senator Tambling's motion. However, we agree with practically everything Senator McMullan has said. The claim in the motion that, because of the operation of the guillotine on 17 November, the following items of expenditure be referred, et cetera, is totally rejected by us and we fully support what Senator McMullan has just said.

PARA.TAB: With over 160 hours of questioning in the Estimates committees and a further 30-odd hours, making up over 200 hours altogether, in which all these matters could be considered, it is certainly not the fault of either the Government or, as Senator Tambling tried to imply, the Democrats in supporting the guillotine on Tuesday of last week. It is certainly not our fault that the Opposition failed to get into these areas which Senator Tambling himself has identified is so important—$800m worth of expenditure, as he says.

Why the devil did Opposition members not get into it? They simply were, as Senator McMullan said, inefficient and unable to control certain people in their own ranks who wasted that time, who went excessively into byways and pathways which had nothing to do whatsoever with the appropriations. I think any person who picks up the Hansard and reads through in a dispassionate way a record of those appropriation debates would have to agree that the Opposition was totally incompetent in the way in which it allocated time.

Having said that, we will certainly not be party, as Senator Tambling implied that we may be, to any process which allows the Government to get off the hook from proper scrutiny. We simply make the plea that in future the Opposition will not use this as a way of getting around the guillotine and that this does not become a standard procedure by means of which it can waste even more time.

We all know the motives of the Opposition in recent weeks. They are to ensure that the Government gets as little of its legislation through as possible and to frustrate the processes of government. When the count was made last week, it was found that we had had something like 19 1/2 hours only on all the other legislation before this Parliament—roughly, a ratio of 10:1 on appropriations and all other legislation put together. The Opposition has been very effective in frustrating the proper processes of this Senate. However, we certainly will not be party to frustrating the proper scrutiny of the $800m to which Senator Tambling referred. So while we object to his invective or his castigation of the Democrats—we find it totally without foundation—we will indeed be supporting this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not support this motion—not that it will make a great deal of difference when it is all boiled down and counted out. But I think Senator McMullan and Senator Coulter have been rather too kind to the Opposition in their speeches. I understand why Senator McMullan needs to be—he has to run this place—and Senator Coulter has his own problems as well.

PARA.TAB: I want to tell it like it is. It was obvious after the first six months—probably even earlier than that—following the last election, or by the end of 1990, that we were in the 1993 election campaign in this chamber, and in the community. If the election spending figures, when they come out after the next election, are to be accurate figures that really tell what was spent in running the Federal election for 1993, they should include at least half the costs of this Senate since the last election. Since about December 1990, an election campaign has been conducted in this place. The Opposition has got away with it because the discipline in this chamber and internally within the parties has not been strict, and discipline has not been imposed by the numbers which would be available through the Government and the Democrats.

The choice has really been between a guillotine and a filibuster. We have experienced a 2 1/2 year filibuster in this chamber. It has been frustrating, annoying and not much of it has been very edifying.

It has always been my view that at the beginning of each sitting period an agreed timeframe should be put down—agreed via the parties in this chamber. It should be able to be agreed to amongst the leadership, the Whips and the Manager of Government Business. They are adults who ought to be conscious of their civic responsibilities and issues such as freedom of speech for all members of this chamber who represent their State, constituency and political party and who carry portfolio responsibilities. I believe that it can be done and that it must be done.

It is possible that we could continue to sit into the week leading to Christmas. We have done it before. We have left here 24 or 36 hours before sitting down to Christmas dinner at home. I have always expected the turkey to be barbequed in one of the courtyards one of these days. I even have some cranberry sauce in my fridge in my office.

The reason that we have a hectic end of year session is that we do not discipline ourselves at the beginning of the session. I know that the Opposition always leaps up and says that it is because the Government does not have anything for us to do. That is not true, and it has certainly not been true in the last 18 months to two years. There is work that can be done, and constructive work can be put forward by the Opposition, the Democrats and Independents in this chamber.

But we come to the end, there is a frantic rush and the guillotine finally gets applied. The Opposition then finds a way around it which, as Senator Coulter suggested, is what this motion really represents; it is a way around the guillotine. The guillotine has been applied in haste and it has meant that important deliberations have been stopped in midstream.

The point has also been made that 200 hours have been made available for the Estimates and the Appropriations debates. I wonder whether the public realises that the Supply Bills finally passed through this chamber as a result of that guillotine only on 17 November 1992. I seem to remember that 11 November 1975 was considered too long to wait for the passage of the supply Bills and that, in fact, a government was tipped out. I have not checked completely, but my memory is that the passing of Supply has not been achieved by the Parliament and the Government before 11 November in any of the years that I have been here since 1986.

The Senate really has to look at its responsibility, both as a House of review and in terms of the way that it organises and behaves itself. I do not think that this rather inglorious end to this session—it may very well be the last one we have in the life of this Government—really is much recommendation for the sort of adult behaviour that I am sure those who elect us to this place expect of us.

I urge those who are in positions of influence and control in their respective parties in this chamber when next we return, be it after an election or in the last days of this Government before an election but certainly next year, to look again, as has been done before—I know that it was attempted because I was one of that group at the time—at the very serious proposition that each sitting session set itself a goal and adhere to that goal to the greatest possible extent, deviating from it only when something really significant determines that that should happen, not just because an ill-disciplined back bench of an opposition, which is desperate to get into government, runs rampant and is not able to be controlled and disciplined by its leadership.

I hope that we can act with more maturity as a chamber in sitting periods to come. I do not support this motion because it is a way around a guillotine which I believe should have been an agreed process throughout this session and previous sessions. It is therefore a last minute attempt to make another political point, of which there have been hundreds and hundreds over the last many months.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up the time of the Senate on a motion that is designed to save the time of the Senate. I will make it clear to people what the motion is because there seem to be quizzical expressions on the faces of some people. This is a motion to reduce speeches on the second reading to 20 minutes, which I will formally move. Everybody knows the mischief which we are trying to redress—and I do not say that in the pejorative sense. Everyone knows the problem with which we are trying to deal in proposing this matter.

PARA.TAB: Everybody is capable of making a quick assessment. They know that we need to manage the business of the Senate more efficiently. They know that 30-minute speeches do not contribute 50 per cent more content than 20-minute speeches. What we usually get here is a three-minute speech 10 times over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—On odd occasions we get a good 20-minute speech with a 10-minute conclusion.
—You have already offended your colleague.

—That does not make it wrong. It is a matter about which I feel fairly strongly. Given that technically I have a right of reply in moving the motion, I will simply formally put it before the chamber. I move:

PARA.TAB: That a Senator shall not speak for more than 20 minutes in a debate on a motion for the second reading of a bill considered during the remainder of the 1992 sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The view we would take is that there is certainly scope for discipline in this place. It is very important that we all concentrate on ensuring that we are not simply repetitious. But irresistible temptations seem to strike both sides of the chamber. Even within a 20-minute speech one can find a great deal of repetition. If one measures the contributions in terms of their ultimate impact in the media, by and large one can often say that a senator might have been better off making a few quick sentences by way of a contribution.

PARA.TAB: Ultimately, we say that it does not make a great deal of sense to simply focus on one aspect when, although we have not done research on this in recent times, one would find that relatively very few speeches exceed the 20-minute limit; there are occasional ones. But there are a number of other reasons why we can say that time gets taken up in a whole range of other areas that have nothing to do with the second reading debates. In other words, one has only to look at the amount of time that was spent on the Appropriations, the committee stage of various Bills and a whole range of other agenda items to realise that cutting back to 20 minutes the occasional speech which might have gone beyond 20 minutes will make virtually no difference.

It is probably much more important that we focus on self-discipline. One cannot actually impose limits short of a draconian measure. We were not really forced to that point in terms of Question Time, but it was a very salutary lesson in how one can concentrate the mind if one tries to achieve a particular result. But if the result we seek to achieve here is that the time of the Senate is not taken up endlessly in verbose discussions, one has to focus on a lot more than the occasional speech on the second reading.

Therefore, it is important that we look at a range of other areas. Hopefully, discussions will take place between the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) and our side of the chamber to identify whether there are other ways in which we might bring about what I think we would all like to see—that is, much fewer sittings after midnight and many more contributions that are pithy and succinct, certainly in the committee stage and during the Appropriations debate. The most recent episode which is fresh in the minds of us all is when we found ourselves sitting until 6.30 a.m. and I subsequently found myself on a 7.30 a.m. flight ready to do a full day's work in Melbourne and have discussions with a whole range of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never done one in your life.

—One has to do it from time to time and I am sure even the Minister for Transport and Communications forces himself along. The end result is quite unsatisfactory in terms of performance. If we examine ourselves and the way in which matters have proceeded in recent weeks, we would conclude that the reason for those sorts of extraordinary sittings has very little to do with the fact that the occasional second reading contribution has gone beyond the 20-minute limit. Therefore, the ultimate solution lies in much more wide-ranging discussions about how we tackle the problems. Certainly, there is a willingness on our side to pursue those matters.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that we understand what the Manager of Government Business is trying to achieve, but simply focusing on one narrow aspect is not likely to make any significant difference in the scheme of things. I would be interested to know whether he has done any research to determine how many speeches have exceeded 20 minutes in the last few months. I suspect that whilst there might be a handful, we could probably point to a difference of an hour or two at most. When we look at why we have been sitting extraordinary hours and why we are likely to in the future, we see that it has nothing to do with second reading debates. We would therefore oppose this motion and hope that there will be much more wide-ranging discussion about trying to pursue the business of the Senate in a more rational way than sometimes is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support Senator Alston's comments. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) really has a nerve to come in here and, in effect, imply that the problem with the program for the balance of this session is the length of speeches. That is not the problem; the problem is the shambles of the program. With four weeks remaining—one of those four weeks being an additional week that we agreed to during the last sitting week—the Government has some 76 packages of legislation still to be debated. We still have not even seen some of those pieces of legislation. This morning we read in the press of the Government's latest position in relation to tobacco advertising. We have not seen that Bill; it has not been through our processes.

PARA.TAB: Obviously in the run-up to the election the Government has decided that it is time it got some runs on the board in relation to certain matters. All of a sudden the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has woken up to the unsatisfactory level of violence on television being shown at certain times of the night when children are watching. He suddenly develops this passionate interest for that subject. We now find that the Government needs to take away the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill, which is supposed to be debated and concluded today, in order that it might draft further amendments. The Government should just support Senator Walters's amendment and the problem will be solved.

The Government program is a shambles. The Government has not managed it properly. There is too much work to be properly scrutinised within the time that is available. Rather than facing up to that deficiency, Senator McMullan has come in here today and said, `We can solve it by limiting the time of speeches', without any research being done or evidence put before the chamber as to whether the length of speeches has contributed to delay.

I support what Senator Alston said. There are not many speeches in this place now that go beyond 20 minutes. But there are occasions—Senator McMullan would know this in relation to complex taxation law or other matters of great detail; there is a corporations law package coming up—when it might be necessary for a speech to be given for the full 30 minutes. It should be given for that period if necessary in order that the Senate properly fulfil its function.

The prescription in our Standing Orders is not that speeches will be 30 minutes; rather that they will be a maximum of 30 minutes. That has within it the flexibility that is necessary in order that the process of scrutiny might be properly carried out. To attempt to restrict honourable senators to a shorter period does nothing to enhance the scrutiny function of this chamber and the case for it simply has not been made out by the Government. For that reason, we will oppose the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most interesting things about being in the Senate chamber and as an observer of human behaviour is to watch the chameleon-like face of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) who, throughout the whole of his speech, could hardly avoid taking the smile from his physiognomy. Considerable discussion went on as a prelude to this. I understood that Senator Hill personally was in agreement with the idea of a limitation of time. I do not think Senator McMullan in any sense has claimed that this will be a complete solution to the problem of filibustering, time-wasting and repetitious points either in the second reading debate or in the committee stage. However, it is a move in that direction.

PARA.TAB: If it is the case that a large majority of second reading speeches can be compressed into the 20-minute time interval, that is an appropriate time limit to set. We will at least then save some time. Even if we get to bed 10 minutes earlier in the evening when we are going into the early hours of morning, that is something. Senator Herron was very right when he expressed concern about the very late sittings.

The discussion which went on earlier with Senator Hill did go further. In fact, the suggestion was made that the Opposition might have only two speakers at the second reading stage, the Government two speakers, the Democrats one and the Independents one. That was something that was being considered. Clearly, the Opposition was not prepared to do that. That was put forward in recognition of the fact that it is at the second reading stage when the broad attitude to legislation is clearly enunciated. It is in the committee stage that the substantial debates occur and changes to legislation are made by way of amendment.

It is quite appropriate to limit the amount of time in the second reading stage to 20 minutes.
