Several speakers from each side can fully enunciate and elaborate the attitudes of their party to a piece of legislation, bearing in mind that when they want to actually implement that general attitude by way of specific amendments they have adequate time in the committee stage. For that reason, we will support the Government's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I am one of the few senators who really offend in this area in that from to time I do go over 20 minutes. I really do not apologise for that. At the same time I wish to put on the record the fact that I do not believe my contributions are time-wasting or repetitious. When confronted by complex tax legislation which frequently involves hundreds of pages of new legislation and explanatory memoranda, this Senate has a duty to examine very closely what is before it. It often involves raising large amounts of revenue and putting individuals to a lot of additional administrative expense in the paraphernalia that is required under the new legislation, which can impact on taxpayers' rights and change the competitive position of various corporations within the Australian sector.

PARA.TAB: A major development has been the referral of Bills to committees outside this chamber, where we have the opportunity of bringing in outsiders and debating some of these issues, again, somewhat under a guillotine, because time is restricted. At the same time, I think there is a responsibility on the Government not to lump groups of Bills together. For example, today the Government has introduced four Bills—Nos 3, 4, 5 and 6—to be debated at the second reading stage. These Bills involve car parking, Medicare amendment, child support and superannuation. This means that, under this restriction, there is virtually only five minutes for such legislation.

There are lots of anomalies; there are lots of problems with certain features of this legislation. It is important that it be put on the public record at the second reading stage so that those people who are interested in coming before the Committee to discuss the Bills—which in this case would be on Friday, 11 December—have the opportunity of reading the debates to see whether their interest might be affected. Unless we can tease out a few of these issues, we are not doing our job in this chamber. Whether this motion is supported or not, I will give an undertaking to try to abide by the 20-minute rule which will apply between now and the close of business because I think this is important. At the same time, I think it is incumbent on the Government not to use the cognate principle excessively by grouping Bills together and then limiting the debate on that sum total.

TALK.START.PARA: —With another example of breathtaking hypocrisy we see the Democrats again siding with the Government in an effort to restrict free speech in this Parliament and the right of senators to fully discuss all aspects of the legislation before them. If the Democrats had any concern at all for the institutions of democracy, they would get on to their mates in the Labor Party and tell them to do something about this atrociously managed program that comes before us at this time every year. If Senator Coulter were concerned about these things that he talks about, why did he not get the Government—the Labor Party—to do something about the atrocious program earlier in the session? He could have encouraged the Government to bring some of these Bills on instead of leaving it until now and then joining with the Government in curtailing the free speech and the right of all members of parliament to discuss things fully.

PARA.TAB: I support what Senator Watson says. He gets involved in a lot of complicated speeches about complicated Bills. It is a pity that the Democrats and Government Ministers did not listen a bit more to Senator Watson, because they then might understand what some of this legislation is all about. It is very obvious from the number of times that legislation has to be amended that not even the Government Ministers who are dealing with these things understand what they are about. By curtailing the likes of Senator Watson and others from fully pointing out to senators what those Bills are about, we simply lead ourselves into this situation again.

Today the Government's management incapability is again shown when there are three Government responses to be dealt within a limited period of time. I was on one of those committees that will be dealt with today in the Government responses. We took many days of evidence around Australia. People put a lot of time into that Committee. Witnesses put an enormous amount of time into making their views known with the intention of helping this Parliament properly determine what should be done with Australia's space agency. But here we have the Government bringing in a response and we will get a maximum of two or three minutes to comment on it.

It is just not good enough, and it is another example of this Government's terrible record when it comes to trying to manage this chamber. It is no wonder the Government cannot manage the country. It is no wonder the foreign debt is in excess of $150 billion; it is no wonder that there are a million of our fellow Australians unemployed when it is all done under the management of this Government. It cannot even manage this chamber let alone manage the country.

I am disappointed but not surprised at the attitude the Democrats are now taking. Of course, when anything important comes along, the Democrats go home. They make us stay, they guillotine things and, when the crunch comes, their people go off home. In the Estimates committees that we are so interested in and that mean so much to the way this Parliament, this Government and this nation works, the Democrats do not even turn up. They are not interested. They do not even bother involving themselves in those things.

I heard Senator Coulter suggesting a minute ago some sort of speaking order where the Government have two speakers, we have two and they have one. The Democrats have about one-fifth of the numbers that we have and yet they want half of the speaking time. That is fairly typical of what the Democrats are all about. They represent 4 per cent of the Australian public, but want to have 50 per cent of the speaking time. We represent more than 50 per cent of the Australian people and he wants us to have just double the speaking time that the Democrats have.

As I said, it is another example of breathtakingly hypocritical actions by the Democrats in yet again joining with this poor Government—this Government that is incapable of managing either the chamber or the country—in trying to curtail the speech of senators and trying to curtail our side from doing something sensible about the direction in which this country is moving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Macdonald a moment ago said that the Democrats go home. I guess that implies that I have gone home. I have never left this chamber. I have been here for every one of the debates which have occurred in this session and, as I recall it, in the last session of parliament. I have never even had a day off. So the claim that I have gone home and left the Opposition debating matters is totally without any foundation and is absolutely untrue.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator McMullan's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: BROADCASTING SERVICES (SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.
Clause 1 agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES (SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TEST PERMIT TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to expedite the Committee stage, would Senator Alston and Senator Bourne agree to move the Government, Opposition and Democrat amendments in block form? We have done that successfully on previous occasions.
—Is Senator Collins proposing that I move the Opposition amendments now?
—Yes.
—Is that satisfactory to the Australian Democrats? That being agreed, the question is that clause 2 stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Walters, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 2, page 1, lines 7 to 9, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: "2.(1) Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

PARA.TAB: "(2) Section 4 commences on 1 March 1993.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment simply provides for a separate commencement date for an amendment which Senator Walters will be moving in relation to clause 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Alston has already said, this amendment provides for a commencement time for my amendment. Therefore, all it does is give the commercial television stations time to adjust to the alteration in the time slot of AO programs. It gives them breathing space in order to allow the alteration to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to the substantive amendment. The Government will be opposing the amendment. It might have been a good idea had the Opposition allowed the shadow Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Smith, the opportunity of drafting this amendment because nobody who is interested in the issue of gratuitous violence, sex or language on television could possibly support this amendment. It is an extraordinarily bad piece of drafting—
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Are we discussing the commencement time?
—We are discussing your amendment No. 1.
—That is right. It is just that the Minister is not referring to that particular amendment.
—We are discussing amendment No. 1. It is my understanding that your second amendment is consequent upon amendment No. 1. So the Minister has to refer to the second amendment at some stage.

—That is correct. I am explaining to the Committee why we are opposing this amendment. We are opposing it because of the substantial difficulties we have with the substantive amendment. The two are linked together. We are opposing the starting time because we think that the amendment is fundamentally flawed in a most extraordinary way. I canvassed this last night in committee, but I want to repeat it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters said on public radio this morning in Sydney that the Government had a secret agenda, or accused the Government of having a secret agenda, in trying to get more violence on television. That was a proposition that was put to me that I had to respond to. I rejected that assertion. As I said last night in response to questions from Senator Harradine, the Government has no intention of allowing any programs to be broadcast on television under these new classifications that are currently not allowed.

As I speak, John Dickie is in my office, and we will be meeting today to advance this matter so as to bring it back to the chamber no later, I would think, than next week. If we did have a secret agenda, we would be supporting Senator Walters's amendment and not opposing it because it is just extraordinarily bad drafting, and I will explain why. Referring to the four substantive parts of the new classification for AO, (a), (b), (c) and (d), paragraph (a) states:
A program is classified as AO if:
(a)it contains physical and psychological violence—

SPEECH.PARA: fine—
but only where the level of realistically depicted physical and psychological violence which it contains is appropriate to the storyline or program . . .

I understand what Senator Walters is trying to do, but the amendment fundamentally not only defeats the purpose but goes 180 degrees in the wrong direction. Exactly the same wording is used in respect of sexual behaviour in clause (b) and in clause (c) with respect to bad language. The amendment specifically states that the physical and psychological violence, the sexual behaviour and the offensive language only apply for classification when all of these things are `appropriate to the storyline'.

PARA.TAB: The amendment is completely silent about what happens when the sex is gratuitous, the violence is gratuitous and the language is gratuitous and does not relate to the storyline at all. I understand the Democrats have had their own independent advice on this which fundamentally confirms the comprehensive advice I have on it. Frankly, I do not think that the television channels would be crazy enough to take the opportunity offered to them under this amendment, but they technically can.

Under this amendment, a program that contains loads of offensive language, loads of gratuitous sex and loads of gratuitous violence does not fall within the definition drafted by Senator Walters for AO and, therefore, is not something about which a standard could be made by the ABA under the amendment. There is a separate piece of law which prohibits X material being broadcast. But, under Senator Walters's extraordinary amendment, if a program contained gratuitous sex, gratuitous violence and gratuitous language which did not relate to the storyline but was not strong enough to classify as X, it could be broadcast instead of Play School at 3.30 in the afternoon.

I am not suggesting that anything as bizarre as that would occur. But I am saying that the amendment is technically badly flawed and does not provide any sensible guidance to the ABA to set standards. The fundamental flaw in each one of the sections of the amendment I have referred to on language, sexual activity and violence is that it is totally silent on the question of where all this occurs and is not related to the storyline and program context and can therefore not be given a classification.

I do not know whether this related to the haste with which this amendment was put together. I do understand what Senator Walters is trying to do. But the amendment fundamentally not only does not achieve this but also provides an opportunity, at least technically, for material to be put to air with no classification. I am sure that is not what the Committee intends to do. As I said, I do not think that any television broadcaster would be crazy enough to do such a thing, but I do think that the Committee has an obligation to support better law than this.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment because the legislation governing broadcasting and transport and communications will be back with us, as the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) just told us, within a week. We have looked at his first draft which came before the chamber last night, as we all know, at a very advanced hour. We think that, substantially, it is an excellent first draft of a new classification of film, television and video. It is about time we had a single classification for all of those.

PARA.TAB: We will, of course, look very closely at what the Minister comes up with, and we look forward to seeing it in about a week. If what he comes up with does not address the problems that we can see, as far as Senator Walters is concerned, with violence on television at an early hour—and we do and have seen that for a long time as a major problem with Australian classification of films on television—then we will be supporting what Senator Walters is proposing, if she can redraft it and bring it back at that time. However, at the moment we want to wait and see what happens with the new draft—we understand it is being drafted right now—and we will have a look at it before it comes before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should take the opportunity to canvass some of the matters just raised by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), even though we are technically dealing only with the commencement date. The fact of the matter is that Senator Walters's amendment spells out certain circumstances in which matters can be regarded as falling within the classification of AO but if one goes beyond that point clearly they are either on one side or the other of that dividing line.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the Minister in his wildest dreams would be suggesting that, if one had a program which contained physical and psychological violence which was not appropriate to the storyline, where the violence was unduly bloody or horrific and where it was not presented as desirable, somehow it should be PG or even the lowest level. Quite clearly, it would fall on the other side of the line.

Similarly, with depictions of intimate sexual behaviour or nudity, we impose a number of limitations that would allow that to be classified as AO and therefore broadcast within a certain time band but subject only to those limitations. On an unlimited basis, it clearly could not be open season. All we would then be considering is the fact that it would not be allowed to be broadcast at all.

We are agnostic at this stage about a revised classification system, because quite clearly in the Government's haste to try to stitch up some sort of eleventh hour compromise we have not yet had the opportunity to see the various definitions of the categories. That is one of the major concerns of Senator Walters. If we assume good faith, if we assume that AO as it currently exists on television is simply subdivided into M and MA, one can understand the logic of the softer levels of violence being classified as M and therefore being allowed to be broadcast earlier than those that are classified MA. But if the Government does not act in good faith and then redefines MA to include matters that currently cannot be shown at all on free to air television, one would then have a fundamentally different situation.

Clearly, no-one ought to be in the business of giving the Government a blank cheque. Clearly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been ducking and weaving on this issue for some days now. Our amendment is simply in line with his original starting point. It is designed to ensure that we do not allow the level of gratuitous violence that is currently able to be shown at 8.30 in the evening to continue to be shown. All sides now accept that there has to be a better way.

In those circumstances we are simply putting forward a formula that would enable certain matters to be deferred until 9.30 p.m. and others to be out of court altogether. Ultimately, the reclassification system is one we will look at carefully. To the extent that it does pick up those concerns, and particularly Senator Walters's concern—that nothing is able to come in via the back door which is not able to be shown on television at all at the moment—then we may have the makings of a better approach to the game.

Certainly, at the present time, I think one could say that the system is a shambles. The Government has allowed this to continue for years. Clearly, the Prime Minister, in raising this matter, was seeking cynically to milk community concern on the issue as a desperate diversion from the state of the economy. Having done that, and having run into some opposition in various quarters, he is now scrambling for a compromise. We do not know the details of that. Senator Walters quite rightly expresses concern that, until we have seen the whites of their eyes and the precise classifications, it is impossible to make ultimate judgments.

But, in the meantime, it ought to be acknowledged that what we are doing here today is reflecting community concerns which, at their most recent, have been canvassed in this morning's Australian, which shows that 72 per cent want violent adults only television material to be screened after 9.30 p.m. That is what I think is at issue here. That is why we are proposing this amendment. It is not designed to take effect immediately. We recognise that the networks do have inventories that accumulate and that should not be rendered redundant overnight. We therefore propose a starting date of 1 March to allow a sufficient opportunity for a rearrangement of scheduling of programs. But, otherwise, we are attempting to tackle the issue in a specific way which contrasts very much with the Government's absolute failure to tackle the issue at all.

We are now given a promise that the Government will come back in a week or two with some more specific proposals. We will await those with interest. But the fact remains that the community continues to be very concerned, not only about the level of gratuitous violence but about some of the fairly specious explanations that are trotted out.

I have only to recall seeing the justification for Romper Stomper as recently as the other day. I do not know how that would be classified as being proper in the circumstances. The film-makers claim that it is making a statement. I would have thought that the true explanation is that it is making a quid. The community does not need that sort of depiction of what goes on in the western suburbs of Melbourne. That depiction does not seem to bear much relationship to real life. The film-makers might like to pretend that it does and to somehow shelter behind the notion that it is based on fact—but very loosely indeed.

One has only to recall Turtle Beach, which I have not seen but one could assume it was based on a well-written book. The book contains a fairly interesting story line and no doubt had the makings of a very good film. Certainly, the scenery in the film, I am told, is excellent. But the beach massacre scene was clearly and utterly gratuitous; quite inconsistent with the facts of what was supposed to have happened in the circumstances, yet we had the film-makers justifying it on the basis that it was based on truth.

I think very loose depictions of that sort get up the nostrils of most members of the community. All we are left with is film-makers who take the opportunity to trot out some pretty savage sorts of violent scenes and then justify them on these specious bases. That is why we believe that it is long past the time when the Government can simply sit on its hands and ignore community concerns in this area. That is why we have moved to put in place a regime that would toughen up the system, but with an adequate delay so that it does not pose immediate transitional problems, and that does address the issue in a way that the Government is only now starting to deal with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to correct a few things. First of all, Senator Collins is totally and unequivocally incorrect when he says that I said that the Government had a secret agenda. I did not say that this morning at all.
—You said, `We've had the wool pulled over our eyes'.

—Those were also not my words, and nor did I say that the Government had a secret agenda. For heaven's sake, get it straight. Let me move from that inaccuracy to his next one when he said that my amendment is fundamentally flawed. I presume he thinks that the classification I have used there is something I dreamed up. It is not something I dreamed up. Indeed, it is the present classification by the industry, the ABT and the ABA.
—It is not.

—The Minister is interjecting, `It is not'. The ABT has told the Committee that those are its present classifications; and I can read them to the Minister. But, on the same page, it also states what is not suitable for television. So Senator Collins's comment that the commercial television stations could then move to more violent and more explicit visions on television is totally incorrect because the present classifications say that those are not suitable for television.

PARA.TAB: All I did was to use the present classifications that are in this book I have before me which contains the classification criteria presently being used. On that same page, as I say, there is the classification that is not suitable for television. So the industry could not move to stronger stuff. The industry has already got its classification criteria that prohibit it from doing so. The Minister's statement about that is also totally incorrect.

There is great confusion. I have never said that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has done this deliberately. Senator Collins must agree that last night I said that I believed he had been led up the garden path. He did not understand, nor does the majority of the community and nor does the majority, by far, of members in this place. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal put out a report in September this year, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a certain amount of confusion surrounding the AO television and M cinema-video classifications caused by the fact that the AO classification designated as being for 18 years plus is, in fact, more restrictive than for all but the mildest of M classified films which are designated for 15 years plus.
So it is pointed out that there is great confusion between AO and M. It acknowledges that AO is more restrictive—it is far more restrictive—than the majority of M. The report states:
. . . more restrictive than for all but the mildest of M classified films . . .
The report then goes on to say:
We propose that, for the purposes of television broadcasts of M classified material under self-regulation, broadcasters adopt a system—
and this is where Mr Keating got it from; he did not dream up his division of M, as he pretended he did; this is where he got it from—
which splits the M classification into two categories, with the milder material in the lower M range being equated to the current AO. . .
Because that is all it would be equated to—the current AO; and do not forget that he wants that shown at 8.30 p.m.

PARA.TAB: So we have got nowhere. The lower M range equates with the current AO classification, so AO material will still go on at 8.30 p.m. The material in the upper M range, which includes the stronger depictions of sex, violence and coarse language, will be restricted to being broadcast in the unmodified form only after 10.30 p.m. What Mr Keating has fallen for is that that material will go on at 9 p.m., not at 10.30 p.m.

The reason for my putting this forward is that the so-called proposal—the Democrats have called it a draft, but it is not a draft—which the Government put forward late last night gives us nothing, explains nothing and does not answer the question I put to Senator Collins last night. He asked his advisers the answer and they all shook their heads because they did not know. The question was: what are they going to do? Are they going to reclassify G, PG, M and R? Or are they going to stick with the G and the PG and only reclassify M in total, dividing it into two? If they are going to reclassify M in total, they will have to reclassify R. R then has to pick up the extreme violence and extreme explicitness that is pushed out of M.

The fundamental question that I want the Minister to answer today is whether G, PG, M and R as presently classified for video and films are to be totally reclassified and M divided into two. If we do not do so, we are back in a worse position than we are in at the moment because we are allowing AO, or the equivalent lower category of M, to be shown at 8.30 p.m.—not 9 p.m.—and the very violent stuff that presently cannot be shown on television to come on at 9 p.m, not 10.30 p.m., as the ABT has recommended. The Minister has to understand that, according to the last survey, 72 per cent of the population could not care a fig that the commercial television channels might lose some money. I heard the Minister say this morning that they would lose hundreds of millions of dollars. That is not what they say.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said.

—I would be interested to know what figure the Minister puts on it. As I heard it, he said it would be hundreds of millions of dollars. So 72 per cent of the population say that they want violence out until after 9.30 p.m. They certainly do not want to see after 9.30 p.m. more violent stuff than is presently allowed on television.

—No doubt the Democrats, including Senator Bourne, will want to make their own points about this matter. Senator Bourne has already indicated that the Democrats will not support this amendment. I say with the greatest respect to Senator Walters—and I am not suggesting that she is personally at fault—that I have the ABT classifications here in front of me and that I do not understand why those definitions simply were not lifted and used. The problem in a nutshell is that the classifications in the ABT guidelines are cast in the positive mode, whereas the same classifications in terms of the language of the drafting in the amendment have been cast in the negative mode. That is the difficulty.
—Not all draftsmen agree.

—I agree with Senator Alston that it is unlikely in the real world that this would cause a problem, but we are not talking about the situation Senator Alston is talking about, where something is refused classification. These classifications are ABT classifications relating to television. We are not talking about the initial classification made by the Film Censorship Board, where unclassified material simply could not be broadcast, screened or looked at anywhere. We are talking about ABT classifications.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty is simply with the drafting, and I am not suggesting that it is any more than that. The positive mode that is used in the ABT criteria has been turned on its head for some reason by the drafting and cast into a negative mode, which leaves silent the question of what happens to all these things when the violence, sex or language is not related to the storyline, whereas in the positive mode in which it is cast by the ABT guidelines that is not a problem.

I repeat the substantive point, which was raised by Senator Harradine last night: I am not suggesting that this amendment in the real world is going to cause a problem. We have an obligation where we know the drafting could be better to draft it better. I hear what Senator Bourne said about being prepared to support a proposal like this if it is more appropriately drafted. I conclude by saying again categorically for the third time that, whatever the classifications are that are determined in the work that has already commenced, the Government will not permit anything to be screened at any hour on television currently which is currently not permitted to be screened at those hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we get it clear? The Minister commenced his second last contribution by saying that one of the reasons the Government is not supporting this amendment by Senator Walters is that the amendment will allow to be screened on television violent material which is gratuitous. That is what the Minister said. I would like to know where he is getting that advice. I am rather concerned about the advice that he is getting. Last night I believe I was able to indicate that the advice that is being given to him or to the Prime Minister has been faulty. I point out to the Minister, as he should know, that the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1992 enables the new ABA to determine questions of program standards prior to the development of codes of conduct by the industry. I have a document in my hand, dated 1 October 1992, by the new Australian Broadcasting Authority, which says that the provisions of subsection 21 (4) of the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1992 establish standards which have effect under Part 9 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: One of those standards is TPS standard 10, television program standard 10. TPS 10 says that material which is not suitable for television is that with explicit and gratuitous depictions, unduly bloody or horrific depictions; that is, in respect of physical, psychological and sexual violence. That material, under the decisions of the ABA, is prevented from being broadcast or televised. When I say that it is prevented from being televised, I realise that one or two stations might get away with it, but it is a breach of their licence.

Perhaps I am misunderstanding what the Minister says, but I cannot understand how the Minister can get up here and say that, because of the amendment moved by Senator Walters, gratuitous violence will be allowed on television. I just cannot understand that because the new Australian Broadcasting Authority has determined that TPS 10, television program standard 10, which theoretically rules out this material, is to be observed by the commercial television stations. I would like a further explanation. If the Minister has been wrongly advised, I wish he would ask his advisers to give him the proper advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very quickly, the substantive reason that the Government is opposing this amendment—as I am sure Senator Harradine appreciates—is that we disagree with it. I made that clear last night. I just did not want to go over the same ground again; we do want to conclude this debate at some stage. The substantive reason that the Government is opposing this amendment is that we disagree with it, and the fact that we are proposing an alternative which, in fact, we have provided for this morning in the change of the order of the business in removing a Bill from the package in order to have a substantive debate on the detail of what the Government is proposing, which will be done expeditiously.

PARA.TAB: To Senator Harradine I say: the advice that I have is not advice on the question of the standards or advice in respect of classifications at all. It is advice from professional parliamentary draftsmen on the technical drafting aspects of how the amendment is cast; that is all. I invite Senator Harradine to compare the positive way in which the current ABT guidelines are cast with the negative manner in which these amendments have been drafted. So the advice I am getting—and I think it is correct advice, having read it myself—does not relate to any interpretation of the standards; it is simply a technical drafting matter.

I went on to say, and I will repeat it—and I think Senator Alston is correct—that I do not think that in reality it would have the effect of allowing this material to be broadcast on television; I actually went on to say that. All I am saying is: I think there is an obligation, having had this pointed out to me, for amendments that we move here to be drafted in the most explicit and clear form. What I am saying, with respect—and I think I am right—is that this amendment can be better drafted. That is all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would make a brief comment about the question of drafting because it is quite possible and, indeed, not uncommon to find disagreement between competent draftsmen. What we have had here is a classic example of Senator Collins going over the top with—
—Oh, Richard!

—He ought to face up to the consequences of his own rhetoric. It is euphuism of the highest order. What we had initially was Senator Collins saying, `This drafting is so fundamentally flawed you could drive a coach and horses through it'. This is precisely Senator Harradine's point. He was saying that, if this went through, the networks could go out there and have a field day and run the most unrestricted forms of violence because they did not technically qualify as AO. The reality is that he and I well know that, even if it is expressed in this way rather than in his way, the end result is that we will not have hard violence being shown on television.
—I have just said that.

—He has just said it, but it is not what he started off saying. I think he ought to learn the lessons of his own high-flown language. Quite clearly, what we have here is a very minor disagreement about the form of words. If we want to line up draftsmen on both sides of the Parliament and try to get them to agree on a compromise, that can be done. But it is not the way the system works in this place. I think the Minister would be much better off addressing the merits of the argument.
—I think what Senator Collins said is quite correct: they do not agree with it—so that is it.
—Correct. We don't agree with it.

—Absolutely. It is not that it is fundamentally flawed at all. That is an excuse put forward and, indeed, as I have already indicated, in the classification it says what cannot be shown on television and anything stronger than AO is not permitted on television. So, in saying it is fundamentally flawed, Senator Collins is totally incorrect. I agree that he will not agree with it; he does not like it. But that is it. That is why he is not accepting it—not because it is fundamentally flawed. So, for heaven's sake, I ask him not to make his excuse that it is technically incorrect. It is not technically incorrect; it is technically correct.

PARA.TAB: I asked the Minister earlier and I ask him again: will he please tell me whether M is going to be totally reclassified; is it going to be a total reclassification? Will any of the present classification of M be in any part of MA; or is he suggesting that the whole of that M classification, before or after it is divided, is going to be reclassified totally? The question I want the Minister to answer is very clear to him. He would not answer it last night. He will not answer it today—or he has not answered it today. As an excuse for not answering it, he says that he does not want to talk for long and that he wants to get the legislation through et cetera. But this is fundamental to the Minister's proposal: will M be totally reclassified, before or after it is divided? Will any part of the present classification of M be included in the MA classification?

TALK.START.PARA: —This has certainly now reached the point of tedious repetition. Not only did I say that that matter would be addressed in what no doubt will be a long, if not substantive, debate probably next week—at least, I hope it is next week—but also the Government removed a piece of legislation from the cognate passage of these Bills this morning to allow that to happen. I also said this morning in debate, and I will say it again: in relation to the question Senator Walters has raised again, the whole question of the detail of the new classifications is being addressed now. The Chief Censor of Australia, Mr Dickie, is in my office as we speak. He arrived from Sydney early this morning and I have already had one discussion with him. Later today, we will also be meeting with Brian Johns, the Chairman of the ABA. We will come back into this Parliament with a completely detailed explanation as to what Senator Walters wants.

PARA.TAB: But I have developed—and I do not mind saying it in here; Senator Harradine has some concerns apparently about some other individuals in this office—a very high regard indeed for the level of advice provided by Mr Dickie during my time as a backbencher on the classifications committee. I think he does a commendable job in this important and very difficult position. I want the best possible advice that he can give me. I am not going to be foolish enough to make off the top of the head statements on my own in here this morning about whether classifications are going to be this or that under this proposal, because I want the highest level of expert advice from people who do this for their daily bread and are experts in it before we debate the matter in the Parliament.

I cannot be more explicit about that. I do not know how many more times I have to say it. The detail Senator Walters is seeking will be brought back into this Parliament as an amendment to the Bill that was removed from the package this morning. It is a matter for the conduct of this chamber to determine what is debated, but my desire would be to have this legislation back in here no later than next week. Senator Walters can then examine the detailed proposals the Government will be putting in respect of classifications after we have taken the expert advice that we are taking, and that process has already begun. I am not sure what else I can add to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. We all agree that there is widespread concern about the amount of violence and sexploit material on television. That has been expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and I give him credit for expressing that. He took the opportunity of addressing the Family Summit and made certain statements about this matter at that summit. It is clear from reading that address that he has gone further than the ABT was indicating. The ABT indicated that classification M should be split into two categories, one of M and the other MV—M Violent. As the Prime Minister said at the Family Summit, parents are also concerned about the level of sexploit and drug use material on certain television programs. He is proposing that the classification be split into M and MA. I am not sure what the `A' stands for, but I assume that MA is mature adults. In so saying, the Prime Minister also indicated that this provision would be mandatory, not just recommendatory.

PARA.TAB: He also indicated to the Family Summit that penalties should be imposed for allowing persons under the age of 15 to view that sort of material. That assumes that he is talking about material for cinema, not material for television. Last night the Minister indicated to me that it is not the intention of the Government to allow material that is currently not allowed on television to be screened, either at 9 o'clock, 10.30 or whatever. I understand that, but from reading the recommendations that came forward as a result of the discussions between the Prime Minister and the industry last night, which were presented to the Parliament last night in an amendment by Senator Collins to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, I am very concerned that those provisions are opening the way for worse material to be shown on television and for certain types of AO material to commence at 8.30 and the remainder at 9 p.m.
Paragraph 6 of Senator Collins's motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: the timeslots for telecast of film on free-to-air television will be 8.30 p.m. for M category product and 9 p.m. for MA category;

That is inconsistent with what the Prime Minister told the Family Summit. As I indicated, he told the Family Summit that MA would not be voluntary or recommendatory but mandatory and that there should be penalties for people allowing children under the age of 15 to view such material. Unless we are going to put policemen in every home, I do not think he means that that is for television. I think what he means is cinemas allowing the material to be shown. I accept what was said by the Prime Minister. The proof will be in the pudding, of course, when the legislation comes back.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters has asked a valid question. If this material is going to be so re-categorised, how much of it will go into R and how much will stay in M? These are critical questions that need to be considered, and that must be addressed. We have been given different views by the Film Censorship Board and the ABT in respect of this matter. I am not reflecting at all on personalities or particular individuals, whether it be Mr Dickie or Mr Haines. I am saying that they have given different statements on different occasions in respect of this matter. I am asking the Government to be careful and run a very fine toothcomb over the legislation. I will not take up the time of the Committee now showing what they said on one occasion and what they said on another occasion about AO and M classifications. Clearly, the issue is who interprets it. The Film Censorship Board—the Office of Film and Literature Classification, as it is wont to call itself—has a different, broader and more liberal interpretation than the ABT had, and I assume that that is where the problem lies.

These matters will be canvassed, but there is every reason for the Committee to support the motion moved by Senator Walters at this point in respect of AO programs not commencing before 9.30. That would be an indication to the House of Representatives of our great concern about the matter. After all, it is putting into legislative place the expressed views of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Harradine says is correct, and the Government will be looking very carefully at the difficulty. Consistent with what Senator Harradine has said, clauses 4 and 7 of the motion I moved last night specifically raised for that reason the probable requirement for the product to be modified for television. We do anticipate that there will have to be a change. What we are trying to do, and I think it is supportable, is to have a generally consistent classification. In other words, rather than have M, MA or whatever and then a completely separate description of AO, these classifications should be made broadly consistent. But we have anticipated the possibility that this will have to be further modified for television.

PARA.TAB: I will read into the Hansard some of the work that has already been done on this matter since last night. This is one of the options that is already being discussed: `That industry must develop and have registered a code of practice of ways of modifying M and MA for television and ways of providing consumer advice and of publicising the system'. I agree with Senator Harradine's statements; there may have to be this advice, and we have already noted it in terms of where we are proceeding with this. In terms of getting a consistent view between the various agencies, the very purpose for which we are meeting with the heads of those agencies today is to get a consistent view.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister mentioned in the media, I am not quite sure where, that because we had not covered the ABC and SBS we were not being consistent with what the Government was trying to do. He said that his transport and communications legislation would cover the ABC and SBS. I am delighted to hear that but, well before the Minister had decided to do this, we had amendments for the ABC and SBS in process. Indeed, I have a copy of them with me at the moment.

PARA.TAB: I believed that the amendment to the free-to-air broadcasting Bill for the commercial television stations would put enough pressure on the ABC and SBS to abide by the same standards but, if it did not, then we had the amendments ready to put through to make sure that they did abide by those standards. So let us lay to rest the furphy that we have not considered it. We considered it well before the Government said that it would bring the ABC and SBS into line. Indeed, the Minister did not mention that last night in this chamber.

Can the Minister tell me whether, when the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill is finally drafted—he said that he hoped it would be next week—the broadcasting Bill will be coming back to this chamber?

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that will be moved will be an amendment to that Bill—
—The broadcasting Bill?

—Yes, but within a miscellaneous provisions Bill. There is no need to bring the principal Act back into the chamber. It will be an amendment, as is normally done, to the principal Act in a miscellaneous provisions Bill.
—So what the Minister is saying is that there will be—

—The Minister had to seek advice on that, so he should not be quite so stupid about it. If the Government's amendments do not suit the Democrats, will my Bill be able to be implemented? Will the broadcasting Bill be brought back so that I can put forward my amendment again?
—Buggered if I know.
—The Minister says, `Buggered if I know'.
—It is up to the Senate.
—They are the words the Minister used; I did not use them.
—If he used those words, they were less than delicate.
—Senator Bourne is under the impression that it will come back. She said that she had been told by the Minister's office that it would come back. Now I ask the Minister, and he says he does not know.

—To put Senator Walters's mind at rest, when this comes back before us in the form of an omnibus Bill, which includes amendments to the Broadcasting Act, I assume it will have in it the classifications we were given last night in the second reading amendment. If they are inadequate as far as violence is concerned they can be amended; it will be a Bill which is amendable, as any other Bill is. If Senator Walters wants to put up amendments to the Transport and Communications Amendment Bill when it comes in next week that extend any classifications that change it in any way, we will be more than happy to look at those. We will be more than happy to consider them in the way we usually do in this chamber. I am really looking forward to doing it next week, and I am also looking forward to getting on with the rest of this Bill today.

—I am astonished that Senator Walters would even want to ask the question, after the years she has spent in this chamber. I said that I did not know for the simple reason that it is in the hands of the Senate what happens with this matter. If the Senate is not satisfied with what the Government brings back into the Senate next week, then the provisions will not pass. Whatever amendments to that legislation the Senate deems to be better than it will be passed.

—I think what Senator Walters is requesting, as I heard it—it was pretty clear to me—is whether it is competent for any member of the Senate to move an amendment to the Broadcasting Services Act when this Bill comes back before us next week or the week after. I notice that the Bill does refer to the Act—
—By way of an amendment to an omnibus Bill.
—By way of an amendment to an omnibus Bill. As I understand the position, it is competent for any member of the Senate so to move, but I would like that assurance.
—The answer to Senator Harradine's question is yes.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, after proposed subsection 93(6), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(6A) A subscription television broadcasting licence must not be allocated under this section if the Trade Practices Commission has reported, within 45 days after being requested for a report under section 97, that, in the opinion of the Trade Practices Commission, the allocation of the licence to the applicant would, if Part IV of the Trade Practices Act 1974 applied to the allocation of the licence, constitute a contravention of that Part of that Act.".

SPEECH.PARA: This first amendment relates to the obligations of, in the first instance, the ABA and, secondly, the Trade Practices Commission, and then at what ought to happen as a result. If one looks at the Bill, one finds that proposed section 93 allows the Minister to determine an allocation system for satellite licences allocated before 1 July 1997; in other words, the three licences the Bill deals with—A, B and C.

PARA.TAB: Before the Minister can do that, the ABA must request the Trade Practices Commission to provide a report under this section. The Trade Practices Commission would consider whether there had been a contravention of proposed section 50, which is to deal with monopolies, and whether or not there had been an authorisation granted; in other words, whether in its judgment a party ought to be exempted from the requirements of section 50. If that request is then made and the Trade Practices Commission provides an adverse report, there does not seem to be anything that would then require the Minister to take that into account. In other words, it is something that happens; he can take it or reject it, but otherwise ignore it.

It seems to us that that does not make a great deal of sense. If the Trade Practices Commission were of the view that there were no grounds for an exemption, that indeed there was evidence under part IV, which deals with mergers, monopolies and other forms of anti-competitive activity, particularly exclusive dealing, those views ought to be taken into account. Therefore it would not be proper for the Trade Practices Commission, having come to the view that a licensee for A or B, or the consortium that comprised the licensee, should be required to comply with the requirements of the Trade Practices Act, to be ignored. In the event that the TPC did not give a clean bill of health to the consortium arrangements—on the face of it the Government would not seem to be contemplating that it should, otherwise there would seem to be little point in requesting a report from the TPC—in the event of an adverse report being received, it would seem logical to have that taken fully into account.

Our amendment would mean that licences should not be granted where the Trade Practices Commission had declined to give a clean bill of health to the composition of the consortium. In those circumstances, it seems only reasonable that the Minister should follow through on his first requirement. Otherwise, all he is doing is saying, `We will require a report, but if the report is adverse we will ignore it'. That does not seem to us to make any sense.

I hope that the Government will see the logic of the argument. It is certainly not designed to frustrate the process. In no way would we anticipate that this could cause difficulties. If the Government were not minded to support this, presumably the Government would be saying that either it did not accept the bona fides of the TPC or that it ought to be up to it to override the recommendations. That does not seem to make a great deal of sense either.

Our amendment is simply a logical extension of the requirement for the TPC to tender a report and for that report to be fully taken into account. If it says that there are not problems in terms of mergers and monopolies or anti-competitive activity, then clearly there is no impediment to the granting of the licence. If, on the other hand, it takes the view that there is a problem, it seems utterly incongruous nonetheless then to ignore it and grant the licence notwithstanding. One might as well not have had the view of the TPC in the first place. I will certainly be interested in the Minister's explanation of why the Government has stopped halfway in that sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment simply because, in our view, it is unnecessary. The Broadcasting Services Act provides for a new and very innovative extension of the role of the Trade Practices Commission. However, in the Government's view the role of the TPC is rightly confined to that area because the legislation addresses competition policy concerns for satellite services by ruling out existing media players for the licences.

PARA.TAB: The Government has taken, if you like, pre-emptive action in respect of the legislation. We have ruled out existing media players from licence A and provided for the ABC to hold licence C, thus confining existing media players and telcos to licence B. The TPC has a very wide role under the pay TV regime. The initial allocation of licences A, B and C do not fall under the Trade Practices Act as the allocation is an act of the Crown. As I have just said, we have already taken pre-emptive action in ensuring that there will be very wide competition for these licences. But at the same time we have introduced this innovative new section that provides for an advisory role for the TPC in any case.

As I have said, we have already pre-empted, if you like, the TPC with this initial allocation. But outside those allocations, all actions under the regime and activities by those involved in pay TV, including these licensees, fall within the ambit of the Trade Practices Commission.

The allocation of licences A, B and C is an action of the Minister for Transport and Communications. It would be inappropriate for the actions of a Minister to be subject to examination or veto by the TPC. We have taken a policy decision that certain people will be excluded from licences in order to guarantee that there will be competition.

I might also say that we have provided an opportunity—and people should cast their eyes down the list of those who already hold licences—for people to broadcast with other technology in respect of pay TV. I know the Opposition supports this position. We are not precluding any other technology. So MDS—which already exists in this country and which uses equipment that is already manufactured in Australia—has an opportunity to broadcast pay TV.

There will be wide competition. The scenario painted that an opportunity might exist for somebody to get a stranglehold in terms of at least the opportunities to play in this market cannot be sustained. That is something with which Senator Alston, even though he criticises the extent to which the Government has gone, would agree. But outside those allocations, all actions under the regime and activities by those involved in pay television, including by these licensees, fall within the ambit of the TPC. As I have said before, the allocation of the original licences is an action by the Government.

The Trade Practices Commission will be concerned about market dominance. In a situation where three satellite licences are being issued in a new industry, it would be very surprising indeed if the Trade Practices Commission judged that the allocation of a licence to any party would lead to market dominance when the other two licences have to be issued to independent players—the Government has legislated for that—and when further licences using other technologies can also be issued at any time. I advise the Committee that not only are a number of those MDS licences already issued, but also applications have already been received from a wide range of interests for the unallocated licences in MDS. So strong interest is certainly being exhibited.

The allocation of those other licences not using a satellite and all satellite licences allocated after mid-1997 are made subject to Trade Practices Commission approval. The market dominance or significant lessening of competition test would apply from the outset in areas where there is no scarcity of the resource. All transfers of licences or acquisitions or mergers involving licence companies can come under the scrutiny of the TPC, and the market dominance test can be applied.

All actions by, and behaviour of, pay TV licensees are subject to the Trade Practices Act, including any effects on market dominance, anti-competitive behaviour or abuse of market power. The consumer protection parts of the TPA would also apply in full. For these reasons, Opposition amendments 1 and 3 are unnecessary and will not be supported by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. We appreciate the innovation that has been displayed by the Government—including reference to the Trade Practices Commission—in the original legislation. Indeed, we are very fond of innovation; at times we have been told that we are too fond of it. But we believe that this is a very good move and we would like to see it included in other legislation as well.

PARA.TAB: We cannot see a problem with the Opposition's amendment. The Minister said that he believes it is superfluous to the original legislation. We believe that it just tightens up the original legislation a little. We cannot see any problem with it. Therefore, we will be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I will cut through some of the verbiage of the Minister. The issue seems to boil down to this: it is conceded that it is an act of the Crown to grant licences—that is not an issue. But if one has a provision that requires the Trade Practices Commission in certain circumstances to express a view and it then reports that, in its judgment, there is a contravention of the Act, what is the consequence? Should the Minister simply ignore that view if it is adverse? Is that what the Minister is saying?
—No.
—Therefore, what harm is done in saying that the licence should not be granted if in fact the Trade Practices Commission recommends that there is a contravention?
—I carefully noted that my unnecessary verbiage took no more than two minutes. I was trying to—
—You could be superfluous in 30 seconds.

—Senator Alston could be a little more positive if he was not so unnecessarily provocative. If he were a little more positive we would save a lot of time in here by not exchanging insults. I certainly thought that the Opposition would have wanted to think twice about running an amendment like this in terms of the precedent that it might create.

PARA.TAB: I recall something that a certain right wing colleague of mine said years ago when the composition of the national executive of the Labor Party was 19. People were carrying on at some length about precedents being established. Senator Richardson commented across the table that the only precedent that ever really mattered on the national executive was a vote of 10 to 9. In the real world, when the composition of parliaments change, precedents simply gather the dust of history.

I would have thought that the Opposition would not have wanted to create a precedent like this. Despite asserting the right of the Crown—Senator Alston has referred to it—of setting up the regime we want, and we believe it is a highly competitive regime, the ABA can still seek an opinion from the Trade Practices Commission. The assertion Senator Alston has made about the non-compulsory nature of that is absolutely correct.

In terms of the harm done, the honest answer to that—that is why I only used the word `unnecessary' and no stronger word—is probably not much. This is not an amendment that the Government is going to die in a ditch over. The only concern that we had was that, by agreeing to it, we already, as I stated a few moments ago, believe that this is a highly competitive model. There are a whole range of licences, not just on the satellite but in other technology. We did not want to tie up the process—we are anxious to get this industry started—by unnecessarily bogging down the process in what could be quite lengthy Trade Practices Commission proceedings.

As to Senator Alston's question about what harm it does, that is the sole area where the Government thought that the Opposition's amendment was unnecessary. Having said that, we do not disagree with the philosophy behind the purview of the TPC. In fact, it has been comprehensively provided for under our model. We were simply opposing the amendment on the grounds that, firstly, we thought it was unnecessary and, secondly, we did not want the process bogged down in TPC procedures. But if that is the will of the Committee, so be it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) for clarifying the weight that we ought to be attaching to the amendment. I am happy to proceed on that basis. I simply wanted to follow through the logic of the Government's position. I can understand the Minister saying, `We are a sovereign Government and we can get advice if we want it at our discretion. If we want to do things, despite advice, that is a matter for us, so you can vote us out at the next election'. But why go to the trouble of requiring the TPC to consider whether there might have been contraventions, then have it reported to the Government that there are and nonetheless say, `Too bad, we'll ignore it'? It seems to me illogical that the Government would go halfway and then thumb its nose at a respected body. Either it does not bother consulting it at all, or if it does it ought to take its advice into account. There is no problem if its advice is, `No contravention; will you go ahead'. But the logic of the Government's position is that if very serious contraventions are reported—that composition of the licensee is fundamentally flawed and highly anti-competitive—it is still in a position to blithely ignore that report.

—We would not be in that position. We have simply provided for an advisory capacity for the Trade Practices Commission that formerly did not exist. This is not a matter of great moment between the Government and the Opposition. I will give a comparison. I guess it is the same kind of provision in terms of advisory opinions as the question of the High Court, for example, providing advisory opinions. The reason we did not extend it any further is that, in the real world, if the Trade Practices Commission brought down an adverse report it is highly unlikely that the licence would be issued.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Alston's) agreed to:
Clause 3, page 4, line 13, insert "93 or" before "96".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 3, page 3, after proposed paragraph 94(4)(b), insert:

SPEECH.PARA: "; and (c) have regard to any relevant international standard.".

Amendment No. 2 simply requires that before the Minister declares a standard, if there has been a failure between the licensees to agree about the appropriate digital transmission system, not only should the Minister consult with the licensees and the operator of the satellite, Optus, but also should have regard to any relevant international standard. That is self-explanatory.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, we ought to be guided by the wisdom of others who have been down this track long ago. We have said many times that we have been dragging the chain on pay television for at least a dozen years. There is quite an accumulated body of expertise out there that ought to be helpful to us in considering the matter. Therefore, the Minister ought to have regard to it as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government intended to take this matter into consideration in any case. Therefore, we have absolutely no objection to the amendment and we will support it.

—The Democrats also will support the amendment, on the same basis. While we are on 94(4)(b), I would like an assurance from the Minister that the Government will also consult with licensee C—that is, the ABC, assuming the ABC is involved in this in the end—before it takes into account what the standard for Australia will be.

—No, we will not be doing that. We do not believe there is a role for the ABC becoming involved in that matter. We already know that the ABC's two channels—the ABC never asserted anything other than this—would not be viable as a stand-alone. It will have to combine with someone else, as its own original galaxy model suggested it would. We have already agreed to consult with the other licensees. With international standards, the major providers of the service should have the role of determining what standard is to be set. That is what the Government will be doing. There is an extremely wide and comprehensive role now provided for the ABC, as Senator Bourne knows, that was not there before.

—I believe it is only a consultation. I believe the ABC does have a lot to offer in this. Nobody is saying that the ABC should decide what the standards should be, but merely that the ABC should be consulted as one of the providers of the service. I still believe that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 3, page 6, lines 25 to 39, omit proposed section 101.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 4 seeks to delete the special conditions relating to advertising. Proposed section 101 provides that there shall not be advertisements or sponsorship announcements prior to 1 July 1997. We simply take the view that it ought to be a matter of discretion. The experience in the United States, which is the best guide, is that only about 5 per cent of revenue comes from these sources. It is clearly a classic case of being sensitive to the market. If we have too much promotion, clearly the viewers will vote with their feet. They have a multitude of choices these days. In practice, the suppliers are very sensitive to the need not to have excessive advertising.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances, we do not see why there should be artificial constraints placed on the basis that there shall not be any advertisements prior to 1997. Presumably, they shall be allowed after that date. The Government would argue that we need some sort of start-up arrangements. It is a matter for those that we seek to protect to look after themselves. If they judge that they should not run advertising, they will not do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's cooperation, regrettably, will not be extended to this amendment. We are opposing it. Consumers are heartily sick of advertisements on television. I would be very surprised if people would pay a weekly subscription for services and be willing to watch ads in the time that they have paid for.

PARA.TAB: The ban protects consumers. It will give current broadcasters a short period to structurally adjust to the new services without any major impact on their revenue. That is a sensitive matter because, as I said in the second reading debate last night, it is a matter of fact that the broadcasters, for whatever reason—I certainly would have no difficulty in saying that much of it has been through their own fault—are not in a robust state of health currently. We believe they do need time to structurally adjust without any major impact on their revenue base. We will encourage the new services to work at being different from commercial television.

As the Opposition knows, and as Senator Alston has just quoted, overseas experience has shown that people will not pay to watch ads, and people interested in playing in this industry will not want to show ads in the early years when the subscriber numbers are low and they are building up their base. So they do not see this a being a major impost on them at all. This amendment is, therefore, in the Government's view, unnecessary, and is opposed by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will also be opposing this for the same reason that the Minister has just given. We do not believe that advertisers and free to air channels at the moment are particularly sensitive to the wishes of their viewers. There is far too much advertising on free to air television as it stands, and we do not believe that allowing advertising on pay TV would, in any way, benefit consumers, who are already paying for the service just to get it without the ads. We see the period until 1 July 1997 as being quite short. We cannot see that pay TV will be up and running much before that. I would like to see that time extended and, if it comes to the point that pay TV is not even up and running before that, I would like to see this ban go on. We certainly will not be supporting any provision which would take the ban out of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, proposed subsection 94(1), line 35, after "licensee B", add "in consultation with Optus and Austel,".
2.Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 94(3), line 2, after "a standard chosen by the Minister", insert "in consultation with Optus and Austel".
These amendments require the two licensees to consult with Optus and Austel in agreeing to the standard before the full digital transmission system is agreed on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing the amendments because they are unnecessary. Before a digital satellite transmission standard is made by me, I am required by sections 94(1) and 94(4) of the Act to consult with Optus in relation to the efficient use of the satellite. To the extent, therefore, that Austel has an interest in the outcome of this, in fact, it would be consulted. I just stress again that we are compelled to do, by the principal Act, what Senator Bourne's amendments want us to do. We have no objection to what she wants us to do and we will be doing it, but the amendments are unnecessary because it is contained in a provision of the Act.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 96(1), omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:

TAB.TAB: "96.(1) Subject to subsection (1A), the ABA may allocate to a person, on application in writing by the person, a subscription television broadcasting licence other than a licence referred to in section 93.
(1A) Any allocation of a licence by the ABA in accordance with subsection (1) must comply with the ownership and cross-media rules set out in Division 3 of this Act.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would require non-satellite services, which the Government has included in pay TV services—so it is not just satellite now, it would include cable, MDS and any other system which is invented in the meanwhile which can deliver pay TV to Australian homes—to be subject to the same ownership and cross-media rules as the satellite services are.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of the smooth running of the proceedings of the Committee, can I say, more in sorrow than in anger, that the Government will be opposing all of the Democrat amendments, Nos 1 to 13. In a general sense, we believe that they go overboard in imposing unnecessary restrictions on pay television that would send this new industry broke very quickly. This is one of those provisions.

PARA.TAB: These proposals affect cross-media rules and we believe that the application of cross-media rules to MDS and cable just does not make sense. There will be at least 19 MDS channels available in every city where MDS will be available. Currently there are 19 channels. On cable, there will be up to 150 channels available. The Government's wider commercial law will apply to all of these. We are not talking about a scarce product at all in respect of these other technologies and it simply makes no sense at all, where the availability of the resource is so wide, to apply cross-media restrictions to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of expediting the process, I also indicate, as I have privately to Senator Bourne, that we will not be supporting any of the amendments for substantially the reasons outlined by the Minister.

—The Minister has told us that there could be up to a large number of cable and MDS services available and, yes, that is indeed true. There could as well be very few which are given to the public. On that basis, and indeed, on the absolute basis of Australia being owned by Australians—of there being little foreign ownership—and on the basis of cross-media rules being very important, we would still recommend this amendment to the Committee.

—As a result of Senator Alston's amendment which has just been carried by the Committee and supported by the Democrats, licences cannot be issued now until the Trade Practices Commission agrees. We believe that the provisions of the Trade Practices Act more than sufficiently cover the problem of anyone getting a dominance. I would point out again that the potential for available channels—not that I think, myself, that the product will be available to fill them all up—on optical fibre, trials of which are about to commence in Wollongong and Sydney, is almost limitless.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the wish of the Senate to get through this quickly and I appreciate the Government and the Opposition indicating that they are not going to vote for anything I am putting up, but I am still going to move our fourth amendment separately. I think this is vitally important and I hope they change their minds in the next two minutes.

PARA.TAB: This amendment raises the requirement for new Australian content on satellite drama services—and that would include cable and MDS, I believe—from 10 per cent to 20 per cent of program expenditure. If honourable senators recall, the Senate Committee looking into pay TV received evidence from a great number of people, none of whom said that 10 per cent was adequate, most of whom wanted well over 15 per cent and nobody said they would go broke if they had to put in 15 or 20 per cent. Twenty per cent, we think, is a reasonable level to start off with and we would like to see it go higher. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 3, page 7, proposed section 102, line 5, omit "10%", substitute "20%".

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be opposing this amendment. As far as the Government is concerned, 10 per cent expenditure on Australian drama is more than enough in the early years of the development of this industry. Too high a levy on local content, in fact, sent Canada's pay TV broke in the 1980s. Ten per cent balances the commercial reality of pay television with the desire to foster new Australian production and inject what will be welcome new funds from pay TV, should it be successful, into Australian production.

PARA.TAB: The Act also allows a review of Australian content in 1997 when we will know what the industry can afford. The viability of the service will be tenuous and no-one is avoiding the fact that this is a high risk new industry. It will be tenuous because of its high cost and low subscriber base in its early years. It has to be given a little time to sustain itself and we believe that 10 per cent is a realistic limit to set.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary to say a few words because Senator Bourne, I think, was hoping that we might be persuaded on this clause. If there is one clause that I would have thought we were least likely to be persuaded on, it is this.
—Why?

—Not only is local content a very sensitive issue, but it is also a critical issue in terms of the survivability of those suppliers and others who come into the business. The last thing I think the Democrats want to do is impose unnecessary restrictions on those people's prospects for viability. I am more than content to set a minimum of 10 per cent, but then leave it to the viewers. In my experience, SBS provides a great range of quality that demonstrates that you do not have to have the local product to attract viewers. But if viewers have a different attitude, that will be very quickly reflected in their viewing patterns. Indeed, the pay television providers will respond accordingly.

PARA.TAB: I do not see why we ought to be providing them with excess baggage at the very time when we are not even sure that they will be able to get off the ground. One of the concerns that one would have generally is that the Government's model is such that we may not even find licence A being viable. With all the uncertainties that lie ahead, the last thing we ought to be doing is erring on the side of weighing them down with unnecessary restrictions when it is ultimately the viewers who will be making the final judgment. Rather than providing endless monopoly protection, as the Democrats seem to be so keen on doing in other areas, I would have thought this was a classic case where Senator Bourne and I and the rest of Australia ought to be able to make up our minds and vote with our feet if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the Minister and Senator Alston are saying. I am very disappointed by it, but I am encouraged that they are saying that this is the way it should start off. So they will obviously be looking at my next amendment, which they will probably agree to now, after what they have said.
