PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bourne's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the Prime Minister's refusal yesterday to refute the suggestion that unemployment will exceed one million, what information does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce have on expected job losses within industries under his portfolio responsibility over the next 12 months? In which sectors will these job losses occur?

—I will give an off-the-cuff answer to that off-the-cuff question. It seems that the largest areas of likely job loss which have been made public are in the banking sector—not under my jurisdiction—particularly two banks which have announced their intention to reduce their staff considerably. There will certainly be some volatility in the telecommunications area. I am unable to make any comment about that because, with the arrival of Optus and the generation of a whole lot of new activity in the telecommunications business, both from Telecom and Optus, it is very difficult to say what the employment situation there will be. It will probably mean a reshuffling of jobs rather than net job losses.

PARA.TAB: There are various other sectors in which one may expect some job loss. The question of job losses in industries specifically covered by my portfolio will be very small. In fact, I expect some significant growth in jobs in a wide range of small to medium size firms as we come out of the recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which sectors?

—Senator Short asks in which sectors. Let me make some generic comment about it. The high growth export sectors—and there are high growth export sectors—obviously will be the ones which will benefit first. A recent survey by the business school at Monash University of some 400 firms shows an increase in profitability over the past year, an increase in sales, little increase in employment, but an anticipated increase in employment later this year.
—Later this year? There are only a couple of weeks to go till the end of this year!

—The survey was done in the middle of the year. So far as that sector is concerned, similarly, work done by McKinsey on high growth export firms indicates the same sort of pattern. I do not see any dramatic changes in the big employing industries. It was anticipated that there would be some decline in textile, clothing and footwear. That has slowed considerably in the past couple of months.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's refusal to provide any real hope for growth and job creation, particularly in those industries for which he has responsibility, I further ask: when will the Government accept that its economic policies have failed and have produced hardship and falling living standards for virtually all Australians? When will the Government adopt policies to create economic growth and jobs such as by abolishing the $5.8 billion of payroll tax; abolishing the $9.4 billion of wholesale sales tax; abolishing the $6.6 billion tax on petrol; reducing taxes on exports by $1.7 billion; and reducing personal income tax by one third, as the coalition has committed to do in its Fightback policies to rebuild Australia?
—Senator Short's leader said on Monday that Fightback was appealing to the Australian people. On Tuesday he announced a Sky Channel program to try to sell it to people in pubs, for goodness sake!

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short's question recycles the old stuff. As at the end of September, 75 per cent of independent economists in Australia took the view that people would be worse off in employment under Fightback than they would under the present Government policies. I repeat that 75 per cent of independent economists took the view that people would be worse off under the Opposition's programs than they are under ours.

—Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce provide the Senate with the latest figures on the level of automotive exports from Australia and their importance to the future of the car industry? What role is South Australia playing in the expansion of automotive exports?

—I thank Senator Foreman for his question. Senator Foreman, of course, is a South Australian senator with a great interest in the automotive industry—an interest which most South Australian politicians on both sides of the House ought to have. Some years ago I made a prediction, somewhat courageously, that automotive exports out of Australia would reach $1.2 billion by 1992. The latest figures suggest that the automotive industry will comfortably reach that target. From January to August 1992, exports of automotive components and vehicles totalled $784m, which works out to about $1.2 billion on an annual basis.

PARA.TAB: It is no secret that exports to the United States of the Ford Capri have fallen below expectations in 1992 because of the recession in the US economy, but exports of automotive components have made up for this. Component exports were worth $736m in 1991. From January to August 1992, they reached $519m. Some manufacturers say that recent movements in the exchange rate will help them, of course, to do even better than that.

Last week I visited car industry companies in South Australia where the industry is making a significant contribution to growth in exports. I probably upset some Federal MPs by faxing them a list of questions on the car industry and its importance to South Australia. Many of them are worried about Dr Hewson's zero tariff proposal for the industry. But apart from the occasional break-out by Steele Hall, Dr Hewson and Ian McLachlan are sticking to their line, publicly at least.

The question was directed to the South Australian industry particularly. Mitsubishi in Adelaide has begun exporting Magna wagons to the United States and also plans to export to Europe. The Government's export facilitation scheme underpins the Magna wagon export program—a scheme, by the way, which shadow Minister McLachlan endorsed by implication at the time it was announced in 1991. Export facilitation, of course, is linked to the level of tariffs. Zero tariffs mean zero export facilitation. Zero tariffs are an even bigger threat than that. The end result of the McLachlan car industry policy would be no exports, no industry and no jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister say how important the growth in automotive exports has been in the overall increase in manufactured exports in Australia?
—Can't you do better than that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Senator Macdonald is upset by these figures. But I make the point that automotive exports have grown, as I said, to $1.2 billion. This is only one of a number of sectors of manufacturing industries which have significantly increased exports.

PARA.TAB: An article in the Reserve Bank's November Bulletin, just published, looks at manufactured exports, particularly to Asia. The Opposition has consistently said that our manufactured exports to Asia are only growing because of economic growth in the region, but the Reserve Bank document explodes this myth. The article says Australia has increased its market share in manufactured exports to Asia. The article states:

ANSWER.PARA: While some special factors have helped, the growth seems to be too consistent and too widespread across destinations and sectors to be attributable to a couple of fast growing markets, some assisted exports or temporary exports of cyclical factors.
The Reserve Bank Bulletin also states:
The evidence suggests manufactured exports have been increasing as a result of changes in competitiveness and attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows the question by Senator Short concerning the ever growing unemployment under Labor policies. I refer to Ross Gittins's piece in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald in which he said that Labor does not deserve to be re-elected, has nothing positive to offer and that, since February, Paul Keating has done `nothing but hope like hell the economy would recover in time for the election', has done nothing but focus on ensuring the Liberals lose the election, and `as to what he'd do if he wins the election, his mind's a blank'. I ask the Minister: why should the Australian people vote for a Prime Minister who is solely occupied with denigrating the Leader of the Opposition and the coalition's policies rather than developing some policies of his own?

—It is all very well to quote Ross Gittins; let me quote the right honourable member for New England, Mr Ian Sinclair, who said, `We, the Opposition, have become the issue in the election'. Why has the Opposition become the issue?

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is an appalling example of the complete misuse of Question Time. The Minister was asked a simple question about the Government's total lack of policies—blank looks on all their faces—and all we get is another cheap serve about the Opposition. If Question Time is to mean anything, you ought to direct the Minister to reply to the question, if he is capable of doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order, just to say that it was obvious that the question was outrageously out of order, but it was so easy to answer we all wanted to give the Minister a chance to do it. It is not our fault if Senator Alston has a glass jaw. The question was much more out of order than the answer.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you put the question very simply: why should the people of Australia elect Mr Keating rather than John Hewson? The answer is because he is much brighter. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister would appear to be reflecting his Prime Minister in offering nothing positive at all. The question is a serious one in the light of a million people unemployed in this country. When are Australian people going to see some policies from the Labor Party? Or is it that Labor is simply offering them more of the same: more of the same disappointment; more of the same misery; and ever higher unemployment, as the Prime Minister seemed to acknowledge yesterday.

—The Prime Minister did not acknowledge that yesterday. He did not acknowledge that for a moment. Senator Hill has the hide to ask this question when all the Opposition is about as a political party is reshuffling some tax expenditures for the benefit of the rich, who will be the considerable beneficiaries of Fightback, and there are no other policy prescriptions that have any particular relevance to the contemporary situation which this economy currently requires.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is the Minister aware of recent studies confirming the improved performance of Australian ports to international levels and the impact of this on port users? What are the implications of these reports for the Australian Government's waterfront reform policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of two recent reports on the performance of the Australian wharves. The first report is from the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority and the other is from the Prices Surveillance Authority. They show that Australian ports are comparable with best international practice and performance levels and they verify that direct and indirect benefits are going to users. Let me give the examples that justify the comments that I have just made.

PARA.TAB: The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority's performance indicators to the end of the September period record the continuing upward trend in stevedoring efficiency compared with 1989, when our reform program began. The stevedoring work force is now reduced by 57 per cent. Productivity measured by the number of containers handled per employee shift is now 127 per cent higher. Average crane rates in major ports are now over 20 containers per hour. More efficient terminals regularly achieve rates of 22 containers per hour and up to 30.5 containers per hour under optimum shipping and stowage conditions.

Some commentators suggest that rates will not be sustained with higher cargo throughput from the economic upturn. In fact, WIRA's report finds that container throughput increased during this period and is now close to the peak levels of 1989-90, when serious stevedoring delays were experienced, with more than double the current work force. As I said, we are achieving world standard. In the Far Eastern trade, Australia outperforms major ports in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Korea and the Philippines, with only Japan's Yokohama achieving better crane rates than our major ports. Our best rates of more than 30 containers per hour are on a par with US East Coast rates. These provide the target for our steadily improving performance levels. This has been done without any marked industrial disputation.

The Prices Surveillance Authority report concludes that since 1985 the price of container services fell in real terms by 59 per cent. The Authority finds a marked break after 1990, when previously charges were static and costs were increasing. Since 1990, waterfront reform has reduced both costs and charges to pre-1985 levels. In the two years from 1990, when our reforms were being implemented, container charges declined by 15 per cent in actual terms. The Prices Surveillance Authority finds scope for further reductions as the one-off redundancy and training costs associated with the reform program are realised.

These are significant changes. It behoves Australians to let everyone know about them. The fact that our ports are efficient means that we are in a better position to realise gains in international trade. Australia should assert that overseas because that is a significant achievement of micro-economic reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to yesterday's statement by the Prime Minister conceding that the number of unemployed could exceed the one million mark and ask the Minister: does he agree that it is now urgent to stimulate industrial activity? In particular, will the Government now reconsider its policy on dismantling tariffs and quotas at the current rate, as this will destroy our industries before they can be boosted—a policy which is almost identical to the scorched earth policy of the coalition parties?

—I do not wish to be personal, but the last part of the honourable senator's question contains a vile allegation—that our policies are similar to those of the Opposition. The honourable senator ties the question of tariff reductions and restructuring of industries to the current unemployment figure. Let me remind the honourable senator of one thing. The unemployment rate in this country is 11.3 per cent. When this Government came to office, the unemployment rate was 10.3 per cent, with very high tariffs. One of the highest tariff governments in the history of this country was the Fraser Government.

PARA.TAB: Those born-again wimps over there, who now say that they are going to lower tariffs, in the period of the Fraser Government allowed tariffs and quotas to become very high and left us with a legacy of 10.3 per cent unemployment. I make the point which I have made to Senator Spindler on a number of occasions in private as well as publicly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis over there was up to his ears in the Fraser Government; he knows all about it. As Senator Spindler knows, we have had a severe recession, which is the predominant cause of unemployment, just as it is in Canada, with 11.3 per cent unemployment. In the United Kingdom unemployment is 10.2 per cent and rising. It is 10 per cent in New Zealand and Italy, 18 per cent in Ireland, 10 per cent in France, 13 per cent in Finland, and so on. That is because of macro-economic factors affecting the world economy and the downturn in the business cycle, which is worldwide.

PARA.TAB: We will not be dismantling the program of reductions in tariff assistance which has been announced. Honourable senators can contrast that with the policy of the Opposition, which believes in zero tariffs—a mindless academic calculation of the appropriate industry assistance regime without any reference to industry and its problems. That is what people will get from the Opposition. Under us they will get a slow and steady reduction in tariffs, but nonetheless over the period of this Government the biggest tariff reduction in the history of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I venture to say that the Minister's answer would have been a little different if he had come with me on my trip to Victorian regional centres and had listened to the people who are suffering.
—Order! Ask the supplementary, Senator Spindler.

—Is the Minister prepared to take some alternative measures, such as toughening the anti-dumping laws, including a reversal of onus of proof, and providing tax concessions for exports and better access to working capital to enable our industries to survive, even if he is trying to destroy them with tariff cuts?

—Let me say at the beginning that I do not wish to accompany Senator Spindler on a tour of regional Victoria. I recently made one myself. I am entitled to choose my own company, and it will not be Senator Spindler whom I choose if I go again. I have recently been to all those places that the honourable senator mentioned and I know exactly what is happening. If he goes there and tries with his Democrat hand to pull people's legs about these issues and pretend that if we had the Democrat policy of high tariffs they would be any better off, I am sorry but he is misleading them; he is being dishonest with them. He knows full well the reasons. Some of those industries were decentralised by Liberal governments in Victoria and they were uncompetitive from the start. He will understand their problems.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the answer to a question on notice on 11 November 1992 concerning the current shipment of plutonium to Japan from Europe and I ask: can the Minister now confirm that the ship will pass through the Tasman Sea between Australia and New Zealand? What assurance can the Minister give to the Australian public that Japan is not going to stockpile this or further shipments of plutonium? Is it not true that Australia's position on this issue is based on reports presented by the Japanese Government? Can the Minister explain the difference in viewpoint between the Australian Government and William Walker and Frances Berkhout in their article in the October edition of Arms Control Today in which they say that Japan will end up with a stockpile of plutonium?

—As I said in my answer to the question on notice to which Senator Chamarette refers, the Government does not know the route of the shipment. We do not expect the Japanese Government to depart from its clearly stated intention for security reasons not to tell any country what the route will be. I have, of course, seen media reports of statements from Greenpeace that the ship is rounding the Cape of Good Hope and speculation that it will proceed through the Tasman Sea. I have no independent confirmation of those reports and I certainly cannot confirm any such speculation about the route.

PARA.TAB: As to the second question relating to stockpiling, as I have also previously made clear, the Government would not under any circumstances support the stockpiling of plutonium by Japan or any other non-nuclear weapons state. We will keep on making that point. We do accept Japan's clear statements that as a fundamental principle it will not possess any plutonium in excess of the amount required for its present and planned nuclear power program. The plutonium to be shipped from Europe will be used on an ongoing basis in Japan's nuclear fuel recycling program. We will certainly continue to monitor that situation.

As to the third part of the question, relying on Japanese statements, we are not relying solely on Japanese reports. We have conducted our own intensive examination of all aspects of the shipments to ensure that any implications for Australia might be fully considered. We have certainly discussed the shipments with Japan. We have considered the information provided on the physical protection arrangements for the shipments. We have also discussed the shipments with the European Atomic Energy Community—Euratom—and the United States which has an agreement with Japan on physical protection and safety arrangements. Government agencies, including ANSTO, have carefully examined the arrangements. On the basis of all these exchanges and quite careful assessment of the information available, we have satisfied ourselves that the physical protection and safety arrangements for the shipments do meet or, indeed, exceed international standards for the transport of plutonium.

As to the final question on the conclusions about stockpiling reached in the article to which the honourable senator has referred, there are two points I would make. The first one is to repeat the point I made earlier that we do accept Japan's clear statement that as a fundamental principle it will not possess plutonium in excess of the amount required for its power program. Secondly, our assessment is that there is sufficient flexibility in Japan's planned program for plutonium utilisation on both the supply and the demand sides to avoid the accumulation of a plutonium stockpile.

The Government will continue to take the closest possible interest in all aspects of this issue—in particular, on the safety and security of the shipment. I will keep the Senate advised if there is any change to the position as I have described it, both in this answer and in the very detailed answer I gave to Senator Reynolds on notice the other day.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I note that the Prime Minister has now conceded that the number of people unemployed could exceed one million. Despite that, a national day of protest is being planned by the union movement for 30 November. Will the Minister and/or the Prime Minister call upon the ACTU to abandon this proposed union action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —One ought to correct the record: the Prime Minister did not concede one million. I saw his answer; that is not an accurate report of what he said. Turning to the question of industrial action in Victoria, I have said on many occasions in this place that the Kennett Government should create the right situation for industrial harmony in Victoria. It should back off from its pernicious legislation and have serious discussions about bringing industrial peace to that State. What is also true—and I have said this on many occasions here—is that it is quite clear that the Kennett Government lied to the electorate of Victoria when it said before the election that not one Victorian would lose a single cent—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have previously ruled in respect of the matter of the Kennett Government being described as lying. I ask that Senator Cook be asked to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr President. The Liberal Government in Victoria lied to the electorate before the election saying that no-one would be one cent worse off and, of course, after the election it reversed itself within days. We in Australia have generated an enviable reputation for industrial harmony. I have reported in this Senate many times the ongoing decline—

—Mr President, on a point of order: I raise the issue of relevance. The question was very clear: will the Government ask the ACTU and John Halfpenny to call off the strike? If the Minister is not prepared to answer that question, he should sit down.

—Mr President, on the point of order: all we have heard from Senator Kemp in this case is a ruling and not a point of order. It is some time before he will ever be President in here and he should not be allowed to get away with it.
—Order! There was no point of order. The Minister was asked a question dealing with unemployment, industrial relations and a national day of protest. I believe at this stage he is answering it.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was saying that the ABS statistics on industrial disputation in Australia are off the bottom of the graph. We are going through a 30-year period of low industrial disputation. It has been a declining trend since we came to government. It is a feature of Labor governments: we manage industrial relations better. The areas on the graph that show upward increases are, of course, in New South Wales and now in Victoria as a direct response to provocative actions taken by conservative governments. We certainly do know that this is all a foretaste of what would occur should those in the Opposition ever grace the treasury bench in this place and apply exactly the same industrial relations policy as that of the Kennett Government.

PARA.TAB: The matter of industrial action in Victoria seems to me to be something which brings no joy at all. It brings Australia's record, to which I have just referred, into some question. But, in looking at what is the cause of industrial action and going to the heart of the matter, it has to be said that the Kennett Government in Victoria has to wear the responsibility fully and utterly. If it were to conduct itself as a humane Government working with people and not against them, trying to generate productivity—not picking on nurses, teachers, transport people and anyone who works weekend penalty shift rates and wanting to cut their salaries—and if it were to work cooperatively with people, not on the confrontationist model but on the cooperative model, in order to generate change, change would occur harmoniously. I think it is a matter of great regret that both the oafish and arrogant attitudes of the Victorian Government have provoked considerable industrial action in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that welter of words that we had from Senator Cook in answer to a simple question, will he now say whether he or the Prime Minister or the Government will or will not support the ACTU action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered this question by saying that it is a matter for Victorians to decide—and in a State such as Victoria where industrial action is made a criminal offence leading to fines and imprisonment it is understandable that people will take industrial action to protect their democratic rights. The solution to this lies with Jeff Kennett. If he wants to create a basis for industrial peace, he can.

PARA.TAB: But let me not conclude my answer with the Opposition appearing to have the moral high ground. This is the Party which wants to kick unemployed Australians off the dole after nine months. That is what it wants to do. That is a mark of its compassion. This is the Party which wants to remove the labour market support programs that, according to independent assessment, give Australians a better chance of finding work. Those in the Opposition have no compassion, no policy and no guts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and refers to relief operations in Africa. What is the Australian Government doing to improve security and the pace of delivery of relief operations in Somalia? What aid has the Government given to the relief operations in that country? What action can be taken to protect Australians in Somalia following attacks on aid workers there?

—Australia has fully supported the earliest possible commitment of the planned 4,200 UN security personnel to the UNISOM operation in Somalia to ensure the security of the international relief operation there. We are going to contribute a 30-member movement control unit to UNISOM; an advance party has already been deployed and the remainder hopefully will be there quite soon. The MCU is intended to coordinate and control the deployment of stores and personnel involved in the UNISOM operation.

PARA.TAB: We certainly share the concerns which have been expressed in recent times about the effect of the security situation in Somalia on the distribution of relief. I am aware of the proposals by the aid organisation, Care International, for a more active role for the UN in Somalia. I have certainly got some sympathy for the position that is being articulated by that body, but it is of course a matter for the UN Security Council to consider any change to the UN approach in Somalia.

The most I can say is that we are continuing to do what we can, including, through a number of personal conversations that I have had with other Foreign Ministers, to encourage the earliest possible full and flexible deployment of the existing approved numbers. We are monitoring the effectiveness of that deployment on the ground, especially the need for possible additional UN forces or for a change in their current mandated role. We are in dialogue, as are a number of other countries, with the UN headquarters on this matter.

The primary need is for some kind of political settlement or some approach which can involve not just the relief of the humanitarian situation but also peace-keeping and political negotiation at the same time. None of these things can be delivered in isolation. The task for the UN, which it still has not succeeded in so far, is to devote the kind of resources that will achieve this coordinated response and one that will produce a durable solution. I suppose one ray of hope in this respect is the UN-sponsored conference on the mechanisms of aid delivery that is now to take place in Addis Ababa on 3 and 4 December and is to be attended by the Somali factions. We will be represented at that conference. We hope very much that something positive emerges from it.

In terms of aid delivery, we have committed, with our latest allocation of $2m in September, a total of $8.5m to the Somalian situation so far this year. We hope the situation will improve to the point that we will not need to make a further contribution, but we cannot guarantee that at this stage. We will do the best we can to help further financially, as well as in the other ways I have mentioned, if that becomes necessary.

As to the safety of Australians in Somalia, that will depend basically on the resolution of these larger questions, to which I have already referred. Our High Commission in Nairobi is in regular contact with Australian aid workers in the country, monitoring the situation as best it can to work out how to assist them. We have urged all Australian citizens who travel to Somalia to register with our High Commission so that we know where they are. We are also in close and continuing contact with the UN and all other agencies on the ground to respond to any particular situation which could put Australian workers specifically at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Brazil, led by Mr Gastone Righi. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia is both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the Minister that in July this year the Liberal and National parties announced a detailed strategy for growth and jobs which supplemented the comprehensive Fightback policy program earlier released. I ask: when is the Government going to release its policies on employment, particularly now that One Nation has failed? Is it not a fact that, as the Sydney Morning Herald reported on 13 November, all that the Labor secretariat has done is `staple together about 10 pages of factional wish-lists and leftovers from the 1980s and call it a draft fifth-term agenda'? After 10 years in office, with a record one million unemployed and no policies other than more of the same, why should the Australian people not now throw Labor out of office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Opposition is starting to get a little bit smart. The Opposition has made itself the centrepiece of politics in this country with its Fightback proposals. Ian Sinclair makes the complaint: `We are the issue'. Look at what Senator Hill said about it on 22 August 1991:

ANSWER.PARA: Australians will be prepared to accept our challenge. They are indicating it in the polls.

What do Australians say about the Opposition's challenge now? After the Opposition announced Fightback and tried to sell it for a year, after it announced its jobs program in the middle of this year, 75 per cent of independent economists in Australia have said that people will be worse off for jobs under the Opposition's policies than under ours.

PARA.TAB: What is the Opposition offering the Australian people? It is offering them a $7 billion cut in the Budget. It is offering them the abolition of tariffs. It is offering them no unemployment benefits after nine months. It is offering them the wrecking of industrial peace, as we have seen in Victoria. It is offering to disrupt the economy with a 15 per cent GST. The goodies in the Opposition's package—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question was: is Labor going to offer more than the misery it has offered over the last 10 years, with one million Australians out of work? Is it going to offer anything new at all?

—As I said, Senator Hill is getting quite smart about this issue, trying to direct it away from the failures of the Opposition. Senator Hill in his original question referred to One Nation having failed. One Nation offers a collection, as the Budget did, of stimulatory policies, which have been opposed by the Leader of the Opposition at every turn, at every opportunity. Yesterday he said that stimulatory policies did not work. Senator Hill says that we have failed because we have the same level of unemployment as every other major economy in the Western world. Those opposite used to come in here and advocate Margaret Thatcher's view of the world. Look at how those policies have failed.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services.
—Can you read his writing?

—I did not hear that, Senator Macdonald. I ask: has the Minister's attention been drawn to complaints from Australian suppliers that they have been unfairly treated in their business dealings with the Department of Administrative Services? What steps has the Minister taken to guarantee the rights of potential suppliers?
—Thank you, Mr President.
—She could read his writing!

—When Senator Walters has finished. I have had complaints and representations. In response to the problem, I am pleased to announce that I have appointed the Hon. Elliott Johnston, QC, as the first purchasing complaints commissioner with responsibility over Administrative Services purchasing. Government purchasing amounts to a monumental $10 billion a year, and within that amount Administrative Services alone spends some $1 billion a year. We also have a pivotal role in purchasing policy and in common use contracts.

PARA.TAB: We are keen to respond to the problem and to do so in a constructive, comprehensive and independent manner. With this in mind, I recently appointed Mr Elliott Johnston to the position of purchasing complaints commissioner. In that role he will have a number of functions to perform. He will have the role of reviewing public complaints against Department of Administrative Services decisions in an independent manner. He will have the responsibility for dealing with them promptly and he will also have an overall responsibility for ensuring probity in Commonwealth purchasing.

As well, he will have the responsibility for developing a model system of procedures, practices and guidelines in respect of government purchasing. I have appointed Mr Johnston for a one-year term. At the end of this period I expect that he will make recommendations about the future operations of his office. He will also have the responsibility of working in a complementary manner with the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

TALK.START.PARA: —How old is this bloke?

—For some reason Senator Alston raises the age of this person. I do not think the age of a person ought to be held against him, particularly in these situations, where the person brings great experience and skills to the job. If Senator Alston wants to discriminate against people because of their age, I can understand why he was tossed out of the social security portfolio.

PARA.TAB: I am confident that Mr Johnston, who has served in the South Australian Supreme Court for a number of years and also most recently on the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, will successfully ensure that complaints in this area are competently and adequately handled.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. I refer him to the latest of Labor's jobs for the boys—the appointment of the new Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Mr John Read. Why did Mrs Kelly and not the Territories portfolio Minister, Ms Fatin, announce the appointment of Mr Read, a former Western Australian State Labor MP, to a position with benefits of over $150,000 a year? Did Ms Fatin deliberately dissociate herself from the announcement because it could have been perceived as a pay-off to Mr Read, who was the Labor branch president responsible for her pre-selection in Brand, where they both live, and her failure to secure a reciprocal endorsement deal for her mate with the Labor Party in the Western Australian upper House?

Honourable members will be aware of Government's commitment to introduce a new legal regime and to achieve mainland conditions and standards on Cocos. Mr Read's experience serving on several task forces—
—You are very subdued today.

—I have discovered actually—I have mentioned this once before and I will continue to exploit it—that all of the hubbub and screaming and yelling here in the Senate chamber is wasted on the outside because the technicians in this building quite sensibly turned down all the microphones except that of the person speaking. Mr Read's experience serving on several task forces and working parties associated with the provision of services and meeting the needs of people of developing regions will be invaluable to the implementation of these reforms.

Could the appointment still be perceived as a pay-off, given that Mr Read was previously Cabinet Secretary to West Australia Inc. Premier Burke, that he received $15,000 from the discredited Labor leader's account in 1989 before getting a special favoured State development job, and that he is now being rewarded with another generous job from Mrs Fatin and Labor mates?
—Order! There are too many comments.
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that the world's largest reinsurance company, Munich Re, has calculated that the increased severity and frequency of windstorms from the 1960s to the 1980s caused economic and insured losses to grow threefold and fivefold respectively. Is he also aware of Munich Re's conclusion that this represents a dramatic trend which will get worse under the greenhouse effect as cyclones increase, not only in frequency and intensity but also duration, size and areas of risk? Does he agree that on the evidence of Munich Re the greenhouse effect is potentially a major economic cost to Australia which should be incorporated into the Government's economic forecasts?

—I was not aware of that report. In the circumstances it is difficult for me to agree or disagree about its conclusions. But, of course, in terms of its essential point that if the predictions about the greenhouse effect are correct, then there are substantial economic consequences inherent in those predictions.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to his answer to my question yesterday. It seems that there he was saying that he and the Government would ignore the recommendations of 99 out of 196 Nobel Prize winning scientists on this issue. Now he seems to be prepared to ignore the evidence of one of the world's largest reinsurance companies. I ask again: should not the Government incorporate either the scientific evidence or the economic evidence into its calculation of the Government's economic forecasts?
—If it is Senator Coulter's view that my answer to his question yesterday was that the Government was going to ignore the statement by a group of scientists, I suggest he go and re-read Hansard.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. At a Senate Select Committee meeting held in the lunch hour, the general manager of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, Mr Tony Branigan, denied that the commercial television stations had entered into an agreement with the Prime Minister to a legislative alteration to television classification and time slots. He claimed that they had agreed only to a self-regulatory code whereas the Minister told us last night and again this morning that they had agreed to a legislative change. Who is telling the truth? Is it the Minister and the Prime Minister or Mr Branigan?

—Why is Senator Walters always picking on me? I said explicitly that one could not actually describe what has been proposed by the Prime Minister as an agreement because in fact it is not a secret that the networks are far from enthusiastic, despite the fact that at least two of them have agreed with the Government's proposals. I think what I said on AM this morning was that they were not exactly turning handsprings over it. The reason I make that point is that it is irrelevant as to what the networks might feel they will do or not do.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has put up a proposal and that is how I described it. A commitment has been given that we will legislate for it. That commitment was actually enshrined deliberately by me in a motion in the Senate—not just introduced into the debate—and the Government will deliver on that commitment.

The Prime Minister has indicated quite clearly the Government's expectations on this matter and I can add nothing to the formal motion that was moved here in the Senate. The Government will legislate and indeed the work on this proposal, as I said in the Senate this morning, has already begun in my office. I have already had one meeting with the Chief Censor, John Dickie, on the matter. I am meeting later this afternoon with both Mr Dickie and Brian Johns, the Chairman of the ABA, and the Government will introduce the appropriate legislation to enshrine the proposal of the Government at the earliest opportunity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I quote from the Hansard for last night. The Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . I am in the fortunate position of advising the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has succeeded in his negotiations with the television industry in producing a proposal which I hope every senator would support. It is certainly the most sensible proposition in terms of classification that I have seen for some time, and the Prime Minister is to be congratulated on getting this agreement, perhaps reluctantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters, if you do not ask the supplementary, you will run out of time.
—He goes on—
—Order! The time for the supplementary question has expired. I call Senator Devereux.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Even Senator Collins, I think, was waiting to be given the opportunity to answer the simple question of whether or not there was an agreement.

—On the point of order, Mr President: on a previous occasion when a member on our side was overly long in the preface and got only halfway through a question, these people opposite objected and said there was no supplementary question. We did not even get the start of the question from Senator Walters.
—Order! I did not think Senator Walters got to the stage at all of asking a supplementary question. If Senator Collins believes that she did and wants to answer, I will allow him to answer.

—I had my meter turned full on and I failed to detect any kind of question in the statement Senator Walters just made. But if somebody else can divine a question from the statement she just read into Hansard, I will answer. If we could, just for Senator Walters's sake, manufacture a question out of a statement where there was no question, I have nothing to add to my previous answer.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Collins asked whether we could manufacture a question. Yes, we can: why did he mislead the Senate?
—Order! The senator has answered the supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. What action does the Government propose to take on the recommendations and report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act?

—I have seen the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. A momentous task has been undertaken by the members of the Committee. Certainly it is quite evident that the energies that have been dedicated by senators here and members in the other place to its tabling yesterday have been commensurate with that task. I congratulate Senator McKiernan for his very evident capacity in shepherding the Committee to a virtually unanimous report on a whole host of recommendations. I also wish to say that Senator Brownhill, who first approached me with a view to getting this Committee off the ground, certainly deserves tribute as well.

PARA.TAB: I have noticed the emphasis on counselling and mediation as ways to reduce not only litigation but also the bitterness associated with the dissolution of a marriage relationship. I understand—every senator would—that the sort of hurt and grievance that is experienced in relation to these matters cannot be remedied always by the Parliament or parliamentary committees. But evidently there has been a very comprehensive attempt here to ensure that a framework can be provided whereby some of the hurt can be healed and some of the grievances can be remedied.

Reading some aspects of the report very briefly, I noted that there is an emphasis on the need to provide stability and security for children after the dissolution of a marriage. For that reason, I understand that the Committee has recommended against joint custody arrangements. I also notice that the question of access by non-custodial parents and the non-enforcement of court orders in relation to that has caused a lot of anger and frustration, as evidenced to the Committee and reported on by it. I believe that quite clearly the enforcement of those access orders needs to be tightened up by the court; that comes through very clearly from the report.

As to property settlements, it is most interesting that the Committee recommended a fifty-fifty starting point. Senator Brownhill also got up his point about special consideration being given to family properties in relation to these matters.

I am quite sure that this report will be of great assistance not only to the Family Court of Australia when considering the report's various recommendations but also to the Parliament and the Government. I can assure the members of the Committee that the Government welcomes the tabling of the report. We will immediately commence our consideration of the very many recommendations that are contained within it so that the sense of anguish and anger, and certainly the anxiety and sense of grievance, that is sometimes experienced by people, not only in relation to the divorce but also in relation to the operations of Family Court, is lessened as much as possible and not exacerbated by the operations of the court or the law. We will certainly try to ensure that in response to this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: New South Wales Public Service: Equal Pay

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman has been chasing my office for an answer to a question about equal pay in the New South Wales Public Service. I have again been in touch with the Treasurer's office. I am sure that the answer will be provided tomorrow.

—Yesterday, Senator MacGibbon asked me about the present situation concerning the weapons and ammunitions taken to the Western Sahara by the Australian contingent to MINURSO. As I advised Senator MacGibbon, the weapons and ammunition, along with communications equipment, were impounded by the Moroccans. The weapons and ammunitions are now stored with the local authorities at Laayoune. The Australian contingent has full access to them and may remove them from storage if the situation demands. Further, it conducts servicing and stocktaking of the weapons and ammunitions on a regular basis.

PARA.TAB: The current security situation does not necessitate the members of our contingent being armed. I am advised that the other national contingents involved in MINURSO do not carry personal weapons. We reserve the right to draw those weapons from storage should there be any deterioration in the current security situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to a question from Senator Crane in the Senate yesterday as to whether I have a copy of a police report which claims that organised crime and international terrorist groups have infiltrated building unions in Melbourne and what action I would take to investigate the allegations. First, I do not have a copy of the relevant report. I was not aware of the allegation referred to that terrorist groups have infiltrated building unions in Melbourne. I have been advised that the report is an internal Victorian police report which is now three years old and which has not been officially released. I do not have access to a copy of it.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that the Government has set a framework in Australia in which unions are required to act in a democratic and lawful fashion. In cases where claims of unlawful behaviour by unions have been substantiated, the Government has acted to deal with the matter quickly and effectively. Indeed, as I noted in the Senate yesterday, the Government took action to deregister the BLF for unlawful behaviour.

If Senator Crane can substantiate his claims beyond newspaper reports, further consideration will be given to the matter. If unlawful or criminal aspects appear to be involved, the appropriate law enforcement authorities have the responsibility for acting. In the meantime, the Government will continue to focus on the positive efforts undertaken by the industry within the framework of the construction industry reform strategy to develop a more productive and internationally competitive industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 November and 11 November, Senator O'Chee asked me a series of questions concerning the collapse of Estate Mortgage and the relationship to that collapse of the National Companies and Securities Commission and the Reserve Bank. I have provided to Senator O'Chee three very detailed answers to those questions. I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—

Senator Michael Tate: On 4 November 1992 (Hansard Page 2213) Senator Bill O'Chee asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General whether the then head of the National Companies and Securities Commission, Mr Henry Bosch, had contacted the Reserve Bank in the seven days prior to what Senator O'Chee described as the collapse of the Estate Mortgage unit trusts to express the then Chairman's concern about the trusts and about the actions of banks in relation to the trusts. Senator O'Chee asked a number of related questions each of which was predicated on the assumption that such a meeting had taken place. I have taken Senator O'Chee's reference to the `collapse' of the Estate Mortgage unit trusts to be a reference to the issue on 11 April 1990 by the Commissioner for Corporate Affairs for the State of Victoria, as delegate of the NCSC, of an instrument under section 215C of the Companies Codes suspending the buy-back provisions of the Estate Mortgage trusts.

In response to Senator O'Chee I indicated that, under the then diffused responsibility through the Ministerial Council of Federal, State and Territory Ministers, the Federal Attorney-General would not have had the sort of political responsibility to deal with Mr Bosch or to deal with activities of the NCSC in the answerable way which the honourable senator implied in his question. I undertook, nevertheless, to ask the successor to the NCSC, the ASC, whether it could find in its records any evidence of such a meeting that might be helpful to Senator O'Chee. I extended that undertaking to any evidence that might be available in the records of the Attorney-General's Department. The matters raised by Senator O'Chee were referred to the Australian Securities Commission and the Attorney-General's Department whose advice to me is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Securities Commission has advised that:

On 10 December 1991 Senator O'Chee wrote to the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Tony Hartnell, requesting information on a number of matters related to the Estate Mortgage trusts.

Mr Hartnell replied on the same day to Senator O'Chee providing answers to his questions and also attaching a copy of an undated briefing note prepared by a senior officer of the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission.

On 11 December l991, Senator O'Chee wrote further to Mr Hartnell indicating that the briefing included in Mr Hartnell's response of 10 December had given rise to a number of concerns. One of the concerns identified by Senator O'Chee was expressed as follows:
`It is unclear what advice was given to the Reserve Bank of Australia, although it is noted that the NCSC had considerable concern over the activities of some of the banks.'
In a response on the same day, 11 December 1991, to Senator O'Chee, Mr Hartnell advised, in relation to the above mentioned concern of Senator O'Chee that:
`Unfortunately we have been unable to locate any note of the discussions which we believe occurred between the former Chairman of the NCSC, Mr Henry Bosch, and the Reserve Bank.'

As a result of Senator O'Chee's question without notice to me on 4 November the ASC has re-examined its records and reaffirms that no record has been found of any meeting or discussion between Mr Bosch and the Reserve Bank on the matter of the Estate Mortgage trusts in the period prior to the issue of the instrument under section 215C of the Companies Codes on 11 April 1990 to suspend the buy-back provisions of the Estate Mortgage trusts.
The Attorney-General's Department has advised me that:
By letter dated 18 December 1991 Senator O'Chee made an FOI request to the Department seeking access to
`documents which contain any information relating to difficulties being experienced by the Estate Mortgage Trusts between 14 February 1990 and 30 April 1990'.
The request went on to say that

`This would include correspondence, file notes, internal memos and minutes, and minutes of meetings of any officers of the Department of the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia and/or the National Companies and Securities Commission and/or the Department of the Attorney-General'.
A response to Senator O'Chee's request was provided to him by the Department in a letter dated 30 April 1992.

Following Senator O'Chee's question without notice on 4 November, the Department has undertaken an examination of files held in the Department relating to proceedings of meetings of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities held during the period 2 March l990—12 October 1990.

An examination of those files has not revealed any information relating to any meetings or discussions that may have taken place between Mr Bosch and the Reserve Bank in relation to Estate Mortgage trusts.

In the light of its consideration of, and response to, Senator O'Chee's comprehensive FOI request dated 18 December 1991, the Department has not re-examined its files relating to Estate Mortgage trusts.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Tate: On 11 November 1992 (Hansard Page 2754) Senator Bill O'Chee asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General a question without notice relating to my knowledge of what he described as a `memorandum prepared by the National Companies and Securities Commission just prior to the freezing of the Estate Mortgage property trusts'. That memorandum, a copy of which was provided to me by Senator O'Chee, refers to the provision of advice by the NCSC to the Reserve Bank.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator O'Chee has asked when that advice was provided to the Reserve Bank and, on the assumption that that advice was provided at a meeting, who was present at that meeting. Senator O'Chee has further asked whether either the Treasurer or the Attorney-General was notified of the concerns of the NCSC referred to in that memorandum. Finally, Senator O'Chee has asked `Why was it that the NCSC and the Reserve Bank allowed millions of investors' dollars to pour into Estate Mortgage at a time when both knew that it was hopelessly insolvent'?

I have drawn the attention of the Treasurer to Senator O'Chee's question concerning whether the then Treasurer was notified of the concerns of the NCSC referred to in the memorandum. I am tabling with this response the Treasurer's answer to Senator O'Chee's question as it relates to the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer's responsibilities.

I have already informed the Senate, in response to an earlier question without notice asked of me by Senator O'Chee on 4 November 1992, of advice provided to me by the Australian Securities Commission and the Attorney-General's Department in relation to the document in question.

As indicated in my response to that question by Senator O'Chee, the Australian Securities Commission has advised that it believes that a discussion occurred between the former Chairman of the NCSC, Mr Henry Bosch, and the Reserve Bank, but that it has been unable to locate any note of such a discussion between Mr Bosch and the Reserve Bank on the matter of the Estate Mortgage trusts in the period prior to the issue of the instrument under section 215C of the Companies Codes on 11 April 1990 to suspend the buy-back provisions of the Estate Mortgage trusts.
The Attorney-General has advised me that he has no record or recollection of having been advised of the NCSC's concerns at that time.

As indicated in answers to previous questions by Senator O'Chee relating to the Estate Mortgage trusts, the NCSC was not, under the arrangements then in place for the co-operative companies and securities scheme, accountable to the Commonwealth Attorney-General for its actions and policies. It was accountable only to a Ministerial Council of eight Ministers of which the Commonwealth Attorney-General was one. There is nothing in records of that Council to which the Attorney-General's Department has access that indicates why the NCSC acted as it did in relation to the Estate Mortgage trusts.

On 11 November 1992, Senator O'Chee asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General a question without notice concerning a memorandum relating to Estate Mortgage Trust, including references to the Reserve Bank.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided me with the following response in relation to the references to the Reserve Bank:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the Reserve Bank advised by the NCSC in the terms used in the memorandum, and who was present at the meeting?

INTERJECT.PARA: There was no meeting between the Bank and the National Companies and Securities Commission during the period relevant to the issues raised by Senator O'Chee.

There was telephone contact between the Reserve Bank and the NCSC, as there is between the Bank and other supervisory authorities. Comments about Estate Mortgage to the Bank from the NCSC were not put in the terms used in the "Briefing Memorandum" from the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission tabled by Senator O'Chee.

PARA.TAB: (2) Was the Treasurer notified by the Reserve Bank in the terms of the memorandum?

INTERJECT.PARA: The Reserve Bank is not the prudential supervisor of mortgage trusts. The responsible bodies were the NCSC and the relevant State CAC. The Bank's interest in developments stemmed from its concern to ensure that there was not a systemic risk for the rest of the financial system.

PARA.TAB: (3) In view of the interpretation in the memorandum tabled by Senator O'Chee, why did the Reserve Bank take no action?

INTERJECT.PARA: As noted above, the substance of the (undated) memorandum tabled by Senator O'Chee was never put to the Reserve Bank by the NCSC.

The memorandum was, it is understood, prepared in early to mid April 1990 by an officer of the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission. His interpretation of events differ significantly from the views held by the Reserve Bank at that time.
In particular, the Reserve Bank would have difficulty agreeing with the following propositions contained in the memorandum:
Estate Mortgage was suffering from a liquidity problem (not an insolvency problem);
there was no risk of fraud or malpractice; and
that it would be sensible, on normal commercial grounds, for banks to increase lending to Estate Mortgage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) this day, in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane on 24 November 1992 relating to terrorist groups infiltrating unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that Senator Crane can have it all ways. Senator Crane rose with angelic naivety pretending that he made an innocent inquiry of me yesterday in Question Time. It would be a credible claim were it not a fact that the resident union basher in this chamber is Senator Crane and that on every opportunity he can find an occasion to put the boot in, he does.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. That is a reflection on Senator Crane. He is not a resident union basher. In fact, I think Senator Crane quite often actually acknowledges good work that unions have done in the past. Why should he be referred to in those terms?
—I took it as a term being used in debate. I cannot see where it is unparliamentary.

—Thank you, Mr President. The fact is that this is notorious. I do not think Senator Crane, in his private moments and among his cognoscenti, would deny it. In fact, he would luxuriate in the title. Let me turn to the issue that has been raised here.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I find that remark offensive. It is not true; it is false. I have often spoken in this place about this matter. Yesterday I made the point that under our industrial relations policy some unions would get stronger and better. I am not a resident union basher. I find the remark offensive and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Order! I am not ruling it as unparliamentary. However, it might be better if it is withdrawn.

—Mr President, I do not think I would want to deny the accuracy of my remarks, so I will not withdraw them on this occasion. One can, in an underhand way, make an allegation by rising and asking an angelically innocent question. Senator Crane knows that his question contains allegations of misconduct and by throwing that sort of mud he is hoping that some of it will stick.

PARA.TAB: My Department inquired of the Victorian police about the existence of the report. From the other end of the phone in Melbourne it got a horse laugh and a guffaw that it was unbelievable that anyone would have even bothered with this; and that they could not understand why my Department was inquiring about a backdated document which had no current relevance.

That is the situation with the Victorian police, who are the authors of this document. It is three years old. It is not relevant to current circumstances. The facts are that the West Australian newspaper has reported this three years after the event, when the document itself is not a public document; the document carries so much weight in the eyes of the Victorian police that they did nothing at all about it; and the document is so important to Victoria that they did not notify my Department or me, or anyone else to do with industrial relations, about it.

If we put those three points end to end, what conclusion do we arrive at? Simply this: it is a discredited document. People do make reports and do come to conclusions but whether all the reports and all the conclusions have standing, efficacy and relevance is another matter. In these circumstances, this document is established as not being an appropriate document referring to relevant circumstances. So the West Australian newspaper, three years on—

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know if you haven't seen it?

—Senator Short has breached Standing Orders by interjecting, `How do you know if you haven't seen it?'. Let me answer his interjection by saying: I am advised by my Department, which inquired of the Victorian police, that that was the answer the Victorian police gave. It is on that basis that I make the assumption I do. People wish to trot out these things after the event and try to get some points on the board. These actions define them as disreputable. In this case, that is a true reflection on the West Australian newspaper. It is also a true reflection on the innocence and naivety which is pretended by Senator Crane.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that we have a strategy in place to sort out the building industry and it is working. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
