SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Walters this day, relating to television broadcasting classifications.

SPEECH.PARA: During Question Time today I asked Senator Collins a question in which I pointed out very clearly that the General Manager of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, Mr Tony Branigan, had told the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services that at no time had he made an agreement with the Government about a legislative change to classification or time slots. That was very clear. In answer to my question, Senator Collins replied that he had not said that an agreement had been undertaken. Yesterday's Hansard shows that he said:
. . . the Prime Minister is to be congratulated on getting this agreement, perhaps reluctantly.

The Minister has very clearly and unequivocally misled the Senate. He assured us and the Australian Democrats—Senator Kernot was also at the same Committee meeting—that an agreement had been reached with commercial television stations. That was not the case. Indeed, after Mr Branigan had spoken to us, Senator Kernot phoned the Minister's office and said, `Is this going into legislation—Mr Branigan is unaware that this is going to happen?'. The Minister's office replied that yes, it was.

PARA.TAB: As far as we know, Mr Branigan was completely unaware that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister representing him in the Senate had said that an agreement had been reached between the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Government. The Senate cannot be misled in that way.

It must have been very obvious to Senator Collins that I would take note of the answer he gave today. But he has not chosen to come back into the chamber and defend himself for the very reason that he is unable to. It is very clearly shown in Hansard that he said that the Prime Minister should be congratulated on the agreement. He then went on—I was about to read this into the record when I was pulled up because I had run out of time—to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it is too strong to say that it is an agreement . . .
He thinks that will let him off. But he said:
. . . the Prime Minister is to be congratulated on getting this agreement, perhaps reluctantly.
Then he tried to tell the Senate that the commercial television stations had agreed so reluctantly that we could not call it an agreement.

PARA.TAB: A few minutes ago I asked Senator Kernot whether she was under the impression yesterday that Senator Collins had said that the legislative method of going about this was an agreement. She said, yes, she was. I am quite sure all of us would be—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I simply want to point out again to Senator Walters—I know she is obsessed with this matter—that it is a matter of public record that the television networks are not enthusiastically buoyant about the arrangements that we are now progressing and which are yet to be finalised, and for obvious reasons. They have reason to be not exactly enthusiastic because there will be a cost to them. The Government believes that that is a cost they should bear.

PARA.TAB: I point out the obvious to the chamber and to Senator Walters: the arrangements that have been entered into by the networks, as reluctantly as they have been, relate to the essential elements of what has been proposed. There are three elements: firstly, a common system across all media—about time it happened—in so far as it is possible to do that, perhaps modified for television; secondly, splitting the M category into two more sensible categories; thirdly, changes to the broadcasting time of those arrangements.

I should not have to point this out to Senator Walters, but the decision as to whether to enshrine these proposals in legislation is a matter for the Government, not for the executives of any television peak body, whether it is Mr Branigan, with the greatest respect, or anyone else. We are progressing these arrangements in consultation with the television industry, and as I said, we are progressing these arrangements as I speak. The decision as to whether we legislate will not be taken by executives of television industry bodies. The Government has determined that we will legislate to enshrine these arrangements, and legislate we will.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the economic impact of the greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.PARA: My question today followed a question yesterday coming at the same matter from a different direction. The question today related to the world's largest reinsurance company, Munich Re, which has found that its pay-outs as a result of storm damage have increased by a factor of three- and five-fold in various areas over the last 20 years, something it attributes to an emerging greenhouse problem.

PARA.TAB: The question yesterday related to the fact that 99 of 196 prize winning Nobel laureates had signed a declaration, along with 1,500 scientists, calling attention to the damage which was occurring to the global atmosphere, and saying that globally we needed to change our polluting habits very rapidly or we would face mass problems not only with human civilisation but with survival of life on earth.
In answer to my question as to whether the Government would change its stance as a result of that document from those learned scientists, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: The answer to that question is no, it will not be reversed on the basis of a statement by a group of scientists. All these issues were canvassed in the run-up to the Rio conference and again at the Rio conference. The fact that scientists have made a statement about these issues will not, I think, change the Government's view.

Today I put to the Minister the fact that this was now, according to the world's largest reinsurance company, costing money. The Government's defence of its position in relation to greenhouse all along has been that because Australia was a large producer of coal and fossil fuel and, indeed, was a very large polluter, it would cost Australia to do something about reducing greenhouse gas emissions.The point that I am attempting to establish here is that it is costing us a great deal and will cost us a great deal more if we do not do something about addressing greenhouse. For the Minister to naively weigh in the balance sheet the costs of not exporting, say, so much coal but, on the other hand, ignore the evident and increasing cost of damage as a consequence of greenhouse emissions—

TALK.START.PARA: —And to farmers.

—As my colleague Senator Bell points out by way of interjection, there is also the cost to farmers because of climate change. I remind the Senate that we have had a major drought throughout eastern Australia for the last two years and scientists are not at all sure that the effects of the El Nino are not related to greenhouse. The effects on the Australian economy will be very large if we do not do something about addressing greenhouse. The point I want to establish is a very simple one. This Government has been stupid. It is not doing the correct sums on greenhouse. If it were doing the correct sums, it would be taking these matters very much into consideration.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Durack this day relating to industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that this question related to the Government's attitude to the strikes which are occurring in my home State of Victoria. Senator Durack's question, in summary, pointed out that the Prime Minister himself had conceded that unemployment may rise to over one million. He asked whether the Prime Minister or Senator Cook would be calling upon the ACTU to abandon its proposed union action to avoid further job losses. The Senate will recall that the ACTU has flagged that there will be a major union national day of protest, as it is called, on 30 November.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting that this is clearly becoming an issue of great embarrassment to the Keating Government. Senator Cook's answer in this chamber today shows the embarrassment that the Government feels. Of course, it cannot say that it supports the strike, although I believe that it does in all substantive matters, but it refuses to make any critical comments about the strike action which is occurring in Victoria, and certainly refuses to call on the ACTU to call it off.

Senator Durack quite rightly followed up with a supplementary question, attempting to press Senator Cook on whether he could give an indication, yes or no, as to whether the Government supported the strike. Again, Senator Cook ducked and weaved.

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in every major strike which has occurred around this nation in recent years, the Government has been directly involved—some of us would think not helping to solve the strike but, at least in its own language, and perhaps in the minds of its own members, attempting to solve the disputes which have occurred. We are seeing in Victoria, and spreading to other States, the most damaging strikes that we have seen in this country for some years. Losses will occur to industry and business, and losses will occur in jobs as a result of this strike action.

I would have thought that with unemployment at close to one million, any responsible Prime Minister would tell the ACTU—tell John Halfpenny—to call it off. I do not believe that is the case at all. I believe that what we are seeing is the political arm of the trade union movement—which is the Labor Party—faced with a reforming government in Victoria which is determined to ensure that trade unions operate under the same laws as other people and institutions, and determined in every way to attempt to defeat the properly elected Kennett Government.

We are seeing Mr Keating and Senator Cook and his colleagues actively working with the ACTU behind the scenes to promote as much industrial disruption as they possibly can in Victoria in the hope that the Kennett Government's reforms will be defeated. I believe that Mr Keating and Senator Cook will start to appreciate that they cannot escape scot-free. As the disputes continue in Victoria, the blame and the public focus will inevitably swing back to what the Labor Party—the political arm of the trade union movement—is doing about it and what role it is playing behind the scenes. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support Senator Kemp's motion to take note of Senator Cook's answer to Senator Durack's question without notice. Senator Cook completely misrepresented coalition policy when he said that a coalition government would throw people off social security and on to the scrap heap after nine months. That is not our policy. It is a complete misrepresentation—and I would use much stronger language if I did not want to be in this chamber tomorrow to debate some other legislation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook knows, as does the whole electorate of Australia, that our policy includes a special program for people who have been on unemployment benefits for nine months. There will be a special program aimed at finding out what the problem really is and why these people cannot get back into the work force. They will be well covered by social security under this special program.

Senator Cook has continually made this false statement during Question Time. He did so twice today, not only in answer to Senator Durack's question but also in answer to another question. The reason I have risen is to point that out and to point out to the people of Australia what the coalition policy is. There will be a special program after nine months; people will not be thrown on to the scrap heap, left to fend for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to speak briefly on the motion to take note of the answer given to me by Senator Cook at Question Time today in relation to the national day of protest which is being organised, orchestrated and supported by the ACTU. In my question, I noted that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has now conceded that the number of people unemployed in Australia could exceed one million. Despite a five-minute torrent of words from Senator Cook, he did not provide me with an answer. He challenged my statement as to whether the Prime Minister had in fact conceded that that figure could exceed one million.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in the House of Representatives, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) asked the Prime Minister to answer yes or no as to whether he could give an assurance that the number of people unemployed in Australia would not pass one million. The Prime Minister, having avoided answering that simple question for the next two and a half pages of Hansard, ended his torrent of words by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It is my sincere hope that unemployment does not pass the one million mark . . . We are now at 980,000; but it will be lower under Labor than under the coalition. That is the key point.
That is clearly a concession by the Prime Minister, as was the headline story on page one in this morning's Australian, which read:
Jobless may pass 1 million: Keating

That is clearly interpreted correctly. So much for Senator Cook's attempted correction of my statement. Perhaps more importantly than that, Senator Cook was asked a simple question today about whether the Government—the Prime Minister or Senator Cook—would call on the ACTU to try to dissuade the unions from going on with this ridiculous national day of protest which can only do harm to themselves, to their jobs and to the productivity of Victoria that is so desperately in need of improvement at the present time.

PARA.TAB: For five minutes, Senator Cook failed to answer that question, as he always does. The specific supplementary question I then asked was whether the Minister would say whether the Government supports or opposes that strike. That was another simple question which the Minister spent another two minutes not answering. Senator Cook's inability to answer questions, except by way of a torrent of words, is becoming an endemic problem. Senator Cook had two minutes in which to answer the supplementary question, but he managed to avoid doing so, even though he could have answered it in a few seconds.

Senator Cook had already been asked whether the Government supported the previous stoppage in Victoria and he avoided answering that question. In view of the answers we have had from Senator Cook, it is quite clear that the Government is in complete sympathy with the massive and unjustified industrial action which is planned to be taken on 30 November in Australia and which is being threatened to be continued indefinitely in Victoria. Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEESLegal and Constitutional AffairsTransport, Communications and Infrastructure

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's responses to the following reports of committees: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report on the Aboriginal Development Commission—Legal costs in relation to Senate privileges matter; Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure report on developing satellite launch facilities in Australia and the role of government; and the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies report on telephone message services. I seek leave to incorporate the documents in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator B. Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Legal and Constitutional Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney

In June this year, the Attorney-General's Department advised that it seemed appropriate for my Department to take carriage of preparing a response to your Committee's Report tabled in August 1991 entitled "Aboriginal Development Commission—Legal Costs in Relation to Senate Privileges Matter". The report had previously been forwarded to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission for action but it was apparently returned with ATSIC advising that action on the recommendation made in the Report was outside its responsibilities.

I note the (sole) recommendation in the Report that Commonwealth agencies seeking to engage legal representation from the private sector require a detailed bill of costs as a matter of course. I endorse this recommendation and can advise that the Finance Directions issued under the Audit Act 1901, for which I am responsible, already require this from Commonwealth agencies subject to that Act. Finance Direction 13B states:

A department receiving a claim for payment of legal fees or costs (other than for minor amounts) must refer it promptly to the Attorney-General's Department, the local Director of Legal Services or Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, as appropriate, for assessment as to whether the claim is fair and reasonable. The department must have regard to that assessment in subsequently paying the claim.

I believe that, for the majority of the Commonwealth, this requirement more than adequately covers the recommendation made in the Committee's Report. The Finance Directions apply to all Commonwealth bodies which do not legally "own" moneys separately from the Executive Government—in practice, departments and those Commonwealth statutory authority agencies declared in the Finance Regulations to be prescribed authorities for the purposes of the Act. Many other statutory authority entities which are not legally subject to the Finance Directions find it convenient to pattern their internal financial instructions on these rules to a greater or lesser extent.

Neither the Aboriginal Development Commission nor ATSIC are subject to the Audit Act and, while it would seem a sensible practice for such bodies to accord with the Committee's recommendation, the Executive Government has limited legislative authority to interfere with the day to day administrative procedures practised by entities which Parliament has sanctioned to operate at arms length from the Executive.
Yours sincerely
RALPH WILLIS
30 October 1992

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE CONTAINED IN THE REPORT "DEVELOPING SATELLITE LAUNCH FACILITIES IN AUSTRALIA AND THE ROLE OF GOVERNMENT".

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation

The Committee RECOMMENDS that if the Project Definition Study supports further development of the (Southern Launch Vehicle) project, the Government should consider favourably further financial or other forms of tangible assistance, to enable the project to proceed expeditiously through its next development phase. Thereafter, additional assistance for the remainder of the development program should be investigated and if warranted and not available commercially, be considered favourably. (Paragraph 3.17)
Response

2.The potential commercial viability of the SLV project will be kept under continuing review in conformity with the tenor of this recommendation. Discussions are currently being held on this subject with the South Australian Government, the Department of Defence and the MFP project office. Other options for tangible Government assistance will also be investigated as they arise.
3.Should any major Government financial assistance be proposed, this will be the subject of specific consideration by the Government.
Recommendation

4.The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Government give a high priority to implementing a review of the future of the Woomera Rocket Range and its facilities not only with the aim of assessing its defence related uses but also to determine what refurbishment or further development is required so that the facility may be used to its full potential. The Committee further RECOMMENDS that the review involve thorough consultation with potential users and industry and that a study be undertaken to assess the Range's international marketability. (Paragraph 3.39).
Response

5.Consideration of the future of the Woomera Rocket Range falls within the purview of the Department of Defence who, as noted by the Committee, have already conducted a study of potential commercial use. The Australian Space Office will liaise closely with the Department of Defence in respect of potential use of the Woomera facilities for space-related activities, including any potential international interest.
Recommendation

6.If as the ASO claims, phase two and three of the project cannot be funded in Australia, the Committee RECOMMENDS that senior officers of the ASO, during the regular visits overseas, Australian diplomatic missions and Austrade representatives based overseas, be directed to actively assist WBM-Stalker to promote the development of the scramjet technology. (Paragraph 3.69)
Response

7.The Government has noted the Committee's concern that no funding was made available for Phase 1 of this project. Consideration is being given by the Australian Space Board to funding the Phase 1 activities as a space-related science project of interest to the National Space Program. This would place the primary emphasis on maintaining the current Australian world-leadership in this technology, and would retain the option for future consideration of Phases 2 and 3 in accordance with the Committee's recommendation.
Recommendation

8.The Committee RECOMMENDS that if the ASB review panel is not able to conduct an examination of Commonwealth authorities' responsibilities relating to space activities the Government should initiate such a review, to be conducted by an appropriately qualified reviewing authority. (Paragraph 5.14)
Response

9.A panel set up by the Government to review the activities of the Australian Space Board (ASB) addressed this recommendation in their report. The panel noted that it shared the concern underlying this recommendation and believed that its report had produced recommendations which it intends will resolve this matter. A major mechanism for resolution of this question is the Australian Space Council, to be established in accordance with the Science and Technology Statement, 1992-93 (Budget Related Paper No 6),(page 1.48).
Recommendation

10.The Committee is aware that at present there is no Australian licensing authority responsible for launching services. Therefore, the Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Space Office should initiate and co-ordinate action by the relevant Government authorities, in consultation with commercial entities to formulate a basic legislative and regulatory framework which will ensure that space-related activities are not delayed or impeded by a lack of appropriate legislation. When the need arises the framework can be adapted to meet specific requirements. (Paragraph 5.42)
Response

11.The Government notes the concerns underlying this recommendation and, in particular, the Committee's observations concerning the need to send a strong signal to the international space community by early establishment of an appropriate regulatory framework. The scheduled activities in respect of this aspect will be conducted within a timeframe which will ensure completion in accordance with this recommendation.
Recommendation

12.The Committee RECOMMENDS that deliberations on third party insurance liability policy give favourable consideration to capping the upper limit for such claims and apportioning only a share of the liability to launch service providers. (Paragraph 5.63)
Response
13.The Committee's recommendation and underlying rationale will be taken into account by the appropriate Issues Group (Group 5) when progress on launch projects justifies re-activation of their work.
Recommendation
14.The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Government gives a high priority to investigating the need to establish a national space policy council. (Paragraph 5.92)
Response

15.The Australian Space Council being established by the Government following the 1992-93 S&T (Budget) Statement is considered to satisfy this Committee recommendation. It will provide for high-level consultation and coordinated and cohesive management of all elements of the National Space Program.
Recommendation

16.If further work on the proposals clearly indicates that Australian launching services could be commercially viable the Committee RECOMMENDS that the Government, in addition to legislative, regulatory and international negotiations support, sympathetically considers infrastructure assistance and any other assistance and that the form and level of any assistance be closely investigated and defined precisely. The Committee also RECOMMENDS that if current industry assistance schemes are found to discourage or inhibit space industry development proposals, they should be reviewed. Furthermore such reviews should not be confined to the space industry but should be conducted to encourage development proposals from other industries. (Paragraph 6.6)
Response
17.The case for appropriate infrastructure and other assistance will be kept under review and the views of the Senate Standing Committee will be taken into account.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO THE REPORT FROM THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGIES INQUIRY INTO:

SPEECH.PARA: Introduction
The Government's response to the Committee's report incorporates AOTC's response, a copy of which is attached.

With regard to standards for message content (Recommendations 1-3) the Government agrees that relevant standards in line with community opinion are essential in this area. I note that AOTC accepts these recommendations in principle and is moving to put appropriate standards in place through negotiation with service providers and the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC). Clearly the Committee's recommendations on specific standards will be an important input to this process.

In relation to monitoring and enforcement of standards (Recommendations 4-7) the Government agrees with the arrangements proposed by the Committee and notes that AOTC is negotiating with the service providers and the OFLC to achieve their implementation. I have agreed with my colleague the Attorney-General that such a role for the OFLC is appropriate.

In addition, I have noted that the Telephone Service Providers Association of Australia (TELSPAA) announced that with effect from 12 May 1992 its members would remove "adult fantasy lines" from 0055, would not operate "Job Lines" that exploit unemployed people, and would support the advertising industry in developing appropriate rules for advertising of 0055 services.

The Government supports the substance of the Committee's recommendations in relation to consumer protection (Recommendations 8-11), although these need to be considered in the context of existing pro-consumer measures for telecommunications. At present, AUSTEL has a specific consumer protection role under the Telecommunications Act 1991 in receiving and investigating customer complaints, including complaints about charging and billing. In practice, individual complaints are referred by AUSTEL to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, to whom complaints may also be made direct.
Arrangements are currently in hand for the establishment of a Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman by AOTC and Optus in accordance with the conditions of their licences.

The Government believes that current and proposed consumer protection arrangements, together with commitments already given by AOTC in relation to Recommendations 8-10, provide a framework which is adequate to address the Committee's concerns. Amendment of carrier licence conditions is, in the Government's view, not necessary at this stage, but could be re-examined should the arrangements I have outlined prove unsatisfactory.

Finally, the Government agrees that all licensed carriers should be subject to the same arrangements with regard to recorded information services (Recommendation 12). I have written to the Chairman of Optus Communications indicating that should they decide to provide recorded information services, the Government would welcome their participation in appropriate industry forums, and their conformance with industry arrangements for content and advertising standards and consumer protection.

I believe that the response from the industry to the legitimate concerns expressed by your Committee is substantially resolving the major problems. Nevertheless the Government will continue to monitor this matter and, as previously indicated by Senator Richardson, will take appropriate action should current arrangements prove inadequate.
In conclusion, on behalf of the Government I thank the Committee for a comprehensive and timely report on a difficult area.
AOTC
Senator the Honourable Bob Collins
Minister for Transport and Communications
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

As you know, the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards relevant to the Supply of Services utilising Telecommunication Technologies tabled its Final Report in Parliament on 28 May 1992 relating to recorded information telephone services.
The Final report contains recommendations from the Interim Report issued in December 1991 (some of which have been amended) as well as new recommendations relating to—
not disconnecting a telephone service for non-payment of charges for 0055 calls
greater publicity of the availability of call barring facilities
establishment of a system of independent mediation to resolve disputed call charges and payment of compensation in genuine cases of product failure
carrier licences to require all future carriers to enter into contracts with service providers and the OFLC similar to those recommended in the report.

AOTC's response to the recommendations is attached and, pending the Government's formal response to the Final Report, you may be assured that we are working expeditiously to implement the recommendations. In particular, those relating to message content and advertising standards (including the new arrangements with the Office of Film and Literature Classification) and the new contracts with Service Providers, are receiving close attention.
Yours sincerely
David M Hoare
CHAIRMAN

PARA.EMPHASIS: AOTC'S RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS CONTAINED IN THE FINAL REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGIES

SPEECH.PARA: AOTC's response to the Committee's Interim Report was included as part of the Government's response to that report in Parliament on 2 April 1992.

As several of the Committee's recommendations in its Final Report are identical to those appearing in the Interim Report, it is not proposed to comment on those recommendations to the same degree on this occasion.
AOTC's comments on the recommendations are set out below.
Recommendation 1: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for its message standard for the 0055 open access service the following:

(a)The Service Provider will not provide knowingly or negligently on any 0055 number allocated to it, information which in any way may be interpreted as indecent, obscene, offensive or sexually titillating or denoting sexual suggestion or sexual fantasy; and

PARA.TAB: (b)The Service Provider will not provide knowingly or negligently on any 0055 number allocated to it, messages whether described as medical or otherwise which contain material that a reasonable parent would not wish his or her child to hear without parental guidance.

SPEECH.PARA: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for its advertising standard for the 0055 open access service the following;

PARA.TAB: (c)The Service Provider must not advertise 0055 services in association with photographs or other artwork or any other information which may in any way be interpreted as indecent, obscene, offensive, sexually titillating or sexually suggestive.

(d)The Service Provider must ensure that none of its advertisements for a 0055 information service carries any connotation that the service may contain information of the type described in Recommendation 1(a) or 1(b).

(e)The Service Provider must ensure that none of its 0055 printed advertisements carries any connotation that the message(s) concerned may contain information of the type described in Recommendations 1(a) or 1(b), simply because of the location of such advertisements in association with other unrelated advertisements or articles which do contain information of the type described in those Recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be recalled that, in our response to the Interim report, AOTC expressed its concern with inclusion of the words "in any way" in part (a) of the recommendation. The Chief Censor of the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) commented in later evidence that he would have no problem with inclusion of those words and the Committee has decided to retain them in its Final Report.
In the circumstances, AOTC accepts the recommendation in principle, including the new parts (c), (d) and (e) relating to advertising.

Recommendation 2: That Telecom ensure that all services currently provided on 0055 which are in breach of the message standard as listed in Recommendation 1 are either migrated immediately to the opt-in 0051 closed user access service (which requires the use of a Personal Identification Number—PIN) or are withdrawn outright.
As outlined by the Committee in its report, action has been taken by AOTC and the Service Providers to meet the Committee's wishes. AOTC will continue to monitor the situation.

Recommendation 3: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for its message standard for the opt-in 0051 closed user access service (which requires the use of a Personal Identification Number—PIN) the following:

PARA.TAB: (a)The Service Provider will not provide knowingly or negligently on any 0051 number allocated to it, information which in any way may be interpreted as equivalent to the R or X film/video classifications.

SPEECH.PARA: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for its advertising standard for the opt-in 0051 closed access service (which requires the use of a Personal Identification Number—PIN) the following:

PARA.TAB: (b)The Service Provider must not advertise 0051 services in association with photographs or other artwork or any other information which may in any way be interpreted as equivalent to the R or X film/video classifications.

(c)The Service Provider must ensure that none of its advertisements for a 0051 information service carries any connotation that the service may contain information of the type described in Recommendation 3(a).

(d)The Service Provider must ensure that none of its 0051 printed advertisements carries any connotation that the message(s) concerned may contain information of the type described in Recommendation 3(a), simply because of the location of such advertisements in association with other unrelated advertisements or articles which do contain information of the type described in that Recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: AOTC has previously accepted in principle recommendation 3(a) but as a carrier does not have any considered views of the appropriateness of comparisons with the R or X film/video classifications.
As for recommendation 1, AOTC accepts in principle the advertising provisions contained in parts (b), (c) and (d) of the recommendation.
Recommendation 4: That Telecom discontinue its contractual agreements with Service Providers and offer new contractual agreements which observe the recommended code of conduct.
AOTC accepts this recommendation and discussions are proceeding with the Service Providers with a view to arranging for new contracts to be drawn up as soon as possible.

Existing contracts make provision for Service Providers to abide by the Codes of Practice. Pending finalisation of the new contracts, we have arranged for new guidelines to be issued which are consistent with the Committee's Recommendations 1 and 3.
Recommendation 5: That Telecom enter into a contract with the Office of Film and Literature Classification for it to act as the monitoring and enforcement body for the code of conduct.
This recommendation has been accepted by AOTC and negotiations for a contract with OFLC are at an advanced stage.
Recommendation 6: That Telecom undertake to introduce an immediate program of random monitoring to ensure contractual compliance of message content on both 0055 and 0051 with the code of conduct.
AOTC has previously indicated that it will continue the arrangements in place for monitoring of 0055 services.

Recommendation 7: That the code of conduct provide that any message content breach of the standards set out in Recommendation 1 for a 0055 message or Recommendation 3 for a 0051 message cause the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) to advise Telecom to adopt whichever of the following measures the OFLC deems appropriate to the case:

PARA.TAB: (a)that the breach be rectified within such period as specified by the OFLC and that failure to rectify a breach within such a period shall entitle Telecom Australia to suspend the operation of the relevant Telephone Information Service for such period as is specified by the OFLC;
(b)that the operation of the relevant Telephone Information Service be suspended until the breach has been rectified;
(c)that the operation of the relevant Telephone Information Service be suspended for such period as specified by the OFLC notwithstanding that the breach has been remedied;
(d)that the relevant Telephone Information Service be terminated; or
(e)that the Service Provider's Agreement be terminated forthwith.

SPEECH.PARA: AOTC accepts this recommendation and appreciates that it has been amended in such a way as to overcome previous reservations.

Recommendation 8: That the Service Providers be required to provide basic consumer information on the duration and cost of each message at the beginning of each recorded message; the cost of doing this to be borne by the Service Provider.

AOTC has previously agreed in principle with this recommendation and will be implementing it as soon as technically possible. AOTC proposes to adopt a targeted approach to implementation; for example, it would not be considered appropriate to provide information on duration and cost of messages such as recording of votes in telephone polls (very limited time frame for making calls).
Recommendation 9: That Telecom and any other carriers be required to both provide call barring to recorded information services and to better publicise its availability.

AOTC agrees with this recommendation and call barring to 0055 services is already available. In fact this is a feature of the Australian service and access to 0055 services is not provided unless call barring is technically feasible.

In regard to publicity, AOTC proposes to send a bill insert to all customers concerning 0055 and 0051 services and this will include details of barring arrangements. Timing of the issue of the bill insert is not clear at this stage as we would prefer the new arrangements with the OFLC to be in place first.

Recommendation 10: That it should be a condition of a carrier's licence that the basic telephone service should not be terminated for the non-payment of a component of a telephone bill relating to recorded information services, where that unpaid component relates to a debt due to a service provider.
Carrier licensing arrangements are a matter for Government consideration.

AOTC's basic position is that customers are responsible for telephone services under their control and for payment of related accounts. However it is AOTC's current practice that no telephone service will be disconnected for non-payment of the 0055/51 portion of the account. In cases of dispute, the matter is discussed with the customer with a view to satisfactory resolution. If it is considered that the account should stand, the debt would be pursued through other means, if necessary.

Recommendation 11: That AOTC and AUSTEL give consideration to the establishment of a system of independent mediation in respect to disputed bills for recorded information services, which should provide for a system of compensation in genuine cases of product failure.

Under the terms of the Government's licence provisions, carriers are required to be subject to a Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO) from 1 January 1993. It would seem appropriate to pursue this recommendation as part of the arrangements being developed for the TIO.

At present, the Commonwealth Ombudsman provides a source of independent review of disputed bill charges. Although the Ombudsman can only recommend a course of action, AOTC naturally gives full and serious consideration to any recommendation that Office makes with a view to accommodating the Ombudsman's conclusions.

Recommendation 12: That, in the context of a future competitive marketplace for telecommunications services, in the case of carriers intending to carry recorded information services, AUSTEL should be empowered to establish as conditions for the granting of a carrier's licence the conclusion by the carrier of contracts with: (a) recorded information service providers similar to those recommended in Recommendation 4 of this report; and (b) with the Office of Film and Literature Classification similar to that recommended in Recommendation 5 of this report.

AOTC agrees in principle with this recommendation. Carrier licence provisions are a matter for determination by the Minister for Transport and Communications under Sections 64 and 65 of the Telecommunications Act 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.
Debate (on motion by Senator Archer) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on the Parliamentary Zone

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—On behalf of the President, I present the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the Parliamentary Zone relating to the future of the old Parliament House. The report of the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Zone recommends that responsibility for the old Parliament House be transferred to the Presiding Officers. The old Parliament House would then be developed as a museum related to the Australian Constitution, Federation and the Australian Parliament.

The report was generally agreed before the Government announced that old Parliament House would be opened to the public. The Committee welcomes the decision to open up old Parliament House but considers the recommendations in the report still stand. The report notes that the year 2001 will be the centenary of the Australian Federation. One way to commemorate that centenary would be to establish a museum at the old Parliament House with the museum the responsibility of the Parliament through the Presiding Officers.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 6 1992-93 Efficiency audit—Auscript—Commercialisation of the Commonwealth Reporting Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the Auditor-General's report on Auscript and the commercialisation of the Commonwealth Reporting Service. I have expressed some concern about Auscript in the past and the way in which it appears that the predatory pricing of Auscript is starting to have a very serious effect on private sector court reporting and on reporting generally.

PARA.TAB: Last week in the Appropriations debate I mentioned that Auscript cost the taxpayer $6.8m in the last financial year and will cost the taxpayer $4.3m in 1992-93. It is interesting that the report is critical of several aspects of the process of what is, effectively, the semi-privatisation of Auscript. One of the key findings was that the activities contemplated in Auscript's strategic planning appear to be beyond the Commonwealth's constitutional powers. It is up to the Government to say what it is doing about this.

The questions I raised last week about predatory pricing have not been answered adequately. Senator Tate was handling this matter in the chamber last week, and he is in the chamber again today. It is time we asked about fairness and the subsidisation by the taxpayer of a service that will simply compete in the private sector. The following are the major findings:

SPEECH.PARA: there was ambiguity in broad direction and no clear statement of expected outcomes

there was no clear nexus between strategies and expected outcomes in the policy document. This emphasis on strategies could have resulted in uncontrolled and unpredictable outcomes from the process, and

the activities contemplated in Auscript's strategic planning appear to be beyond Commonwealth constitutional powers. In the opinion of the ANAO, Auscript should not operate under strategies that will, if successful, result in a breach of the Constitution.

My concerns remain those I have had right throughout Estimates and the Appropriations debate. Here we have another situation where the Commonwealth is placing itself directly in competition with the private sector on a very privileged basis. Let us face it: Auscript is not paying sales tax; it is not paying payroll tax; it is not paying a whole range of other taxes that private industry pays. Yet the private sector is now being regularly undercut by Auscript. The other day, Senator Tate said that that was not necessarily so. He said that it had been a matter of concern to Estimates committees over the years `because, quite frankly, the transition to the marketplace by Auscript has been far too slow'. It may have been far too slow, but what does that mean? Does it mean that Auscript should have carried out more predatory pricing at a faster rate and put some of these private companies out of business earlier than it will now obviously put them out of business?

PARA.TAB: This is a genuine concern. It is not just party politicking. This is a genuine concern for the future of these private companies, who have their own employees and who in some cases have financed their businesses over generations. The particular company in Western Australia to which I refer is a company that has gone from generation to generation. That company is now being undercut by Auscript at virtually every turn. That undercutting is being subsidised by the taxpayer. Yet the ultimate problem is that the employees of that private company will lose their jobs, effectively, on the taxpayer's subsidisation of Auscript.

I really do need to start getting some answers on what the Government plans to do about Auscript. Last week I tried to draw the attention of the Committee of the Whole in Appropriations to particular answers I had obtained to a series of questions with regard to Auscript. Those answers related to the billable hours of total pages transcribed over 1991-92 and to revenue and expenditure for that year. When the market rate of $25 per hour is applied to 68,193 billable hours, we get a total of $1.7m. But applying the market rate of $7 per page to 767,966 pages results in a total of $5.4m. In the absence of Auscript, the commercial sector would have done the same work at a cost of $7.1m. Instead, the actual revenue obtained by Auscript was $12.6m. The Minister might say, `There is a contradiction in what you are saying because you are talking about predatory pricing which, one would suspect, is undercutting on all occasions'. That might be true, but this distortion in quoting is also making life extremely difficult for these very experienced private sector companies.

It is not surprising that we do not have some of this material on the record, but I have now been asking for answers for a considerable length of time. I have been asking through Estimates and Appropriations, and now some of these general concerns have been highlighted in the Auditor-General's report. It is about time the Government gave us some answers on where Auscript is heading, how these private companies are expected to survive under the constant privileged pressure that Auscript is placing upon them, and whether Auscript will be totally privatised, with the Government saying, `If you want to be in that field, go in and survive on your own merits'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I believe it is very important for the Senate to pay particular attention to this belated, although satisfactory, response by the Government to the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards on telephone message services. It is particularly important to note that the Government has agreed with every one of the 12 recommendations made by the Committee, and through the work of AOTC these recommendations are being implemented.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators will recall, the AOTC annual report was tabled in this place on 11 November 1992. At that time several concerns were raised about the apparent laxity with which it seemed to be going about implementing the recommendations of the Committee. These recommendations called for the restriction of the content and advertising of adult telephone message services, which AOTC gave an undertaking to implement. Since that time, clarification of the matter has occurred and it appears that the Committee's intentions, which are shared by the AOTC, the Telephone Service Providers Association of Australia and now the Government, are being thwarted by a technical legal hitch.

Unfortunately, a rebel service provider, which is not a member of TELSPA, refuses to abide by the recommendations of the Committee which have been accepted by everyone else in the industry. This provider is called A.AA and it is flagrantly flouting the recommendations by advertising in People magazine in the manner which I outlined in the Senate on 11 November.

When AOTC tried to implement the recommendations and disconnect the services being advertised in the sexually explicit manner A.AA insisted upon, AOTC was forced to back down due to legal threats. Under the old contracts which the service providers were given by AOTC there was no muscle to enforce the adopted voluntary code of practice. It appears that stopping A.AA would involve a breach of contract and AOTC would be liable to pay damages. As the old contract is enforceable until 1996, I regard the current situation as unacceptable.

A.AA cannot be allowed to continue to flout the recommendations of the Committee, the Minister and this Parliament which clearly reflect what the community in general wants. The Government in its response today has agreed with every one of the proposals of the Committee. The Government applauds the rapid and voluntary adoption of the recommendations by AOTC and TELSPA. Unfortunately, this simply is not good enough.

A.AA is obviously a disreputable company which does not have the interests of the community in mind and in fact is acting irresponsibly. It cannot be allowed to continue to do so. AOTC must break the contract and pay damages if necessary. The current situation, where any child can see the 0055 number in People magazine, then pick up any telephone and dial this disgraceful service, cannot be allowed to continue until 1996.

AOTC should not have entered into the old style contract, anyway, as the provision to the general public of adult message services, with no controls on accessibility, was clearly in breach of Telecom's founding codes of conduct. As a result, it should wear the cost of entering into this contract and break the contract with A.AA to protect community standards in the area of telephone message services.

Similarly, the Government should immediately legislate to ensure that the recommendations of the Committee to which it has agreed have the full backing of the law. I commend the Government for agreeing with the Committee, but I now call on it to do something more substantial about seeing that these recommendations are enforced.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I support what Senator Tierney has said. The Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies, in its report on telephone message services, has considered these matters, and quite a number of people have been put at great difficulty in giving evidence to us. There has been great concern in the community about certain 0055 material. It has been of concern to AOTC because it wants to see its 0055 service intact and with integrity. The Government has now responded to our Committee's report. It has supported what we recommended. We now have one company, out of all the organisations, thumbing its nose at the community.

PARA.TAB: I agree with what Senator Tierney said. I believe that unless this matter is determined very quickly, within the next couple of weeks, the Government must legislate to ensure that the Committee's recommendations are adopted and enforced. At present AOTC is the only organisation playing ball because it is the only one providing these services, but there is now a competitor in the field. The legislation would be important so that that competitor would observe the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee which have now been endorsed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: IMPORTED FOOD CONTROL BILL 1992
The purpose of this Bill is to introduce point of entry inspection procedures for imported foods aimed at ensuring they meet Australian food standards.

Australia imports some $2 billion of food each year. The current system of imported food inspection, introduced from July 1990 under health provisions in the Quarantine Act, covers only around 10 per cent of this trade. It focuses on a small group of products assessed as high or medium risk in human health terms. It does not address the broader requirements of Australian food law.

All foods sold locally must comply with Australian food law as a precondition of their sale. In practice most imported foods are subject to little checking for this purpose, and then usually by occasional sampling from retail shelves by State and municipal authorities. However, domestic product also has to comply with a network of hygiene, production and environmental requirements before it reaches the shelves.

While some countries maintain broadly equivalent, effective control over their food production, others, who supply a significant proportion of our import trade, do not. Product from these sources can pose real risks. Allowing potentially risky food to reach our shop shelves before implementing control is clearly unsatisfactory.

The existing Imported Foods Inspection Program has found a significant incidence of non-compliance with food safety requirements in the products it covers. In its first year of operation, 8.4% of risk categorised foods failed for microbiological contamination, for the presence of mycotoxins, or for excessive levels of chemical residues. In the year just concluded the overall failure rate was 6.8%. These failure rates are, simply, too high.

There are continuing claims from a variety of sources that a much broader problem exists. Reports from domestic health authorities, some survey information, and claims from local consumer and various other groups suggest a significant rate of imported food non-compliance generally with Australia's food law requirements. While indications are that much of the non-compliance is not directly safety-related, being concerned with such matters as country of origin labelling, there are disturbing reports also of obvious deterioration, contamination by filth and foreign objects, and other defects including excessive levels of pesticides, heavy metals and use of illegal additives and preservatives.
There are claims too that product found unacceptable overseas has been redirected to the Australian market, exploiting our lack of general point of entry control.
The situation not only poses a risk to our consumers it also disadvantages local producers, who have to meet the costs of complying with our standards on a day-to-day basis.

The National Food Authority (NFA) whose role includes the issue of a wholesome food supply, has concluded there is sufficient concern to warrant extending point of entry monitoring to all imported foods to ensure the same safeguards are available as are required of local producers. The current Bill represents the outcome of work by the NFA and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to achieve a fair and equitable way of doing this.
The Imported Foods Control Bill aims at ensuring imported foods meet the same Australian food standards as local product. It will achieve this by

first, extending point of entry inspection coverage to all imported foods; the focus will remain on public health matters, but enforcement of other food standards requirements will be included in the scope of the inspection program

second, providing for AQIS to negotiate certification arrangements with overseas authorities where AQIS is satisfied that they operate equivalent production control arrangements to those we require of our own producers; this would largely obviate the need for inspection on arrival, although some inspection for auditing purposes would remain
third, providing for AQIS to negotiate quality assurance arrangements direct with overseas suppliers aimed at meeting Australian food law requirements.

The standards to apply to imported foods are those in the Australian Food Standards Code. General requirements of food safety will also apply. Risk assessment of particular food groups will remain the function of the National Food Authority and will be done on a sound and objective scientific basis. Foods not risk classified will be subject to surveillance monitoring. Monitoring intensity will reflect a food's compliance performance. Significant non-compliance may lead to the food being elevated to high or medium risk status.

Current arrangements, whereby high risk classified foods are withheld from release until results of analysis are obtained, and medium risk foods allowed release subject to possible recall will continue.

Other inspected foods will also be released once samples are taken. In many cases they will be subject only to visual inspection, particularly as compliance records are built up. There will be minimal clearance delays for these foods unless importers voluntarily hold product.
The new system will maintain and build on links with overseas food import authorities to ensure information exchange on products of concern and consistency of control approaches.

The new arrangements will involve, for the most part, the use of existing multi-skilled food inspection staff of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. It will add an estimated $4.5 million to current $2 million import inspection costs. These costs will still amount only to around a third of a cent for each dollar's worth of food imported, so the impact on consumer prices will be minimal. Offsetting this may be savings on costs States would face in mounting effective point of sale monitoring of imported foods to the extent they cut back on this activity—inspection at point of entry is, simply, much easier and more efficient—savings through a better control capability over defective product, savings through feedback from importers to their overseas suppliers focused on getting things right during production, and a potential reduction in health-related problems, caused by consumption of unsafe foods.
Costs of the system will be recovered from importers on a fee for service basis.

The system will overcome the problems inherent in a point of sale monitoring approach by different regional based bodies, including general difficulties in the coordination and uniformity of sampling, and possible redirection of product to another region if problems are found in the first, a practice known as "port shopping". It will also counter the many claims by local food producers that they operate at a competitive disadvantage where imports effectively do not comply with control requirements imposed on them.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

Mr President, this Bill follows on from the Territories Law Reform Act, which introduced major reforms to the legal regimes of the Indian Ocean Territories, Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands, with effect from 1 July 1992.

The Commonwealth's plans for the effective and efficient administration of the new legal regime depend in large measure on the continued co-operation of the Western Australian Government. It is pleasing to note the introduction of an Indian Ocean Territories (Administration of Laws) Bill into the Western Australian Parliament on 11 November 1992, which corresponds to the Territories Law Reform Act and provides for appropriate intergovernmental arrangements.
Mr President, this Bill makes minor technical amendments to the Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act, which have been requested by Western Australia, in the above context.

One particular amendment relates to the manner of application of Western Australian laws. The Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act currently provide that the provisions of the law of Western Australia are in force in each Territory, so far as they are capable of applying in the Territory. Western Australia has expressed concern about possible undesirable and unintended restrictions on the applicability of some Western Australian laws, arising from this formulation. This Bill will remove references to the applicability of Western Australia law. This will not substantially affect the laws currently in force in the Territory, but removes a possible doubt as to the validity of actions under applied laws.

Another group of amendments concerns the exercise of judicial and related powers under applied laws by Territory or State courts and court officers. The Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act currently deal differently with powers under applied laws which are vested in the courts and judicial officers of the Territories, and other powers, which are vested initially in the Commonwealth Minister administering those Acts. Provisions dealing with exercise of jurisdiction by the existing Territory courts will be repealed and replaced (by the Territories Law Reform Act) when jurisdiction in respect of the Territories is conferred on the courts of Western Australia (given suitable intergovernmental agreement).

Western Australia has sought a range of amendments of these provisions, to refer to "court officers rather than "judicial officers" (encompassing officers with primarily administrative functions but possibly some judicial attributes), and to be able to deal more comprehensively and consistently with the full range of courts and tribunals of the State.
The Bill will have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
