Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to limit the exposure of the public to advertisements for smoking and tobacco products, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to present the latest in a series of initiatives to reduce tobacco consumption in Australia. The problems caused by tobacco consumption cannot be denied and the Government can see no justification for promoting tobacco sales in any way.

This Bill will establish a national prohibition on tobacco advertising, expanding the existing bans in the broadcasting and print media and complementing the action of those States and Territories which have introduced their own restrictions on tobacco promotion.

The facts about the impact of tobacco on health in Australia are clear and stark. Tobacco is the major preventable cause of death and disease in Australia. In 1990 over 18 000 people died before their time because they smoked. In addition, smoking was estimated to present an annual cost to the Australian economy over $6.8 billion in 1988. Tobacco use is clearly a serious problem.

On the other hand, although smoking rates are declining from the extraordinary levels seen at the end of World War 2, some 28 per cent of adult Australians currently smoke. Thus, at least for the medium term future, it is not possible for the Government to simply make tobacco an illegal substance. Like powerful drugs, firearms and other legal, although dangerous, products, however, advertising of tobacco products should be severely limited. This is especially so when advertising has the effect, intended or otherwise, of persuading children to take up an addictive life-threatening habit.

To coordinate national action on the tobacco issue, the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments adopted the National Health Policy on Tobacco in March 1991. This policy recognises the need for a diverse range of measures to reduce tobacco related harm. Marketing, availability, taxation, education, passive smoking and cessation services are each separately addressed.

This Bill is the latest in a series of initiatives by this Government to reduce tobacco consumption in Australia. Achievements to date include a ban on smoking in Commonwealth buildings, a ban on tobacco advertising in the print media to extend the established broadcast media ban, a ban on smoking during airline flights and a ban on the sale of chewing tobacco and oral snuff.

In addition, the Government increased tobacco excise by over 10 per cent in the last Budget, leading to increased prices and reduced consumption. Furthermore, significant funding has been provided for education programs including the very successful `Smoking. Who Needs It!' campaign.

It is important to understand that removing tobacco advertising is primarily a prevention activity intended to reduce the number of children taking up smoking. Although advertising may not directly cause children to smoke, it reinforces other influences such as peer and social pressures which cause children to smoke. Tobacco advertisements glamorise smoking, making it seem like a desirable activity.

We are reminded by the recent decision of the High Court that free speech is a value fundamental to Australia. Serious consideration must therefore be given to any restrictions on free speech, including commercial free speech. However, tobacco advertising is a clear case of where restrictions on speech are appropriate in light of the need to protect the community's health, especially the health of its children.

Even if we accept the claim of the tobacco companies that their advertising is directed towards increasing market share, not recruiting new smokers, it is stretching credibility beyond its bounds to claim that this advertising has no effect on total consumption. Tobacco advertising supports and reinforces pressures to take up smoking and increases the difficulties encountered in quitting.

There is plenty of evidence to indicate that tobacco advertising increases tobacco consumption. A recent draft discussion paper released by the United Kingdom Department of Health used a variety of methods to examine the effect of tobacco advertising and reviewed existing research. One of the conclusions of this paper was that "the balance of evidence thus supports the conclusion that advertising does have a positive effect on consumption".

Research has also demonstrated the beneficial effects of tobacco advertising prohibitions such as those contained in this Bill. The same discussion paper examined the effect of advertising bans in several countries. On this matter, the paper concluded that "in each case the banning of advertising was followed by a fall in smoking on a scale which cannot reasonably be attributed to other factors".

Tobacco advertising in association with sport is particularly insidious as it seeks to link an unhealthy product with a healthy activity. Sponsorship of sporting and cultural activities has been exploited as an effective form of tobacco advertising. For example, a sponsor's name or logo may be recognisable for up to one third of the broadcast time of a major sporting event. One estimate is that a tobacco sponsored team received the commercial equivalent of over $4.5m worth of advertising during this year's Bathurst 1000.

This Bill will break the nexus between tobacco and sport and between tobacco and cultural activities. There can hardly be a more bizarre association than that between a product which is known to be a killer and the health giving nature of sport. This is especially so in the Australian context where sport is a vital part of our culture and where elite sportspeople are idolised, particularly by the young.

The Government has recognised that sporting bodies may need some time to find alternative sources of funding. Hence, the Bill will allow phasing out of advertising associated with sponsorship. The elite sports can be expected to find alternative commercial sponsors readily. The fact that a range of minor sports and small scale events, including in rural areas, will also need to seek support is a measure of the degree to which the tobacco dollar has penetrated sport and culture.

The Government commends Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory governments for having established health promotion foundations to provide alternative funding and commends these examples to the other States and Territories. If, however, these smaller sports and events do genuinely find it impossible to replace lost tobacco funding, the Government will consider subsidising some events following the transition period.

In recognition of the effect of tobacco advertising, the Commonwealth has already banned direct advertising in the broadcast and print media. Several States and Territories have banned various other forms of advertising and marketing. In particular, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales have all introduced legislation to limit tobacco advertising. This State and Territory legislation also addresses other marketing activities by, for example, banning tobacco related competitions and free samples.

Different regulations addressing tobacco advertising in each State and Territory have resulted in some difficulties with enforcement. For example, national activities have needed to be exempt and there has been ongoing problems with the venue for the 500cc motorcycle Grand Prix due to differences in the legislation between Victoria and New South Wales. Thus, a national advertising prohibition is required to ensure a comprehensive approach and one which minimises any disadvantage to a particular jurisdiction.

The international community is also increasingly introducing restrictions. Adoption of this Bill would move Australia from equal tenth to equal fifth in the OECD in terms of tobacco advertising restrictions.

The community expects the Government to act. The Government announced in April that it would ban tobacco advertising. Recently there has been a number of calls for the promised legislation to be introduced. Recently this call was renewed by the National Health and Medical Research Council, the principal medical advisory body to the Government.

The Bill will establish a complete ban on tobacco advertising to be phased in over the period 1 July 1993 to 31 December 1995. The major additional forms of tobacco advertising to be prohibited by this Bill are:
.advertising through sponsorship of sporting and cultural events (covering both naming of the event and publicity at the event);
.outdoor advertising such as on billboards or by illuminated signs; and
.the use of tobacco brand names, logos etc on non-tobacco products.
The maximum penalty for breaching the ban is $12 000 for an individual or $60 000 for a corporation.
This Bill removes the potential for tobacco advertising but not to the extent that extreme measures are taken:

.Accidental or incidental advertising for which the broadcaster or publisher does not receive any benefit will be permitted. For example, broadcasts of tobacco sponsored sporting events held overseas will not be affected by this Bill.

.International events to be held in Australia will be able to apply for an exemption from the ban. Such an exemption would be granted if the event has international significance and Australia would be likely to lose the event if the exemption was not provided.

.Point of sale advertising will not be eliminated. In those jurisdictions with point of sale legislation, the State or Territory rules will apply. In other jurisdictions, point of sale advertising (as defined by Commonwealth Regulations) will be permitted.
.Also, tobacco advertising in imported periodicals will be exempt so that these publications may continue to be available in the Australian market.

-The Bill contains sections which, if proclaimed, would permit the Minister to specify periodicals excluded from this permission. Should it appear that tobacco companies are exploiting this exemption, these sections will be proclaimed.

The Bill, in essence, prohibits the broadcast or publication of a tobacco advertisement. It will have the effect of setting a national standard for bans on tobacco advertising. The Bill does not preclude or limit application of a State or Territory law which might apply a stricter ban.

A tobacco advertisement includes any image or audio message which publicises or otherwise promotes any words or designs closely associated with tobacco products. This includes logos, brand names and manufacturer's names. Some material is specifically excluded from the definition of tobacco advertisement such as:
.labelling of cigarette packets;
.manufacturer's names on Company letterhead;
.advertisements for specified non-tobacco products with tobacco brand names; and
.anti-smoking advertisements.

The act of publishing a tobacco advertisement, in addition to incorporating it in a printed document, is defined in a wide sense to include displaying or selling something containing the advertisement. A tobacco advertisement is published if it is brought to the attention of the public, or a section of the public, in some way.
The Bill creates an offence for a tobacco advertisement to be published, unless the advertisement:
.is at the point of sale of tobacco products and complies with the Regulations;
.is contained in an imported periodical which is not principally intended for Australia;
.is associated with an exempt tobacco sponsored event of international significance and complies with any conditions attached to that exemption; or
.is accidental or incidental to the publication of other matter and where no benefit has been received by the publisher for publishing the tobacco advertisement.
In addition, an independent person is permitted to publish an advertisement on his or her own initiative (eg a person may wear clothing which has a tobacco advertisement on it).
Furthermore, persons publishing a tobacco advertisement in the following categories are exempt:
.advertising arising from sponsorship contracts established before 1 April 1992 which will be temporarily exempted until 31 December 1995; and
.billboard and other outdoor advertising established before 1 April 1992 which are provided for by a gradual phase out period until 31 December 1995.

The publishing offence does not apply to Norfolk Island. The Norfolk Island administration has indicated that it wishes to be excluded from the extension to the advertising bans. In accordance with the Commonwealth Government commitment to consult, given at the time of Norfolk Island independence, only the broadcasting offence will apply in Norfolk Island. The Bill has been constructed so that a person based in Norfolk Island will not be able to use this circumstance to publish a tobacco advertisement in Australia.

Should it be necessary to proclaim those sections of the Bill concerning specification of imported periodicals, it would be an offence to import a specified periodical which contains a non-incidental tobacco advertisement. However, importing for private use or exempt library use would be permitted.

Part 5 of the Bill amends the existing bans on tobacco advertising. The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 is amended so that it is consistent with the new bans. In addition, the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Act 1989 is repealed as the Bill incorporates the offences contained in that Act.

The ban on tobacco advertising will lead to reduced smoking rates. The effect on the tobacco industry (growers, manufacturers, importers etc) is expected to be gradual as the major impact of the ban will be a reduction in the number of children taking up smoking rather than a sudden increase in smokers quitting.

The outdoor advertising industry is also likely to be affected by the ban. In New South Wales and Queensland in particular, tobacco advertising provides a significant proportion of the income for several businesses involved in billboard and illuminated sign advertising. However, a gradual phase out of outdoor tobacco advertising in the Bill has been negotiated with the Outdoor Advertising Association of Australia.
.Regulations will establish different deadlines for categories of signs (eg small signs are to be removed by 1 July 1993) with all signs banned by 31 December 1995.
.Accordingly, the Outdoor Advertising Association has indicated that it does not oppose this Bill.

The time has come in Australia to end tobacco advertising. The passage of this legislation is among the most important health initiatives that can be taken by this Government. By supporting the trend away from smoking, it will make a major contribution to reducing illness and premature mortality amongst Australians.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to introduce amendments to the Pig Industry Act 1986, the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act 1977 and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985.

The Pig Industry amendments are designed to improve the effectiveness of the pig industry's statutory policy body in providing advice to Government and industry on issues affecting all sectors of the industry. Other minor amendments to the Primary Industry Councils Act, of an operational nature, are also proposed.

The amendments to the Meat and Livestock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation Acts enable levy motions put to annual general meetings of industry stakeholders to be passed on a simple majority on each of the appropriate registers, and no confidence motions passed by two-thirds of total votes cast with a minimum of 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register.

This Bill will establish the Australian Pig Industry Council under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 to replace the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council, which was established in 1987 under the Pig Industry Act 1986. This change gives the new Council enhanced powers and operational functions so that it can more effectively perform its role of coordinating and formulating industry policy. Also it will allow for funding of the Council by the Commonwealth Government.

Under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 industry councils are required to review and report on the strategic direction of the industry; to inquire into and report to the Minister on matters affecting the pig industry that the Council or the Minister consider warrant investigation or action; to convene industry review conferences; and to convene regular meetings of chairpersons of the other relevant statutory bodies in the industry.

The passage of the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 provided the catalyst for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to review the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council with the object of improving its effectiveness.

The review found that there was a need to clarify the Council's role and functions. It found a need to improve communication of the Council's work. It suggested that the Council needed to be financially independent, and that it should be staffed full time and located in Canberra. It recommended that there should be a minor adjustment to membership to better represent those with a direct investment in the industry, with associated interest groups being accommodated through working groups.

The review also concluded that the industry needed to take a more strategic approach to securing its future. At the moment only about one percent of domestic production is exported. Clearly, the future for the pig industry lies in developing an export orientation. The level of investment in technology in the industry needs to be increased, and greater efficiency and rationalisation in the processing sector achieved.
The review concluded that the Council would be in a better position to address these matters if it was brought under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991.

Under this Act provision is made for the establishment of a Council and the specification of its membership by amending the Schedule to the Act. This Bill adds the Australian Pig Industry Council to the Schedule and it is proposed that the new Council will begin its operations on 1 January 1993 or as soon as possible after that date.

Besides the Chairperson, membership will include three persons nominated by the Pork Council of Australia, one person nominated from each of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia and the National Processors Association, and the Chairpersons of each of the Australian Pork Corporation and the Pig Research and Development Corporation.

The anticipated operating costs of the Australian Pig Industry Council, which will be met by the Government, will be about $205,000 in a full year. The present Council is funded by industry levies paid to the Australian Pork Corporation. This arrangement is inconsistent with the principle of separating industry policy development from statutory marketing authority arrangements. Government funding will remove this dependency and will bring it into line with other industry council funding arrangements.

The Bill also provides for the termination of the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and establishes transition arrangements for the orderly transfer to the Australian Pig Industry Council. These arrangements ensure that all outstanding liabilities at the date of commencement will be met by the Australian Pork Corporation. There is also a provision for the old Council to continue beyond the date of commencement for the sole purpose of preparing and submitting a final annual report to Parliament.

The Bill also amends the Pig Industry Act 1986 to recognise the Pork Council of Australia as the eligible representative producer body for the purposes of Australian Pork Corporation accountability and membership of the Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee. The industry formed the Pork Council of Australia in March 1992 to supersede the Australian Pork Producers' Federation as the sole nationally representative body of pig producers.
The other amendment to the Primary Industry Councils Act provides for representation of the Food Committee of the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Limited on the Grains Industry Council.

At present the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Limited is represented on the Grains Industry Council by its Chairman, as provided for in Part 1 of the Schedule to the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991. After introduction of that legislation the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Limited established a Food Committee, the membership of which includes major producers of grain-based food products. It is more appropriate for this Committee, rather than manufacturers of grocery products generally, to be represented on the Grains Industry Council.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act 1977 and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 will change the requirements for passing motions at annual general meetings. Levy motions will now be passed on a simple majority on each of the appropriate registers. Currently it requires 75 per cent vote against a levy motion put by a Corporation for it to be overturned. No confidence motions will be passed by two-thirds of total votes cast. Additionally, at least 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register must be in favour of the motion.

The amendments will give effect to the Government's decision that levy motions at AGMs should be passed on a simple majority. This also has the support of the meat and livestock industry organisations.
The new arrangements will ensure that any successful no confidence motion, which represents a very serious step for the industry to take, is based on strong industry support.

In conclusion, this Bill will create an Australian Pig Industry Council that is responsive to the policy needs of the pig industry and is effective in coordinating policy input from all industry sectors to deliver an overall strategic policy direction for the benefit of the whole industry. In the case of the meat and livestock industry, AGM requirements give effect to both the Government and industry's desire to make voting requirements more democratic.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will acquaint the Senate with the story so far on this Bill. When we left off, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, and Senator Alston were earnestly considering whether they should support my amendment No. 5 to clause 3, page 7, which I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 3, page 7, at end of proposed section 102, add the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "(2)At the expiration of each period of 5 years commencing on the commencement of this Act, the ABA must conduct a review of the percentage of licence program expenditure mentioned in subsection (1).

SPEECH.PARA: This is an eminently sensible, reasonable and delightful amendment which I am sure I can convince everybody that they would love to accept. It does not actually say that one has to do anything except have a review. It just shows the public of Australia that we are looking after their best interests and that we are considering what is best for them and what is best for the industry. I really look forward to a bit of support on this one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment. It requires an ABA review every five years. The operation of the condition relating to Australian content is already subject to a legislative review that must be held before 1 July 1997. That provision is contained in section 215 of the Broadcasting Services Act. The Government does not see much point in legislating for two reviews in 1997. The Government accepts that a review at an appropriate stage is sensible, but we feel that there is only need to legislate for one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Considering that my eloquence did not move the Minister or Senator Alston, which I am shocked to see, I might take the rest of my amendments in a block, unless the Minister or Senator Alston wish to indicate to me that they would be willing to support any of them. I take it from the Minister's polite gesture that he is not willing to support any of them. I will just explain the amendments to the Senate once more while a few of my colleagues come in here to support me. My amendments Nos 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10 all support the idea that cross-media ownership rules should apply to both licences, both A and B. We believe that there are far too few people in Australia with far too much power as far as the ownership of our media—radio and television—is concerned. We think pay TV should be included in that. Licensee B should be under the same cross-media rules and foreign ownership rules as licensee A. Amendments nos 12 and 13 are on a different matter. Amendment No. 12 states:

SPEECH.PARA: 12.Clause 3, page 11, proposed paragraph 116(1)(a), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a)a subscriber management system is provided by them for use by the licence holders of subscriber television broadcasting services only where such a system is conducted by an autonomous business enterprise, distinct from any interest they may have as a service provider themselves; or".

SPEECH.PARA: 13.Clause 3, page 11, proposed subsection 116(2), line 14, insert "influence upon or" after "(whether directly or indirectly)".

This means that any licensee who sets up a subscriber management system would have to make it an autonomous business enterprise and could not run it in exactly the same way as he ran his channels. This amendment is worthy of support, too. In fact, I think they are all worthy of support. Unfortunately, they do not appear to be getting an awful lot of support. I can understand the Minister, the Opposition and, indeed, the Democrats—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even the Democrats.

—No, the Democrats support it. The Democrats are busy people, as the honourable senator knows. We all have about 100 portfolios. One of mine is transport and communications. Because I want to see us get through this legislation, and I know the Minister and the Opposition do, I seek leave to move my amendments in a block.

7.Clause 3, page 8, proposed section 106, line 13, after "licence A", add "and licence B".

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek a point of clarification. My amendment comes in before the last part of Senator Bourne's amendments. Do you want my amendment brought in before hers, or will her block go through and mine be dealt with later?
—I do not think there is a problem for Senator Walters if we dispose of Senator Bourne's amendments in one block. Then we would return to the balance of Senator Walters's amendments.
—We are dealing with clause 3. I think Senator Walters's amendment comes after clause 3. I will come to that in a moment. The question is that Senator Bourne's amendments be agreed to.

—With the greatest respect to the Democrats, the gravamen of these amendments is a bit much even for the Democrats. I do not think it is reasonable to totally and utterly exclude all of our own Australian broadcasters from any involvement whatsoever with both licences—
—I never said they should be.

—Yes, they would be. It is a bit much. I do not think we should treat our own Australian broadcasters as criminals. They are not. They actually have something to offer to this fledgling industry if we are to establish an Australian presence before we are totally overrun by foreign services on foreign satellites, and that is certainly on the way.

PARA.TAB: One of the positive aspects, in my view, of the involvement of the Australian television broadcasting industry in pay television is that it is a certain way to get an additional boost to Australian production put into pay TV. For that reason, as fundamentally as any other, we will not, regrettably, support the remainder of the Democrats' amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither are we.

—I do apologise to all Australian broadcasters: if any of them have gained the impression from what I said that I feel they are criminals, I do not. As I said before, I do feel that we could have a much broader representation of the Australian community in pay TV. Regretfully, I accept that nobody is going to support this amendment.

—I suppose we are all concerned about the question of cross-media ownership. If we are going to see a situation develop, as is envisaged and forecast by some of the experts in this field, where in 15 years' time free to air television will have a negligible impact and pay TV will be the key area in the television field, then clearly we ought to be looking more closely at cross-media ownership. I believe that we are going to end up with a situation in Australia whereby the provisions that currently apply in respect of free to air television and the press media—the cross-media ownership provisions—will then not apply, even though at that stage pay TV will have taken over virtually from free to air television.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether these people are right in their assumption that pay TV will be so substantial and influential in 15 years' time; I have not a clue whether they are correct. But I think we should now consider legislation with the view that this might be the case in 15 years. Once it comes, there will be few cross-media ownership rules in respect of pay TV and media ownership as they exist at the present moment. I would be happy to be corrected if the Minister would like to do so—and I am sure he would be delighted to correct me on that.

I do not have a clue whether they are correct or not. Obviously, there are people with that view who are experts in this field. Bearing in mind the definition of `expert'—X denotes the unknown quantity and a spurt is a drip under pressure—I do not know that we should take a great deal of notice of them. But these people are in the field. They are paid to do the job of forecasting what will be the case in 15 years' time, 10 years' time, seven years' time, five years' time, and they are paid to do so by people with money who have investments in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, I do not think anybody could confidently correct Senator Harradine or, as he himself has suggested, even agree with him. I think it would be impossible. It would be a very brave prediction indeed as to what level of penetration pay TV will have in the Australian market. I have to say in that sense that I think Senator Harradine's estimate would be as good as anyone else's, and so would mine. My own view is that, on the most optimistic scenario that is painted for pay television, I would be very surprised indeed if it would get a much greater share of the market within the next five years than its own projections indicate. That certainly would indicate a situation where free to air would substantially still be dominating the Australian landscape.

PARA.TAB: For what my view is worth, and it is worth no more than anyone else's, I would be very surprised indeed if the scenario Senator Harradine paints, which may well be held by some people, occurs before the end of my lifetime. Of course, that may well be the middle of next week; I do not know. If this pay TV debate never finishes, it probably will be. It seems to have been going on for the whole of my life. Seriously, I have a contrary view. For the next 10 to 15 years, I think it is reasonably safe to assume that free to air services will continue to dominate the majority of television reception in Australia.

I do not think it is sensible or reasonable for parliaments to try to predict that far ahead. It will be very much a question for the parliament of the day. We are legislatively planning—it is contained in the Act—for a complete review of the industry by 1997; that is in five years. I think that is as much as any parliament could reasonably expect. There will be a comprehensive review of the entire television industry at that time, and I have no doubt at all that at that time there will be a very substantive debate in this chamber. Whether Senator Harradine or I are here to participate in it is something neither of us can predict at this stage. However, we have already legislated in the Act for a comprehensive review of the entire industry, including pay television, in 1997. I think that is about as far ahead in this world as we could safely plan for.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bourne's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to this Bill; and I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendment to be moved to the Radio Communications Bill 1992.
—With the concurrence of the Committee, we will consider Government amendment No. 1 and the additional amendment to be moved on behalf of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 6, proposed section 100, add at the end of the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(5) The ABA must impose a condition on all subscription television broadcasting licences requiring each licensee to make available, as an option, domestic reception equipment on a rental basis.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 6, add at the end of proposed section 100 the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(6) The ABA must impose a condition on all non-satellite subscription television broadcasting licences requiring that, if a licensee rents domestic reception equipment to a consumer, the rental agreement must allow the consumer to terminate the agreement on giving one month's written notice to the licensee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's amendments, which I am sure will be welcomed and supported by all senators, are to add to the consumer protection measures contained in the amendment Bill and to ensure that opportunities are provided for the Australian drama production industry, irrespective of the delivery technologies used for pay TV.

PARA.TAB: Clause 1, as amended, requires the Australian Broadcasting Authority to impose on all subscription television broadcasting licences a licence condition requiring them to provide domestic reception equipment on a rental basis rather than just for purchase. This will provide consumers with protection from changes in technology, services not living up to expectations or services failing. To stop people being caught with unsatisfactory rental arrangements, or being locked into a service that does not deliver what it promised, the Government will require that consumers renting non-satellite equipment can terminate a rental agreement for pay TV on one month's written notice.

The Government recognised when it mandated digital technology for satellite that this technology is the way of the future. We all know that analog technology is on its way out and digital technology is on its way in. Indeed, as was made clear by AOTC when I was in Wollongong the other day to launch the fibre-optic trial which will involve pay television services in Wollongong, the full intention of all of the people who will be involved in cable fibre optics will be to go to digital on all of the services that they provide.

Digital technology is a path to high definition television, wide aspect ratio television—that is, cinemascope on TV—multiple channels and potentially broadband services to the home on satellite to compete with cable. Other technology, such as MDS, may provide some useful transitional paths and will definitely provide a range of narrowcasting services, for which MDS is particularly suited. These will involve such things as ethnic movie channels and, in particular—and I know there will be a wide demand for these services—educational services on subscription television provided by narrowcast. That kind of technology, which not only is currently available in Australia but the equipment on which it is delivered is manufactured in Australia, is ideally suited for this role and not so well suited for the broadcast delivery of pay television.

At the end of the day, we do not want any financial impediment for consumers to move to a better technology. People may determine in the interim, before digital is available, that they may want to use MDS, which in most circumstances does not provide a signal of comparable quality with digital satellite delivery.

We are legislating to ensure that consumers are protected, so that, if consumers do avail themselves of this opportunity, they will have the option of renting or leasing the equipment, rather than buying it. They will then suffer no impediment when the better technology is available and they can simply move to that technology without being stuck with $400 or $500 worth of hardware which is no good to them.

On equity grounds, clauses 2 and 3 extend the new Australian drama production requirement to all subscription television broadcasting services, not just those using satellite as a means of delivery. I am sure this is something all senators will support. It will add to the requirements that originally were only placed on satellite subscription television broadcasting services in the amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the Minister will be very pleased to hear that we do indeed support and applaud the Government's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition also supports the Government's amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Amendments (Senator Collins's)—by leave—agreed to:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 3, page 7, proposed section 102, line 2, omit "satellite".
3.Clause 3, page 7, proposed section 102, line 3, omit "satellite".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 3, page 11, add the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "4. Section 128 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Standards and codes to be amendable by the Parliament

PARA.TAB: (a)either House of the Parliament agrees to an amendment of a standard or code of practice which has been determined or registered in accordance with this Part; and
(b)the other House agrees to that amendment of the standard or code of practice;

SPEECH.PARA: the standard or code of practice has effect as amended by that amendment from the day on which that other House agrees to the amendment.

PARA.TAB: `(2)If notice of a motion for an amendment to a standard or code of practice is given in a House, and within 15 sitting days of that House after the notice has been given:
(a)the notice has not been withdrawn and the motion has not been called on; or
(b)the motion has been called on, and moved and has not been withdrawn or otherwise disposed of;

SPEECH.PARA: the amendment specified in the motion shall then be taken to have been agreed to by that House.

PARA.TAB: `(3)If a House agrees to an amendment, in accordance with subsection (1), or is taken to have agreed to an amendment pursuant to subsection (2), to a standard or code of practice, and the other House does not, within 15 sitting days of that other House, agree or disagree to the amendment, or propose a further amendment, the standard or code of practice has effect as amended by the amendment agreed to, or taken to have been agreed to, by the first-mentioned House from the expiration of that time.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is an amendment to section 128 of the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992. It is not intended at all to be a political point-scoring measure. It is intended as a helpful measure so that, in the end, Parliament will be able to have some say over a situation which could result in widespread concern amongst the community in respect of television standards determined by the ABA and codes of practice developed by the industry.

PARA.TAB: It is generally agreed that commercial television, indeed television in general, has a very significant impact on the development of attitudes and community standards. Thus, it seems to me that if that particular area is not able in any way to come before this chamber, the situation needs to be remedied.

Having regard to the Government's deregulatory intention, I consider that it would be inappropriate for me to suggest at this stage that all of the codes of practice developed by the industry, and indeed the standards determined by the ABA, should automatically be tabled before this Parliament and automatically be the subject of consideration by this Parliament. If one took an opposite view to that of the Government and of the Opposition in this area, one would have drafted this differently. One would have drafted this measure so as to require the ABA to table in the Senate its determinations, and to table

SPEECH.PARA: those codes of practice which it registers and which were developed by the industry within, say, 15 days. They would then be the subject of disallowance, approval or disapproval by the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.

—I will come to that in a moment. I am talking in general terms about the codes of practice and I am talking also about the standards. What the Minister is talking about is the provision in section 128 in the legislation that at present requires the standards that are determined by the ABA, pursuant to sections 122 and 125, to be tabled and to be subject to disallowance. I am proposing to change that in such a way that if people are concerned, they will make their concerns known to senators and to members of the House of Representatives. They make their concerns known to us only too well.

PARA.TAB: If there is a glaring area of concern in respect of those matters which the ABA must determine, namely under section 122 relating to programs for children and the Australian content of programs, and if this concern is sufficiently developed and mature, we should be able at that stage to move amendments to those provisions.

At present in regard to programs for children and Australian content, the ABA need only table those and the Parliament has only a disallowable function, and it cannot amend. If, for example, the ABA developed a standard in respect of children's television which dealt, for example, with the types of educational programs that are appropriate for children of various age groups, and if there were a great deal of concern about one particular aspect of that standard, then the Senate and the House of Representatives could not deal with that particular aspect, but would have to disallow the whole standard. I do not think that is appropriate, and I believe that this gives the flexibility which is desirable for the Parliament to have.

In regard to codes of practice which are developed by the industry, my amendment would again not require those codes of practice to be tabled before the Parliament for automatic determination by the Parliament. My amendment simply makes provision for the Parliament to consider questions as they arise from time to time. They may arise from time to time by virtue of interpretations, for example, that the Australian Broadcasting Authority may make in respect of its own standards and also relating to the codes of practice after a complaint has been lodged. Those interpretations may vary from time to time, and over a period of time may not truly reflect what the industry as a whole, or indeed what viewers, expected. At that time that the Parliament could come into its own, a notice of motion could be moved and consideration could be given to that matter.
I have been quite deliberate in the way that I have developed this amendment. The amendment which is before the chamber says:

TAB.TAB: If:
(a)either House of the Parliament agrees to an amendment of a standard or code of practice which has been determined or registered in accordance with this Part; and

(b)the other House agrees to that amendment of the standard or code of practice, the standard or code of practice has effect as amended by that amendment from the day on which that other House agrees to the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: So it will not be a situation where only one House of the Parliament decides the issue. In effect, it will require the support of the Party, whichever one is in power, that has the numbers in the House of Representatives. That means that the issue would be of such major concern in the public arena as to require its consideration and resolution by the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: In my view, that probably would not occur all that often. It may occur more often while this system of deregulation is settling in, but in the long term it probably will not occur very often. Why do I say that? Because if there is some concern that an individual member of parliament is approaching these areas in a manner which is not broadly consistent with the views of his or her colleagues, there would be a 15 sitting day delay, as per paragraph 2 and paragraph 3, in one House and a 15 sitting day delay in the other. In total, that would mean delay over a period of about six months. If the matter is of great concern, the industry ought to get its act together within that six-month period.

I believe that this provision is quite reasonable. The measure ought to go into the legislation in any event, but it is a measure which the Government might wish to utilise in respect of its present discussions with the industry. For example, if the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister were in discussions with the industry and at the end of the day there was no agreement by the industry to deal with particular issues, the Government may wish to utilise this measure. It could very well be quite a handy way of dealing with the matter.

I believe that my measure has regard to the general deregulatory policy that has been adopted by the Government and the Opposition in respect of this matter; it has regard to the responsibility of the television industry to develop codes of practice; and it has regard for the statutory obligations which are imposed on the Australian Broadcasting Authority to determine particular standards. It also has in mind that members of the public would feel cheated if, at the end of the day after all has been said and done, the Parliament is powerless to deal with this major question of public concern.

Therefore, I submit the proposal to the Committee. I acknowledge that it does not cover the ABC and the SBS. I hope that that difficulty is overcome in the other House or in some other way. The Minister might have some suggestion on that point. I did not deal with the ABC and the SBS in my amendment because I did not think it would be supported. But, having regard to what the Minister said last night—that it was the Government's intention to ensure that program standards and classifications would apply also to the SBS and the ABC—which came as a bit of a welcome surprise to me, the Government at some stage might consider what amendment is needed to ensure that the ABC and the SBS are covered.

At the Senate Select Committee hearing today, the Managing Director of FACTS considered it rather discriminatory if we were to pursue a particular line with the commercial television broadcasters and not with the ABC and the SBS. I repeat: my amendment is intended to be helpful. I ask the members of the Government or any other senator, when considering it, to show me where it is not helpful and not consistent with the policies that have been advanced by both the Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an appalling amendment that substantially removes one of the greatest strengths from the brand new broadcasting regime which, with overall support from almost everybody within and without the industry, was given to it. It has been couched in very reasonable terms by Senator Harradine in the way in which he has presented it to the Committee. I understand, to my total astonishment, that it will be carried in the Committee because it will be supported by the Opposition—and I seriously say `astonishment'. I cannot honestly believe that the Opposition could sensibly support this measure.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that the Opposition has considered the way in which this proposal will be used. Senator Harradine said that it may be used from time to time. I guarantee him right now, having regard to the way this chamber is presently constituted, that it will be used again and again, and again and again. But that is not really the major objection to it.

I do not think that people simply appreciate just how substantially this amendment removes the philosophical basis on which the deregulated regime—the arm's-length regime that we set up with proper parliamentary scrutiny, as Senator Harradine acknowledged at the end of the day, under section 128—has been properly achieved. Frankly, it is a classic example of how the politics of this debate have fundamentally overwhelmed completely a rational treatment of broadcasting standards in this country.

This amendment fundamentally gives the Parliament a power that it already has—that is, a power to make law. As I just said a few moments ago, I believe that it fundamentally compromises the proper arm's-length position of broadcasting and politics, the independence of the regulator—the Australian Broadcasting Authority—and the Government. I am pleased that the Government was widely applauded. It carefully considered the appointment of the constituent members of that authority as people who had a wide understanding of the community and the industry with all the public consultation in which it is, by legislative requirement, required to engage. This amendment destroys that arms-length approach of politics to broadcasting regulation. It takes away from the ABA its power over these standards. It fundamentally weakens—and I mean fundamentally weakens—the new body that we have just established.

It is an underlying principle of the Broadcasting Services Act, which has been widely applauded, that the regulation of broadcasting be carried out by the Australian Broadcasting Authority on behalf of the Parliament, with certain parliamentary oversight, such as program standards. It makes a mockery of the concept of supervised, guided industry self-regulation and allows the industry to wriggle out of its responsibilities to take full account, in the first instance, of community standards.

The industry will simply say, `Why should we bother doing this. Parliament has taken over the right to make standards on a regular basis and it has supplanted the ABA on a regular basis?'. We should have no doubt about the fact that it will be used on a regular basis, despite the soft words. The industry will say, `Fine, we go back to being a totally regulated body by Parliament'—a very inappropriate agency to actually carry out this kind of regulation on this kind of basis—`and we will simply let Parliament make the laws or not make the laws'. If people are unhappy at the end of the day, I suppose they will blame the Parliament.

If this proposal is passed, all of the matters—Australian content, children's programs and so on—can constantly be challenged. I put this on the record because it will happen for negative as well as for positive reasons. There is no question that this will occur. It will create an enormous degree of uncertainty in an industry which has only just received the new regime—the total overhaul of the Act—in a compromise. It has been a balance between an independent regulator that is at arm's length from politics. It is totally publicly accountable in everything it does and is subject to parliamentary oversight. There is the traditional oversight of the Senate in making a disallowable instrument if Parliament fundamentally disagrees in a substantive way with the standards that the authority is making.

However, to set up Parliament to supplant that role on a regular basis and actually create the standards—indeed, to make them in here—fundamentally and totally destroys one of the central tenets of the deregulated organisation that we have just set up, with great support from the industry. I say again that the reason we are in this position fundamentally is because the politics of the current climate in which all this is being generated has totally overtaken any rational consideration of the full repercussions of this measure. It certainly will be used. It is unprecedented in Australian, United Kingdom, Canadian and United States' broadcasting regulations. Those overseas regulations contain nothing like it.

The Broadcasting Services Act rightly gave Parliament scrutiny of program standards by making them disallowable instruments under section 128 of the Act. That is the proper, independent arm's length approach. It is the correct balance that should be struck between this brand-new authority with this new less regulatory approach to the industry, whilst at the end of the day maintaining the proper parliamentary role in disallowing something that Parliament felt was grossly excessive. This will provide this chamber at least with an endless opportunity—and it will be used endlessly—to set itself up in place of the Australian Broadcasting Authority.

I indicate that the Government is fundamentally opposed to this amendment. It strikes at the very heart of what we thought was an extremely good regime of arm's length regulation of the industry. We feel strongly enough about it to divide on it. The reason I indicate that—I did so privately to Senator Alston and Senator Harradine—is that in the event we will not be dividing on it for the simple reason that we are trying to save the Senate time. But I do not want that lack of a division at the end of the debate to be taken as any indication of the Government's fundamental opposition to the effect that this amendment will have and the way in which it will fundamentally strike down what we felt was an excellent balance between a brand-new authority, a completely revamped set of regulations after 50 years, and a proper arm's length role of politics from broadcasting regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a lecture on the evils of parliamentary democracy. With about two minutes of the Minister's speech to go, I had a bet with myself that Senator Collins, having used the word `fundamentally' at least half a dozen times, would almost certainly use it once more in that time. He excelled himself; he used it three times. It is a classic example of the dangers of hyperbole—in other words, the currency becomes debased.

PARA.TAB: In regard to Senator Harradine's proposition, we do not want to see this Parliament being distracted on a regular basis and dealing with trivial, frivolous and capricious proposals that might reflect a minority view. We want to try to reflect community attitudes and views that sometimes get lost in the process of bureaucracy. We could not have a better example of that than to look at the question of violence on television. We have had standards authorities in this country for many years, and one would have thought that they would have got it basically right. But ever since we started talking about this whole problem and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in a fit of macho aggression thought that he would trot out the 9.30 p.m. proposition, it has been a very hot topic.

The fact that Mr Keating has walked away from that does not contradict the proposition one iota. What we saw in today's Newspoll was a very strong indication of public feeling on the issue. We find that 72 per cent of Australians regard AO programs with a high level of violence as not appropriate in current viewing hours and that they ought to be restricted to being shown after 9.30 p.m. How do we have standards authorities, bureaucracies and the like on the one hand supposedly doing the job of protecting public standards and, on the other hand, the public itself saying, `You got it fundamentally wrong'? If the public cannot have a say through Parliament, we have come to a pretty poor pass.

If the Minister is not aware of the dangers of capture of regulatory authorities by special interest, it is about time we tried to interpret these sorts of findings in a more rational way than seems to operate in the Government's decision-making processes. We would not allow this mechanism to be used to rewrite the rules. We would not allow it to cause untold double tracking and double guessing at vast expense to the management. We would not want to see television proprietors and others being put to vast expense to satisfy the whims of individuals in this Parliament. But that is not what I expect to happen. If it does, we would act to stop it.

However, we ought to be alive to the concerns that are often reflected in this chamber that are out of step with what the Government thinks is in the best interests of the community. If ever there was an outfit that indulged itself on a regular basis in that sort of deception, it is the current Government. Time and again it tells us that whilst we might not appreciate the virtues of superannuation, we are going to have it. It says, `Whether or not it means that your salary will be reduced, we are going to impose it on you'. We can find numerous examples of where the Government thinks it knows best. That is really what this is all about.

Therefore, we reject the Minister's snide insinuations that somehow the sky will fall in and we will spend all of our time in this chamber doing nothing but responding to frivolous attempts to amend the rules. Those rules will still be the responsibility of others outside the Parliament. It will require both Houses of Parliament—it is no mean feat and is certainly not very common to have one party in control of both Houses—to effect any change.

The Government can run as many scare campaigns as it likes on this and any other issue in the run-up to the election, but this will have the same success as its current efforts will have. Commonsense will prevail and people will appreciate that these sorts of mechanisms, if used sensibly, can make a very valuable contribution to reflecting community views. If they are abused, there will inevitably be a reaction and we will find a majority view in both Houses being prepared to restrict that democratic access.
It is appalling to me that Senator Collins should go over the top in such a way that he has to use the word `fundamental' every couple of minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to use the words `over the top' once more in this debate, Senator Alston?

—Senator Collins had better tell me how many times I have used them. I hoped I had not transgressed. It is not my intention to try to match him in hyperbole, but simply to say that if he looks at this rationally, he ought to be able to see the merits of it; and if it gets out of control down the track, let us have a talk about it then.

—The Democrats will be supporting Senator Harradine's amendment. I believe the Minister to be quite genuine in his worries about this, but I also believe that Senator Harradine is quite genuine in putting it up and I do not believe it will cause the doom and destruction that has been predicted. I certainly hope not. If it does, as the Minister has told us, there will be a full review of all this legislation. When that review takes place—or even before, if this does cause an absolute disaster in this place—we would well and truly be open to seeing it being amended or changed. At the moment, we see it as a step forward for parliamentary scrutiny. We are going very much along the deregulation line in all areas of government and parliament in this country, and we would rather see us slow down a bit on that track. We see this as a very valuable contribution in that direction.

—The Minister starts his hyperbole again: `We are setting a precedent. Never done before in this place. Never done anywhere else in the world'. He keeps telling us how both my amendment and Senator Harradine's are fundamentally flawed. I think it is setting a precedent for regulations. I think it would be a fantastic idea if Senator Harradine were to introduce this sort of thing into regulations too, because, quite frankly, we have great concern about not being able to amend regulations. This would make us able to amend regulations.

PARA.TAB: For Senator Collins to say that this would create the situation where the matter was coming up time and again, and again and again, is absolute rubbish, because it would have to be so serious that it would have to be agreed by both Houses, and the Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Opposition would not be keen on putting up frivolous suggestions that they know darned well would be defeated in the lower House.

Senator Collins said that it would upset the arm's length situation. He has already informed us very clearly today that the Government intends to regulate the situation on standards; that the Government intends to pass legislation; that even though the commercial television stations did not agree with this, they were going to be big and strong and everything else and were going to regulate for this. There is no longer the arm's length situation that he referred to about self-regulation. So of course I support Senator Harradine's amendment. As I said, I think it can go further than it does under this Bill. I think it is setting a precedent that we should look at very carefully for other situations in the Senate where we are unable to amend regulations, for example.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the matter raised by the Minister, I must say that I was a bit shocked when he got up and said that this was an appalling measure. I really was shocked about that. In my view, coming from my philosophical basis, I would have made it very much stronger, but I gave instructions about this particular measure having regard to the deregulatory policy of the Government and the Opposition, and I believe I have met that standard.Of course, I cannot impose my philosophical views in respect of these measures on this chamber, let alone the other chamber, but the instructions that I gave were to retain intact the philosophical approach of both the Government and the Opposition in respect to broadcast television.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to focus on the points that the Minister made. He indicated that this measure could be used again and again by persons within this Parliament in an attempt to change the codes of practice developed by the industry or the standards determined by the ABA. That is just not so. If the Minister looks at paragraphs (2) and (3) of my amendment, he will see that the amendment clearly indicates that this cannot be done if it is the view of the majority of persons in either House of the Parliament.

For example, if I were to give a notice of motion next week for consideration of a particular program standard which the ABA has, in the interim, determined under the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, it could take until March of next year, if the Government did not want to call it on, for this Senate chamber to consider it. Indeed, the Government need not bring it on. Of course, if it did not bring it on, the motion would be deemed to have been carried and would go to the House of Representatives. So we are up to March. Come March, we have 15 sitting days in the House of Representatives. By that time, we will probably be in an election period, and it will be August before the matter would be determined by the Parliament. By that time, if public opinion were so developed and vocal about a particular matter—say, violence on TV—the industry, surely, would have had time to get its act together.

The Minister's next point is that it totally removes the deregulatory regime. Well, it does not do that. He says that behind the deregulatory regime is a requirement of the industry to take full account of community attitudes, and that this motion will weaken that. Well, it does not do that. I point out to the Minister that section 123 of the legislation requires the industry to develop codes of practice, and requires the industry to have regard to community attitudes in respect of a number of matters in the development of those codes of practice. That is a requirement of the legislation.

Is the Minister saying that just because this amendment goes in, FACTS will transgress the legislation? Certainly not. If there were some narrower time limit, I could understand that it might say, `Oh, well, we will develop those and throw them over and see who brings it up in the Parliament'. I do not think it would do that. Having regard to the times involved in this particular measure, there will be plenty of time for the industry to reconsider its position.

The Minister says that there needs to be a proper arm's length approach in the broadcasting legislation. What I am proposing is far less of an interference than is being proposed, I respectfully suggest, by the Minister and the Government at present, and I feel a bit miffed to have that sort of comment made about my amendment.

I have pointed out that there is widespread public concern over certain programs on certain television networks—not all—which broadcast unacceptable themes, depictions of violence and `sexploit' material. I agree with that, and obviously the Prime Minister is also concerned. It is his intention to pursue that matter. Furthermore, it is the intention of the Opposition, the Democrats and myself to pursue that matter and, of course, it is also the Minister's intention. What I am proposing is not a measure that will give the Parliament an automatic interfering approach in these particular matters.

I appeal to the Minister to recognise that I have not included in this provision the requirement that the matters have to be tabled in the Parliament within 15 days. When the viewing public complain to members of Parliament and there is sufficient response, surely in those circumstances members of Parliament have some recourse. Surely they have some ability to express the concerns of viewers in their electorates. Unless we take this measure on board, we will not be able to do that. We will have bound ourselves forever into a situation where we will be unable to express the viewpoints of the electors as to program content on commercial television in an effective manner.

The Minister says that the ABA fundamentally weakens the new body. I would like to know how it does so. What are the powers of the new body contained in the Broadcasting Services Act under Part 9 relating to program standards? The powers of the body—the ABA—include determining standards that are to be observed by television broadcasting licensees and community broadcasting licensees. How is that to be done? Standards which it is required to determine relate to programs for children and the Australian content of programs. Under the existing Act, those particular standards must be laid before the Parliament for its consideration if it wants to disallow them.

I am not interfering with that. I am not suggesting there has to be a disallowance provision that knocks everything out—even the good parts of a standard which has been determined by the ABA. I am saying that if the ABA has determined standards which in general are regarded as satisfactory, let us deal only with the area that is unsatisfactory. I cannot see that that is weakening the body at all; it is probably supporting its particular standards where they are seen to be generally acceptable.
So far as the other requirements of the ABA are concerned, section 123(4)(b) of the Broadcasting Services Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the ABA is satisfied that:
(i)the code of practice provides appropriate community safeguards for the matters covered by the code; and
(ii)the code is endorsed by a majority of the providers of broadcasting services in that section of the industry; and
(iii)members of the public have been given adequate opportunity to comment on the code;
the ABA must include that code in the Register of codes of practice.

What does the phrase `appropriate community safeguards' mean? Sometimes these are interpretations which might be appropriate at a particular stage but not at other stages. Once the ABA has registered the codes, there is nothing it can do about them. In those circumstances I cannot see where the ABA has the power to revoke a code of practice. It does not have that power. It has power to revoke its own standards, but once it registers those codes it cannot do a damn thing about it.

PARA.TAB: My amendment does not interfere at all with the powers of the ABA and would not fundamentally weaken that new body. Without further ado, I suggest that it is not an appalling measure. It simply provides at the end of the day—and perhaps at the end of the year—a backstop for the community to have its say, provided there is support by both chambers of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly, more than anything else as a courtesy to Senator Harradine. I will not go over all the issues which I have canvassed in debate on other occasions. I am aware of the differences between the drafts. I had a conversation with the Clerk at the table a few moments ago about this amendment—simply in an academic sense. I think it is an extremely well-drafted amendment.

PARA.TAB: As a former Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I appreciate the care that has been taken with the drafting and execution of this amendment in terms of accomplishing what has been clearly enunciated in the Senate. I acknowledge that there is no question at all that if Senator Harradine wanted to exercise his personal views on the matter, he would certainly have taken this measure much further than he has.

I conclude by saying that I have an inherent distaste for passing unnecessary law. I think we do far too much of that. I make that point because I want to end as I began, by saying that that is my fundamental objection to this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a fundamental one; that's good to hear.
—I am not embarrassed about that word, as Senator Alston obviously is about his overuse of the expression `over the top'.

PARA.TAB: The point that Senator Harradine made is the very point that I made at the beginning of the debate. Senator Harradine said, absolutely correctly, that the legislative measures that we will shortly have before us in respect of what we view on our broadcast television screens at night are certainly far more intrusive than what is being proposed by Senator Harradine. That is the very point I made at the beginning of the debate.

I do not believe this legislation is necessary for the simple reason that it gives Parliament a power to do what it already has power to do—that is, to make laws. Senator Harradine talked rightly about getting representatives from the community. He talked about these extreme circumstances where community concern was so great, as it has been—and I acknowledge it—in respect of violence. Indeed, it has been so great that parliamentarians have got a right to intervene. Of course no independent body—whether it be the ABA, a statutory authority, a GBE or whatever one wants to call it—can ever supplant the sovereign role of this Parliament. Indeed, we will be demonstrating this shortly in respect of these standards with legislation which is far more intrusive than that which Senator Harradine is suggesting.

I simply make the point that, at the end of the day, Parliament already has this power. If Parliament feels strongly enough—I use the word `Parliament' because Senator Harradine's amendment talks about both Houses, not just the Senate—about a particular measure related to broadcasting, program standards or anything else, it has the power, as we will demonstrate shortly, to make laws to that effect.
Amendment agreed to.
