DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INVESTMENT) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it for debate the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Foreign Investment) Bill 1992. An earlier Bill ran into so much criticism some months ago that the Government sought comment from an overseas tax consultant, Professor Brian Arnold, from the University of Western Ontario in Canada. Professor Arnold is a well-known and respected expert in the field of international tax law. Professor Arnold released to the Government his independent review in August. He came up with 52 different recommendations. The Government, in response, subsequently agreed to 37 changes. While some major problems for industry have been allayed by the new amended Bill, some of the outstanding concerns, I remind the Senate, are still of the Government's own making.

PARA.TAB: Following Professor Arnold's independent review, a new Bill was introduced by the Government on 3 November. This was for a commencement date of 1 January 1993. This is hardly sufficient time for consultation on the technical aspects of the Bill and for industry to establish the necessary systems to cope with the foreign investment fund measures.

I would like to encourage my colleagues in the Government to adopt a proposal that was suggested by Professor Arnold in his presentation—that the tax industry itself should have a greater role in the formulation of tax policy and legislation. Under this proposal, input would result not only from those who receive the revenue from taxation, but from those people who actually have to work with the legislation on a daily basis.

The Bill before the Senate today implements the Government's 1991-92 Budget announcement to complete the third element of its tax reform agenda to develop a comprehensive system for taxing foreign source income. The first element, as we know, of this agenda was the foreign tax credit system which, from the income year 1987-88, replaced the general exemption in Australia of income earned offshore and subjected to foreign tax. The second element was the introduction of the controlled foreign company and foreign trust rules which took effect from the income year 1990-91.

The measures in today's second reading debate address the tax deferral issue where entities are used to shelter income from Australian tax by accumulating it in low tax or tax free jurisdictions.Under this Bill income will now be taxed, not as it is sent to Australia, but as it accrues on an annualised basis overseas.

The foreign investment fund measures will apply to income and gains accumulating in foreign countries that are not Australian controlled or foreign trusts that fall outside the scope of the FSI measures. The measures will also apply to certain foreign life assurance policies, particularly those that have an investment component, such as life bonds.

In addition, the Bill will amend the existing trust provisions in division 6 and division 6AAA of the principal Act in their application to non-resident trust income. The principal change is to the way in which a person's share of the net income from such non-resident trusts is ascertained. This will be aligned in a way in which a person's share of foreign investment fund income is determined under the foreign investment fund measures. During the committee stage of the Bill I intend to raise some technical anomalies arising out of these changes.

Industry has advised the Government that it will take about nine months to adequately implement a system to cater for foreign investment fund record-keeping. Bearing in mind that we have a start-up date of 1 January, this is hardly sufficient time. The few overseas countries that have introduced such legislation have allowed open debate. They have also allowed the Bills to lie on the table for up to two years, and in some cases even longer. The foreign investment fund measures contained in this Bill will take effect from 1 January 1993. The industry has indicated that this implementation date is unsatisfactory. The Liberal-National Party coalition will, therefore, move a committee stage amendment to defer the commencement date to 1 July 1993.

In adopting 37 of the 52 recommendations made by Professor Arnold, the Government feels that it has solved the majority of the problems that were raised by the industry and by those who had a concern about this legislation. However, there are still a number of problems associated with this legislation, some of which were the subject of the recommendations by Professor Arnold in his review and not adopted by the Government and some others that were beyond the purview of the recommendations and the review conducted by the professor.

It should be noted, though, that Professor Arnold's report dealt only with the technical and practical aspects of the implementation of the foreign investment fund legislation and not with the policy basis of the FIF legislation. I take issue with the Treasurer's press release No. 153, of 9 October, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (Professor Arnold's) Report endorses the basic FIF approach adopted by the Government . . . None of its recommendations is inconsistent with, or requires any alteration to, the fundamental policy and structure of the legislation.

I believe that it is incorrect of the Government to use Professor Arnold's report to endorse its policy in this area. The Treasurer has taken Professor Arnold's comments out of context. Let me read what the Professor states:

Second, the terms of my appointment do not permit me to examine the policy aspects of the proposed legislation. Although the distinction between policy and implementation is a difficult one to make, I have resisted the temptation . . . to examine the fundamental policy aspects of the proposed FIF measures. (Therefore,) none of the recommendations is inconsistent with, or requires any alteration of, the fundamental policy and structure of the legislation.

Further, the Taxation Institute of Australia, for example, has expressed the view that the proposed legislation has been introduced on the basis of an anti-avoidance and anti-tax deferral measure, but notes that the proposed legislation sets out an entirely new regime for taxing investments in foreign entities generally and the anti-avoidance objective does not seem to justify the scope of these provisions. This is evident from the fact that the major burden of the proposed legislation will fall on Australian taxpayers with bona fide investments in offshore entities. That is the problem that we have with the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The latest Bill has made concessions in this area, but they do not go far enough. Again, the Taxation Institute, for example, notes that the proposed changes to the foreign life policies are only an alternative method of valuing income by referring to the sum value of the policy. All this alternative does is effectively tax the contribution at the top marginal rate.

Importantly, the schedule 4 so-called `white list' has been replaced with a so-called `black list', in taxation parlance. The connotations involved in such terms are unfortunate. The so-called black list exempts interest in any foreign company engaged principally in an active business other than an investment, financial services and certain real estate, banking investment businesses.

Sections of the industry have generally greeted the concept of a black list with enthusiasm. However, those parts of the industry involved with resident public unit trusts and the funds management areas have noted that the record-keeping and distribution problems have not been resolved by the introduction of this so-called black list.

This approach does not resolve the inconsistencies associated with the de minimus exemption and the problems associated with distributions of income. Where entities have made a significant distribution, the Bill fails to provide an exemption from the foreign investment fund regime and has given rise to double taxation, a most unfortunate aspect of tax which is creeping increasingly into tax law.

The compliance costs of establishing a system to cater for the maintenance of attribution accounts and the detailed record-keeping requirements will not differ under the black list approach. The coalition—the National and Liberal parties—believes that those corporations carrying on an active business of providing financial services should be exempt when the shares are widely held, actively traded and on an approved stock exchange—and especially where they make regular distributions.

Another concern highlighted by the new Bill is the exemption for an interest held in a foreign bank. This has now been amended so that the test is now more practically feasible. Instead of the taxpayer having to establish the existence of a fixed number of non-associated shareholders—a most difficult task—the interest will be exempt so long as the shares in the foreign bank are widely held and actively traded. Why not the same rules for financial services institutions?

The treatment of foreign investment fund losses has also been addressed—and this is welcomed by those who are involved in this particular area of activity—as recommended by Professor Arnold, to allow foreign investment fund losses to be offset against a taxpayer's assessable income generally. However, there remain serious concerns regarding the rationale behind the proposed legislation.

With the large number of exemptions now contained within this new Bill, its purpose is even more obviously aimed at avoidance and deferral of taxation. It is submitted that this stated objective could well have been achieved by a greater reliance on the present general anti-avoidance provisions contained in part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936.

The need to enact 113 pages of legislation in an attempt to bring into the tax net a very small proportion of the taxpaying community already covered would appear to be legislative overkill at its very worst. The enactment of such a complex piece of legislation which taxpayers will theoretically have to acquaint themselves with simply to determine whether their investments are excluded from the operation of the foreign investment funds measures does not sit comfortably with the concept of simplification of the tax law.

Foreign investment fund legislation will prove a strong disincentive to overseas executives wanting to settle in Australia and to expatriates returning to Australia. Intending migrants with passive investments in their home country, such as endowment life insurance policies, will face a penalty tax in Australia, which would not apply to an equivalent Australian investment. Regrettably, the Government has not adopted Professor Arnold's recommendation to transfer offshore policies onshore. The Australian industry has suggested that when a foreign life policy is transferred onshore, it should not be necessary to restart the 10-year period for the purpose of section 26AH of the ITAA.

I now turn to a discussion of those areas of this Bill which need further examination. First, I highlight the inequities and deficiencies in the Bill with respect to the funds management industry and the treatment of resident public unit trusts.

The primary issues can be discussed under four headings. First, there is the need to defer the Bill's implementation date to 1 July 1993. Secondly, the 5 per cent de minimus exemption should be determined on the basis of the total portfolio held by a resident, including domestic investments and cash holdings. Thirdly, investments in companies carrying on an active business or providing financial services should be exempt where the shares are widely held and are actively traded on an approved exchange. Fourthly, there are the compliance and administrative issues associated with the small investor exemption and distribution from resident unit trusts.

Of the aforementioned issues, the request for the deferral of the implementation date needs urgent examination. The Government needs to understand the mechanics involved in what it is asking the industry to perform. Let us take one unnamed investment company which invests on both the domestic and global markets according to the superannuation funds investment mandate and portfolio type. Where the investment company acts as the fund manager and custodian on behalf of the superannuation fund, detailed reports have to be sent out to the trustees on a monthly basis.

The reports detail, firstly, the performance of the fund for the month; secondly, the investments held by the fund at the end of the month; thirdly, a transaction list detailing each investment bought and sold during the month; fourthly, bank account transactions for the month; and, fifthly, specific tax information which sets out the tax position of each fund on a monthly basis and year-to-date basis. These reports reflect the type and source of the income-expenditure received and incurred by the fund and are based on each fund's year of income.

One firm has estimated that the cost of designing and implementing amendments to the firm's computer and other systems to comply with the FIF legislation is over $3m. This is because the system has to be amended to ensure that it, firstly, monitors each client's portfolio for black-listed FIFs; secondly, determines the FIF income or loss arising in respect of each FIF; thirdly, determines whether there is an attribution surplus for a particular FIF to calculate the exempt component of a distribution from the FIF; fourthly, maintains attribution accounts for each FIF; and, fifthly, calculates the FIF income to be included in each fund's assessable income after accounting for FIF losses which have been utilised against the fund's assessable income.

As can be seen from what I have just outlined, the compliance costs are therefore extraordinarily high. Further, many of the tax reports required are based on each fund's year of income. Often, many of the funds have substituted accounting periods in lieu of the succeeding and preceding 30 June. Given that in some cases funds can balance as early as 31 March in lieu of the succeeding 30 June, there is just not enough time to implement complex changes to many systems being used by the industry affected by these changes before us; hence, the need for an amendment to defer the implementation date to 1 July 1993. We contend that no money will be lost as a result of this because if funds of such a nature were out there they would certainly already have been brought back.

The funds management industry has also pointed out to me that an inequity occurs for investors who invest in both Australian and global markets with regard to the 5 per cent de minimus exemption. This occurs since the exemption is determined by the total value of all FIFs held rather than the total value of the investor's assets.

Whilst industry is very happy with the rationale for providing an exemption from the FIF legislation through the de minimus exemption, it believes that by adopting the total value of investments as a denominator in applying the 5 per cent exemption it does not contradict the Government's stated objective—that taxpayers with minimal investment in black-listed activity offshore companies and in offshore trusts do not put the revenue at risk and are rightly excluded.

The industry has also expressed concern that this Bill has not adopted Professor Arnold's recommendation, on page 18 of his report, that it is `difficult to justify the exclusion of Australian investors from important sectors of the international economy', such as real estate, insurance and financial services.

I am happy to note that the real estate and insurance sectors have been provided subsequently with an exemption, but not the financial services sector. The Treasurer's rationale for this action—that is, because of its potential as an avenue for abuse—is inconsistent with the comments made by Professor Arnold in his report on pages 19 and 20. The Government should consider such an exemption for the financial services sector if the shares are listed on an approved exchange; the foreign company carries on an active business of providing financial services; and the shares are widely held and actively traded.

Companies which engage in the financial services industry are not exempt from the FIF legislation. I ask the Senate: what is wrong with Australian fund managers investing in corporations such as American Express and Merrill Lynch, which carry on active financial services business—an investment made solely on the investment performance of that particular corporation?

A further recommendation made by Professor Arnold and not adopted by the Government concerns the amendments in the Bill with regard to the exemption for unit holders investing in resident public unit trusts. The small investor exemption in section 96A(2) has not been resolved and in its present form has created severe compliance problems for fund managers. Time will not permit me to discuss this in detail here, but there are several other concerns which I wish to list. Firstly, there is the double taxation of income from interest in non-resident estates that still exists where the FIF is sold during the year of income. Secondly, the balance sheet method is an impractical method to apply and assumes the taxpayer has access to detailed information. Thirdly, the life insurance exemption can be satisfied only by using the balance sheet method. Fourthly, the Morgan Stanley Capital Index—MSCI—does not differentiate between companies carrying on life insurance and general insurance businesses. Rather, there is only one classification of insurance; hence, a taxpayer would have to use the balance sheet method to determine whether the FIF was exempt.

Given the time and the importance of a number of other issues that I wish to put on the record and in view of the fact that we have agreed that I would be the only speaker on this side of the House, I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate my remaining comments in Hansard. However, I think this guillotine motion is absolutely atrocious and is such that important legislation will be caught by it.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Watson, I will put it to the Senate that there be leave for incorporation. Of course, you could have sought leave to speak for a few more minutes. But I will put what you have requested. Is leave granted for the remainder of Senator Watson's speech to be incorporated in Hansard?

TALK.START.PARA: —If he is absolutely the only Opposition speaker, I am happy to give him 10 minutes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I agree to the comments being incorporated, so I think we can proceed on that basis.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: 5The trading stock exemption in Section 520 implies that all FIF's have to be valued at market value under section 31(per cent) for the FIF's to be exempt. It has been suggested that the exemption should be amended so that a taxpayer can elect to use the market value method under section 31 (5) in respect of a particular FIF to ensure the FIF provisions do not apply.
6Compliance costs could be significantly reduced if a deemed disposal election, similar to the amendments made to trading stock provisions were introduced.

7The use of an index to determine the international sectoral classification requires further consideration. Morgan Stanley Capital International classify stocks according to their activities, and produce a listing of these stocks on a monthly basis according to the activity of the company. These stocks incorporate companies which may not necessarily be included on the MSCI. If the same classification process is used to categorise stocks not included on the MSCI, the classification provided by Morgan Stanley for all stocks should be adopted.

Mr President, in conclusion, I would like to remind this chamber that debating such a complex, intricate Bill as this one before us tonight has been greatly disadvantaged by the operation of the Guillotine. In future, I think that the industry of this country could be best served if a full and adequate debate is permitted.

The Government has produced documented evidence of the need for the legislation and the measures in this Bill are out of proportion to the problems involved. The breadth of the proposals, the impact on legitimate overseas investment and the high compliance costs indicate that this legislation is an overkill not only for institutional investors and Australians but also for intending migrants and expatriated Australians wishing to return home from their retirement.

The legislation for taxing increments to investments accruals approaching is becoming a feature of ALP taxation policy. Pensioners have been subjected to such an attack resulting in the reduction of their Commonwealth Age Pension on three occasions—Friendly Society Bonds, Managed Investments and most recently investments in offshore valuations. I conclude by predicting that full wealth taxation is just around the corner should the ALP win the next election.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Do you want to incorporate your speech too?

—Senator Bolkus would like me to incorporate my speech, but I will not be long. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Foreign Investment) Bill 1992, which is before the Senate today, has had a long and complex history. The measure was originally scheduled to take effect from 1 July 1990, was deferred for a year and then another year until the broad details were released in last year's Budget. A detailed information paper was released in April this year and an original Bill was introduced shortly afterwards. That Bill was subsequently withdrawn because of a major alteration of policy. Professor Arnold was appointed to further review the legislation and an extensive report was released in October. This suggested dozens of further amendments, of which the Government accepted 37. I think Senator Watson was hoping that it would accept the lot. A new revised Bill was introduced incorporating these changes.

PARA.TAB: So these measures are the final stage in a total restructuring of the taxation regime, which applies to income from foreign sources, which commenced in 1987. At that time a comprehensive foreign tax credit system was introduced. This removed the previous provision which allowed income to be enjoyed tax free in Australia if it had borne any foreign tax at all. Clearly, this system provided a huge incentive for taxpayers to arrange their affairs so that they earned their income from offshore sources. In 1990, the accrual measures were introduced. These complemented the foreign tax credit system by taxing certain income earned by foreign entities which are controlled from Australia on an accruals basis; that is, people could no longer avoid their Australian taxation obligations simply by not remitting their foreign income back to Australia.

These foreign investment fund measures before us today buttress these accrual measures which I have just mentioned by introducing a regime to tax the interests held by Australian residents in foreign entities which are not controlled by Australians—that is, where an Australian owns an interest in a foreign company or trust which is not controlled from Australia.

In many instances, I think Senator Watson could argue, a foreign company or trust is still an attractive investment vehicle because it allows for the accumulation of income offshore, especially in low tax countries, allowing the investor to minimise and defer Australian tax. I think it is important to realise that the current tax regime in effect provides an incentive for foreign investment by Australian residents. This contributes to a bias against local investment and, hence, has important ramifications for the level of economic activity and employment in Australia, especially in the financial services area.

This was recognised in the Arnold report. That report clearly supported the need for and the desirability of these measures—measures which, as Senator Watson said, are incredibly complex. That is unfortunate but, given the unavoidable complexities of the world's financial markets and the world's economy generally, I guess it is to be expected. I think we have found from experience that there is nearly always a trade-off between equity and simplicity in taxation matters. While the Democrats support legislation which is as simple and, hence, as accessible as possible, we will not sacrifice equity just for the sake of simplicity.

It is fair to say that the Government has consulted extensively on this matter and that it has targeted those non-controlling interests in foreign entities that provide the greatest scope for tax avoidance. The particular focus is on long term interests and multi-tiered offshore investments that enable the deferral of Australian tax. That income is then usually converted into concessionally taxed capital gains on the disposal of the interests.

Short term interests, that is, those that are held for less than 12 months, are generally not caught as, by their very nature, there is no significant deferral of the derivation of income. Furthermore, there is a reasonable de minimus exemption which excludes small amounts of offshore investments—and by `small' we mean up to $50,000—from the regime.

This recognises the legitimacy of some passive offshore investment by Australians, but it sets limits. I am in favour of setting limits. We should be setting limits on what comes in as well, but honourable senators all know my view on that. It sets strict limits on the amount which can continue to be concessionally taxed. That is sensible and reasonable and deserves support.

The major change recommended by Professor Arnold and accepted by the Government is that the system originally proposed by the Government, known as a white list approach, is to be changed to a black list approach. The white list states what kinds of activity will be considered to be active and hence exempted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you happy with those terms?

—No, I am not happy with those terms and I know a lot of people in the indigenous community would not be particularly happy either. On the other hand, a black list approach lists all those activities which do not qualify as active and which will therefore be caught by the fifth measures.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is not aimed at discouraging active foreign investment—for example, investing in a foreign manufacturing plant—by Australians, but there are certain types of business investment which will be caught by this black listing. These include banking, insurance, real estate, financial services and funds management, although banking, insurance and real estate activities are now exempted where they are conducted by a publicly listed company whose shares are widely held.

The legislation will ensure that only those activities which are black listed are treated as passive and consequently will be affected by the accrual taxation regime. This legislation further defers the commencement date until 1 January. I heard Senator Watson saying that we should be considering an extension of the implementation date until 1 July 1993 and he gave the reasons of compliance and complexity. We will deal with that proposal at the committee stage.

I do not want to discuss the intimate detail of these measures. I acknowledge that there are still some outstanding issues, some disagreements between the Government and some taxpayers on detail. However, this is only to be expected, given the complexity involved, and I am sure we will be dealing with these during the committee stage as well.

I welcome the fact that the Opposition will also be supporting this legislation, although there is the unresolved question of the commencement date. The Bill is estimated to raise $90m in 1993-94 and $200m in subsequent years. It is certainly a good measure to increase the incentives for Australians to invest in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shouldn't be the purpose of taxation legislation.
—Of course it could be the purpose of tax legislation. Removing the unfair advantage to passive foreign investment which currently exists will achieve this purpose.

—in reply—I thank both Senator Watson and Senator Kernot for their considered contributions and support for the legislation. Given that we are under some time pressure to get on to the next debate, I will not go across the whole range of issues we have to deal with. We will also have a committee hearing in which to respond to any details.

PARA.TAB: I do want to make some points because, notwithstanding that there has not been an extensive debate, we are dealing with an important, if complex, piece of legislation. It is important for one very straightforward reason that Senator Kernot referred to, which is that it raises a lot of revenue. That should not be underestimated as a significant purpose.

Secondly, it is the third element of a three-stage process to make the tax system fairer, to ensure that the avoidance potential which existed with regard to foreign income is no longer available and that there is a comprehensive anti-avoidance package in the way foreign source income is taxed.

As senators in the main will know—and certainly Senator Watson and Senator Kernot know—this goes back to a 1991-92 Budget announcement which outlined the broad design features of the foreign investment fund measures. It concludes the process which overcomes the taxation bias which had operated in the past and which encouraged Australians to invest in offshore tax havens rather than in their own country. That is the purpose.

I mention the timetable for a second reason, because that is one of the two reasons why we do not accept the proposal that it is necessary or appropriate to further delay the operative date of the FIFs measure. Nobody will be taken by surprise by this legislation. It was first announced on 20 August 1991. A detailed information paper was released on 2 April 1992 and the proposed legislation was first introduced in the 25 June Bill. It is true that there has been some significant amendment since that time, but the core concepts remain constant. The essential elements of the Bill have in fact been known by the sorts of people who are likely to be affected by these measures since 20 August 1991.

People who are dealing with the sophisticated level of investment that we are talking about here have known since that time exactly what was envisaged by foreign investment fund measures because they know other countries have such measures. Almost every other Western country has something similar and they have certainly known for a long time the broad nature of the responsibilities that would be imposed upon them. If that is not apparent as a matter of logic, I am sure it is apparent by the nature of the correspondence we have all received. People were not in much doubt about what it meant for them.

It is also the case that people do know and have broadly known what sort of information they will be required to provide and what it is that they have to do to comply with the requirements of this legislation. Of course, the date of operation has already been put back so that nobody really has a reasonable excuse for saying that they have not had time to prepare.

So, on the one hand, I do not believe that people will be caught in a position where they have not been given reasonable time. They may not have made reasonable arrangements, but that is not the Parliament's responsibility. Our responsibility is to make sure that they have reasonable opportunity. On the other hand—and let us not underestimate the significant of this, and Senator Kernot referred to it by implication—if we put back the date of operation to 1 July 1993, it means that the $90m that it is proposed to raise in that financial year is also put back.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not.

—Senator Watson understands the way it operates. He knows that is the case. The date of operation of a Bill cannot be put back by six months at no cost. Senator Watson knows that is true. Of course it costs revenue to put back the date of effect of something by six months.
—The sorts of moneys have already returned to Australia. You have evidence of that.

—If all the money had come back and this was not going to cost anybody anything, we would not be receiving quite so many letters. I understand some people are putting that argument. They eloquently say, `This is not happening, but you should not tax it anyway because it is going to cause us too much difficulty'. Both positions are not tenable.

PARA.TAB: The other point that is made is that this legislation is too complex and that the man and woman in the street would not be able to comprehend and cope with it. I want to make two points about that without unduly taking the time of the Senate because I want to finish promptly. One is that the FIF measures have become more complex as a result of the consultation process. This is far from a unique circumstance. We all know that it happened to an even greater extent with regard to the controlled foreign corporations legislation, the second stage of these foreign income taxing measures. The size and complexity of the Bill grew, quite reasonably, as a result of the consultation process. I do not say that as a criticism. In the consultation process, new issues were raised that meant that further amendments to the legislation were required.

They cannot have it both ways. They cannot say, `We want to be involved. We want to have the variations that we suggest, the one-off or extraordinary circumstances which might arise that the Bill does not properly encompass, taken into account. But we want a simple Bill'. They cannot have both those things and I think it is more appropriate that the legislation be comprehensive and that it deals with the issues people raise with us in their consultation than for it to be simple and not cope with the multitude of different circumstances this sort of legislation has to deal with.

The last point is that not very many ordinary men and women in the street will have to deal with this legislation. Not very many people will be doing back-of-the-envelope calculations on the kitchen table to work out how much the FIF legislation will cost them in their tax bill. It just will not happen. Let us just think about it. The FIF measures will apply only to taxpayers whose offshore investment exceeds $50,000. I have to say that there are not a whole lot of mum, dad and the kids taxpayers doing their back-of-the-envelope calculations who are worried about how they cope with their $50,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the expatriates who come back to Australia from overseas?

—The expatriates Senator Watson knows are doing a little better than the expatriates I know if they have $50,000 overseas, if they have the sort of investments where they get caught up in FIF and have brought back with them the assets they have. Certainly, a typical offshore investment of an Australian resident is unlikely to be more than 20 per cent of the total investments in a portfolio, on the normal investment advice that people get. So we are really talking in the main about people who have an investment portfolio of about $250,000 with $50,000 offshore. By the time we get to that, we are down to a fairly small crowd and, I have to say, a fairly sophisticated financial crowd.

PARA.TAB: Even expatriates who come back with those sorts of investment arrangements are, I think, expecting to get, at least for the first transitional year of their return to the Australian tax system, professional tax advice. They probably would be well advised to do so whether they are involved in this legislation or not.

We are now in the situation where the alternative to this legislation is allowing people to continue to avoid their proper tax responsibilities. I know that no-one in the Senate is supporting that. I am not suggesting they are; that is why they are supporting the legislation. I will not accept the argument that the legislation is unnecessarily complex. It is a response to complex circumstances; therefore, it is complex legislation. I think it is timely legislation. We have proceeded in a measured and methodical way. We might be criticised for being too slow, but I do not think that is reasonable. People do have to have time to prepare and we have to make sure we get each piece of legislation right.

When this legislation passes we will have the three major elements of taxation of foreign source income in place. We will be in the same sort of position as most countries comparable to ourselves with regard to the taxation of foreign source income. Most of them have such arrangements and most of them incorporate foreign investment fund type measures in their package. It is time we caught up. I am pleased to have the support of the Senate in doing so, and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
