PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator McMullan, from 10 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus, from 9 November, on motion by Senator McMullan, and from 12 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a package of four Bills—Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992, Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1992 and Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992—but because of the shortage of time I intend to confine my comments to only one aspect of the Bills. Certainly, my colleagues will be commenting in more depth on the others. For example, my colleague Senator Alston will shortly be in the chamber and will be talking about the superannuation aspects.

PARA.TAB: Once again, I register my disapproval at the institution of the guillotine and the consequent lack of debate that will occur on the intricacies of this Bill. I contrast the amount of time spent on the last Bill with the time spent on the broadcasting Bill, which was debated yesterday and most of today.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992 implements the Government's 1992-93 Budget announcement to amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to impose FBT on certain car parking benefits. The Bill also amends the Income Tax Assessment Act to deny deductibility for car parking expenses incurred in relation to the above benefits. This latter measure was not announced in the 1992-93 Budget and the new measures are to take effect from 1 July 1993. So it is a new tax measure.

The Bill will include a new division 10A in the Fringe Benefits Tax Act to deal with the benefits provided by an employer to an employee in the form of car parking facilities. This proposal has taken the entire business world by storm. The Institute of Chartered Accountants has labelled the proposal as ridiculous and comical. The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants has described it as absurd and a Monty Python tax. Further criticism has called it unworkable and a joke. This is only part of the huge avalanche of criticism that is flooding the newspapers as well as coalition and, I would imagine, Government offices.

Generally, car parking benefits exist where an employer provides to the employee any car parking facility on business premises which are owned, controlled or leased in whole or in part by the employer. In summary, no benefit will exist unless a permanent, commercial car parking facility available for all-day parking is within one kilometre of the employer provided car parking facility and/or where the car is parked at or in the vicinity of the employee's primary place of employment and

SPEECH.PARA: is parked at that place for more than four hours during the period between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. on a particular day.

PARA.TAB: Broadly speaking, a car parking benefit will arise only where a car used to commute from home to work is parked at or near the employee's main workplace for more than four hours between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. Where an employer reimburses an employee's car parking expenses, the value of the benefit will be the amount of the reimbursement. The taxable value of the benefit where the employer provides car parking facilities for the employee will be the value of the lowest cost all-day parking at a permanent commercial parking area available to the public within one kilometre of the employer provided facilities.

Without taking very long on these rules, it can be ascertained that although they may be targeting the high income earner, these car parking arrangements will unintentionally affect ordinary workers in schools, TAFE colleges, universities, private hospitals, airports, rail employees, building workers on construction sites, local, State and Federal public servants, retailers and their employees, factory workers, police and other emergency workers, and people with disabilities and their car parking arrangements. The tax therefore will affect businesses as well as non-profit businesses and charitable organisations.

I have been advised that this tax will cost Qantas alone $6m a year. As a consequence, Qantas is considering no longer allowing its employees to park on premises within the confines of the airport. I foresee an overflow of parking problems on the streets surrounding airports and a further increase in the damage to parked cars by vandalism. It will have a dramatic effect on industries around Tullamarine airport in Victoria. Similarly, lay employees of religious institutions can no longer be provided with car parking on church premises without exposing the church to an FBT liability.

The Government has said that it will introduce some regulations, but we do not have them before us. It is sending out all sorts of letters saying that this is not the intention of the legislation. But the Act which governs the legislation does not deal with such provisions.

The businesses most affected will be labour-intensive industries that are traditionally Labor supporters. I am surprised that the Labor Party has introduced this tax, especially after it found in the mid-1980s that such a tax was unpopular and unworkable. At that time it was demonstrated that revenue derived from the FBT on car parking spaces would be significantly eroded by administrative costs. Little has changed since 1986, except the capacity of firms, because of the recession, to bear the extra imposts. Further, it was decided that those people who participated in the central business district parking were not really receiving a benefit, but that the parking was essential to their work.

An interesting development has come to my attention in a letter written by the ALP candidate for Lowe, Ms Mary Easson. She has written to the schools in her hoped-for constituency informing them of the following. Apparently the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has informed her, by what means we are not told, that he has made arrangements that will enable schools hit by this tax to apply for exemption from the new FBT provisions. As I see it, this does not seem to be included in the legislation before us at the moment. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this letter from the Labor candidate for Lowe.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 20 November 1992
The Principal
Meridan School
PO Box 78
STRATHFIELD NSW 2135
Dear Principal

I am writing to you to explain the new arrangements, now deferred until July next year, regarding the Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT). It has been speculated that this could affect the free school parking, provided by schools, for their staff.
Following representations from myself and others, the Treasurer John Dawkins, has made arrangements to enable schools to apply for exemption from the new FBT provisions.
Under these arrangements peak school councils will need to apply for exemption on behalf of individual schools such as Santa Sabina.
The Treasurer informs me that it was never intended that parking of minimal value or of an obviously non commercial nature would or should fall within the FBT provisions.
If I can be of any further assistance to you on these issues or any other matter, please don't hesitate to contact me.
Yours faithfully
MARY EASSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not heard of such arrangements. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), or perhaps some other New South Wales Labor Party senator, to clarify the situation. I am not in any way questioning the need for the exemption, but I am questioning the manner in which it is done. Surely such an announcement would come from the Treasurer or a parliamentary representative rather than from an endorsed candidate.

PARA.TAB: Two schools that immediately come to mind are the Meriden School and the Santa Sabina School, which both now face bills of approximately $81,000 and $100,000 respectively. So there is no question that they and all other non-profitable and charitable organisations need an exemption.

This letter states that it was `never intended that parking of minimal value or of an obviously non-commercial nature would or should fall within the FBT provisions'. I look forward to hearing the Parliamentary Secretary's comments.

The all-encompassing restrictive rules of this tax need the soundest condemnation that this side of the chamber can possibly muster. This tax highlights a need to reassess our whole approach to fringe benefits tax legislation. It is a good example of how the flow-on effect of taxes can completely distort a market.

For example, there are three types of car parking arrangements. First, the employer makes no arrangement for his or her employees. The employee meets the expenses with his or her after-tax dollar. The second arrangement is that the employer provides car parking at the employer's expense totally independent of any salary arrangement. The employer provides the car parking free for a variety of reasons, including competitive pressures, government regulations, a lack of public transport and others.

The third category is where the employer has a total remuneration concept and permits an employee to salary-package his car parking. This third person is definitely receiving a benefit, which this Bill recognises. The employee benefits, but the tax is imposed on the employer.

While this tax may encourage employers to eliminate the car parking benefit in the third category, it results in a variety of distortions with situations particularly in the second category. Those employers are forced to pay an additional tax when neither they nor their employees have been involved in any form of tax avoidance. This increase in costs is presumably in many cases passed on to their customers or clients in the form of increased prices, but others, such as schools, cannot do this as easily.

As noted, the purpose of the proposed legislation is to bring car parking benefits into the fringe benefits tax net. Its intended aim was to prevent the executive from obtaining a fringe benefit that the ordinary worker was not obtaining. I am sorry to say that it has backfired due to the arbitrary base of the tax, not only for the inclusion of the benefits but also for the valuation of such benefits.

It does not necessarily follow that the mere existence of a commercial car parking station within a one-kilometre radius of the employer's premises gives rise to an assumption of a valuable benefit having been provided to an employee. The flaw in the logic is compounded by the proposed measure which adopts as the tax value the lowest fee charged by an operator of a relevant parking station open to members of the public for full day parking.

The tax is said to apply only to central business district employees because of the one-kilometre commercial car parking test. However, the absurdity is illustrated by the Australian Taxation Office's own decentralisation program. In Melbourne, the Taxation Office now has offices in Dandenong, Box Hill, Moonee Ponds and Moorabbin. Because of the number of employees involved, commercial car parks have been established for all these decentralised sites, with the exception of Moorabbin. As a result all employees within one kilometre of those taxation offices, with the exception of Moorabbin, will now have to pay FBT on the provision of car parking facilities to their employees.

This produces a somewhat absurd result. Banks, insurance companies and retailers that provide employee parking in such large centres as Ringwood, Greensborough and Werribee are not providing their employees with a taxable fringe benefit. Yet the employees on exactly the same terms and conditions of employment who work in centres where the Taxation Office has decentralised offices are receiving a taxable fringe benefit.

This is not the only silly analogy. For example, Melbourne University is subject to the tax when neither La Trobe University nor Monash University, which can provide parking at a much cheaper cost, appears to be exempt.

The proposed formula promoted by the Government in this tax is clearly distorting the true value to an employee of the benefit of the on-site parking provided by an employer. This is not a fair balance between the provision of benefits to employees and the incurring by an employer of a valuable business expense. The fringe benefits tax recognises that as far as a motor vehicle is concerned, vehicles may be used for business and private purposes. This is particularly the case with regard to parking bays.

This proposed legislation is more onerous than the initial motor vehicle fringe benefits provisions. The record-keeping requirements are greater and will be extremely difficult to administer in their current form. For example, the absurdity is that the legislation requires that each employer keep daily records of the cars parked on his or her premises and must distinguish between the employee and non-employee cars. This is a very time-consuming procedure. As a result administrative overheads will rise and paperwork will increase. The proposal will increase the cost of running businesses at a time when many businesses and companies are still shedding staff. It appears that the recession we had to have must continue by government legislation.

In summary, the form of record keeping required under the proposed measures will deprive employers of a right to bear FBT only on that part which generally represents a benefit to employees. It will impose an unrealistic administrative burden on employers—another increased cost of compliance.

Other inconsistencies occur when the provision of parking bays is examined. Where parking bays are provided by the employer, there is in effect a presumption that in the proposed legislation there is no business use. This current proposal does not provide taxpayers with equal access to the otherwise deductible rule. As a result, firms will be taxed on legitimate business expenses. The proposal before us today will actually discourage firms from locating in existing commercial districts—an outcome which runs contrary to urban consolidation policies that are being pursued by State and local governments.

Further questions raised by the Bill include: when does the use of a car park constitute the provision of parking facilities in respect of the employment of an employee? Presumably, the answer is quite clear: when a specific space is provided to an employee on the employer's premises—for example, reserved parking for the secretary or manager of the club. However, if a business is required by law to have a certain number of car parking spaces, is it a provision of parking facilities if employees are permitted to park on the premises if the spaces are available? That is difficult to determine if the proposed legislation is meant to catch these sorts of cases. Other examples include schools which permit or do not permit staff parking and manufacturers who permit or do not prohibit staff car parking in a general area or on a vacant allotment which the manufacturer owns.

Another concern expressed has been that the tax will actively discriminate against the security of women who have to work overtime, especially in winter when it is well and truly dark by 7 p.m. The possibility exists that employers will no longer provide car parking close to their places of work. Time does not permit me to raise further examples. It is absolutely outrageous that a boss who regularly provides a taxi home to protect members of his female work force who have to work after hours should be caught under the fringe benefits tax legislation. A fringe benefit!
In conclusion, I quote the Taxation Institute of Australia's comments on the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Institute's view the proposed legislation neither meets the tests of efficiency nor equity and needs to be substantially reviewed.

If enacted in its present form, it places substantial and onerous administrative burdens upon employers, and therefore, would represent a failure by the Government in meeting its duties to the community in enacting fair and reasonable legislation.
I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson dealt very effectively with one aspect of the package that has caused a great deal of anxiety in the community. As a result of his analysis, I am sure that the Government will at least come to appreciate the ways in which its measures have so arbitrarily impacted on many groups that are totally undeserving of such treatment.

PARA.TAB: In the time available, I want to deal with another aspect which goes to the heart of the Government's double standards in the area of superannuation. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992 contains a number of provisions which flow from the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on security in retirement of 30 June last. Some of these are commendable and some are long overdue improvements.

Let me outline a most extraordinary provision which to date has not had the attention that it deserves. A government which used to claim a mortgage on social justice and which tries to claim that somehow it is out there benefiting low income earners has not only introduced a superannuation guarantee charge regime, which will do little or nothing for this generation of the work force in terms of improving its position vis-a-vis the age pension which it would otherwise have been entitled to receive, but also has provided absolutely extraordinary different levels of taxation treatment of high and low income earners. For example, at present those who are self-employed can claim a tax deduction of $3,000 plus 75 per cent up to the limit of their reasonable benefit limits.

The Government is proposing to rationalise the extraordinarily complicated, unfair and illogical system currently in place which provides differential tax treatment of contributions, depending upon one's status in the work force, with limits on deductions for superannuation contributions. What do we find that the Government does in the case of high income earners—usually self-employed professionals with perhaps two income earners in the family? We find that this Government, with its great concern for helping the low income groups, will allow a person over a 45-year working period, taking maximum advantage of the age base limits, to contribute a maximum of $1.44m. If we average that out over that 45-year working period we find that those high net worth individuals or those fortunate enough to be employed by generous corporate employers will be able to contribute $33,000 per year on average throughout their working lives.

What sort of treatment do we find is given to the low income earners—the ones that the Government professes great concern for and for whom the SGC is supposed to represent some sort of progressive achievement? We find that they are cut off at the knees. For contributions of $1,000 they are given a maximum $100 rebate—10 per cent of contributions up to $1,000. They get a miserable and derisory $100 a year. It is not as if that is available to everyone in the work force. In fact, it is only available—even at the full rate of $100—to those with incomes of $27,000 or less.

If 70 per cent of the work force is in receipt of less than $30,000 average weekly earnings, the great majority of wage and salary earners will at best be entitled to a rebate of $100. On the other hand, those who are least in need of extraordinary generosity and who are least likely to be claimants for the age pension are getting tax deductible benefits of up to $33,000 a year. That is a travesty of social justice for which there has been absolutely no explanation other than that the Government, in its usual reactive negative approach to superannuation, has simply sat back, looked at the proposals that have been announced by the Opposition and tried to go one step further in so far as it thinks there is political mileage to be gained. I think this will rebound on the Government devastatingly, as low income earners come to realise that not only will they effectively be denied any tax concession but also the SGC regime will not provide them with anything near enough to a reasonable level of retirement income.

Take the current generation of the work force. The Government says, `You would need to receive 12 per cent over a 40-year working life to get 40 per cent of average weekly earnings if you are on average weekly earnings now'. That may be a commendable target. A pensioner who would otherwise be looking forward to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings—or 28 per cent under Fightback—is being offered 40 per cent. But the fundamental problem is that the vast majority will not have anything like 12 per cent. Indeed, something like 1 1/2 million employees are not even getting the first 3 per cent under the award superannuation regime. There are a significant number who are getting 3 per cent and nothing more. Under the SGC regime, that will rise progressively to 9 per cent by the year 2002. No doubt, in due course that will be converted to 12 per cent as an employer impost. The fact remains that one will not even be getting anything like 12 per cent for at least another 10 years. So much for 12 per cent across the board!

What are the prospects of people working for 40 years? The majority of those in the work force—if they are lucky enough to be there; and there are one million or more who are not, so they get nothing under the SGC regime—are 30 years of age or more. We have a government that is so craven and pusillanimous when it comes to policy reform that it was not even prepared to take the advice of industry and everyone else who acknowledges the need to have income set aside for genuine retirement income by raising the preservation age progressively over a 10-year period, as we have done, from 1 July 1994. What has the Government done? It has accepted the principle of phasing that in over 10 years. But when is it starting? I do not think people would believe this unless they read it in the legislation, but the Government is actually proposing that that 10-year phased increase should commence in 23 years' time.

Call it appalling cynicism, call it an absolute cop-out, but one thing is for sure: it will continue to encourage the work force to retire prematurely. If that is in the national interest, I will go home. One of the great things that Halfpenny and his mates would claim in the 1970s and 1980s was that somehow, if you could get people out of the work force earlier, you would create more jobs for those coming through.

That is not the basis and rationale for the SGC. The SGC is all about this rising demographic tidal wave that will overwhelm us, and how we have to accommodate these legions of older people who will need all the income assistance they can get. Yet what we are doing is encouraging them to retire prematurely from the work force and not take advantage of at least the last five, ten, or even more years in which they are capable of earning more income and providing for themselves in retirement.

No, because the ACTU says that these people have a divine right to double dip, we are going to encourage them—make it easy for them—to get out at age 55. Not just splash it up against the wall and dissipate their accumulated lump sums, but simply rearrange their affairs, take all the professional advice they can get from financial planners and others, and make sure that, one way or another, when the time comes, they will be in the queue with their hand out expecting an age pension, as 75 per cent of those over age pension age do at the present time.

Not only do we have a monumental policy cop-out, but we also have the bulk of the work force with no prospect at all of spending 40 years in the work force, let alone 40 years of 12 per cent. If one takes women—and presumably the likes of Senator West, as a member of a select committee, ought to be expressing particular concern—what does one find? One finds that on average women work for ten years less on a full time basis than do males.

Not only are they not in the work force for 40 years, but if they are lucky enough to be in the full time work force at all—in other words, if they are not unemployed, voluntarily or otherwise—if they have families, they are likely to be out of the work force intermittently looking after their families. Then, of course, they are encouraged to get out at age 55 and if that is not good enough for them, they will get the pension offered to them at 60. So there is an additional incentive to retire prematurely.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you suggest?
—What do we suggest? I am sorry Senator West has not read Fightback. We suggest that we gradually phase in the—
—I have lots of letters from people who don't like it.
—What do we say about the preservation age?
—That is what I keep getting letters about.
—What do we say about it?
—I don't know.
—No, Senator West does not know at all. I ask her: what do we say?
—Grow up and get on with the debate.
—It is just an example of how the Government has no real concern for the policy solutions to the ageing of the population.
—I read Fightback and I didn't find anything in there.
—What about the 16 August statement, to which Senator McMullan has not replied?
—I didn't like that either.
—I can understand that Senator McMullan did not like it, but if he had read it he would have seen—
—I said I didn't find any solutions there.
—But Senator McMullan would have found the precise formulation for phasing in the increase in the preservation age.
—I don't like the proposal. There is no solution to the problem there.
—Well, why is the Government proposing to increase it, starting in 23 years' time? It is clearly the way to go. Everyone else knows it but, once again, we have a cop-out.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the proposition that not only will members of this current generation of the work force have virtually nothing set aside for them by way of superannuation guarantee charge—in other words, force fed compulsory super that they could not have got under the pension—but in most instances they will not even do as well as they would on the pension. Who will pay for it? It is up to them, is it not? We know that the employers will not bear this multibillion dollar impost, so workers will have to go without wage increases progressively over the years in order to disqualify themselves from the age pension.

There is the great equity of a Labor government. If you are a high income earner, if you have a wealthy employer, you can get a contribution of $33,000 a year. If you are a middle income earner, you get nothing. If you are a low income earner, you get $100 a year rebate. That is an absolute travesty of social justice.

If we go on to some of the other initiatives we find the deductions and rebates for personal contributions. Not only was that decision made, but it was made to take effect with less than 24 hours' notice. I have not yet heard a satisfactory explanation for this. Senator McMullan might like to enlighten us. Why do all the other initiatives have at least a two-year lead time, and this one immediately and severely disadvantages about 1.3 million individual workers who are claiming deductions at the present time? They are told they are out of the game. They are told—it has not been legislated yet, we are simply being confronted with retrospective legislation to ensure that they have not been silly enough to take advantage of their legal entitlements to the present time—with less than 24 hours' notice that that tax deduction has been withdrawn.

Irrespective of the fact that they will not get anything like enough under the SGC, they are being told, `The last thing we want you to do is top up. We want workers to take no interest at all in making their own retirement income arrangements. Leave it all to us. We will do a deal. We will force employers to make the contributions'—the lowest common denominator, of course. `Over that period, we will look after you'. That is dead right. They will fix workers right up. The end result is that workers will be significantly worse off than they would be under the current system, let alone under a very generous, tax incentive driven, voluntary system such as we propose.

I will move on very briefly to the pension and rollover annuities provisions. They constitute a simpler approach than existing arrangements as they do not differentiate between annuities and pensions which were payable prior to 1988 or prior to the individual reaching age 55. For individuals with pensions or annuities payable prior to 1988, the new rebate arrangements will present a windfall gain. Overall, the measures are commendable in that they represent a simplification of current arrangements and do encourage the choice of an annuity or a pension over the taking of lump sums.

But when we come on to another of the extraordinary cop-outs, in other words, the changes to reasonable benefits limits, we find that the Government is proposing to introduce flat dollar RBL amounts—$400,000 indexed for lump sums—which, of course, will not touch the vast majority of the population. If we are serious about somehow gradually forcing people to take at least a portion of their entitlements in pension or annuity form, this measure will do absolutely nothing to achieve that. Once again, a total cop-out.

It is worse than that. Those who do find themselves affected by it will find that as from 1 July 1994 that will be it and even though they might have exceeded that RBL limit, the SGC will continue to make contributions payable on their behalf. The excess will be taxed at their top marginal rate. If the fund earns ten per cent and AWE is three per cent, that seven per cent difference will again be taxed at their top marginal rate. That is another example of the gross inequity and unfairness of this flat rate approach.

It is in stark contrast to our very generous arrangements which are spelt out in our 16 July statement and which have been remarkably well received in the community. All I can say, from the discussions I have had with people in industry and all those people who take a keen interest in the subject, is that they are delighted at the generosity of our transitional arrangements. We have had nothing but praise from the industry for the refinements and improvements we announced some three months back. Again, they stand in stark contrast to these flat and arbitrary limits. If Senator McMullan were to do the rounds of the industry, he would find out just what most high income earners—the very few who will be touched by this $400,000 limit, when the average lump sum pay-out is about $50,000—think of it. They do not think it is good news at all.

I want to say a few words about the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. It makes relatively minor changes and, in a number of instances, improvements to the current regime. I know that Senator McMullan has put in quite a good deal of time in trying to improve the system. He has probably had the same representations that I have had in recent years. I still have to say that I do not think we have yet come to terms with the delicate balance of fairness that has to be struck in this area.

I still receive a significant number of what appear to be very valid complaints of unfairness. In many instances they are not put forward in a spirit of rancour, revenge or resentment at having to face up to legal obligations, but simply as outcomes that are very hard to justify in logical or other terms. I particularly commend the DADs organisation for trying to address some of these inequities; but one has to say there is still a long way to go. I foreshadow that we will generally support the Bill but we will be opposing the averment provision, and I will spell out why when we come to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a heap of taxation Bills. I would like to direct my remarks mainly to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992. As Senator Watson has pointed out, the basic principle of the Bill is to make an employer liable for FBT if he or she provides an employee with a car parking space for at least four hours between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. This FBT is put in place on the pretence that it is inequitable that some employees receive car parking benefits while others have to pay for car parking out of their own pockets, out of their after tax income. In explaining why this measure was introduced, Senator Button said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will give effect to the Budget measures announced on 18 August 1992 to tax certain car parking benefits. The Government finds it inequitable that some employees receive these car parking benefits in a tax exempt form while other employees, most of whom will not get a tax deduction for their car parking costs, must pay for equivalent facilities out of their after tax income.

That would be a noble idea if the Minister were to stick to his line of being equitable towards employees. I believe that was only a pretence. The real reason the Government has brought in this measure is to raise more tax via FBT. There is a shortfall in tax collection this year, as admitted in a report by the Australian Taxation Office not so long ago. The reason for that shortfall is that we are in the worst depression we have had since the 1930s. It is time to stop using the word `recession'; it is now a depression.

PARA.TAB: The financial impact of this Bill will be to raise $90m in 1993-94, $240m in 1994-95 and $190m in 1995-96. I have not had it explained to me yet—someone can probably explain it to me later—why there will be a drop in revenue in time to come. However, according to the Bill, no benefit exists for an employee unless a permanent commercial car parking facility is situated within one kilometre of the employer provided space. So if no commercial car parking facility is available, there is no benefit.

That is where Senator Button's idea of being equitable goes out of the window. Car parking deductions will not be available to employees who use car parking stations for more than four hours between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. or in the vicinity of the place of employment. In other words, when this legislation comes in, if the employee uses a public parking area for a cost and the employer does not reimburse the employee, then he or she cannot claim that as legal expenses for tax deductions. I would like to know what happens in a situation where someone works for three hours. Would they be able to get a deduction? I would like that question answered.

I would also like to find out about the situation where no parking is available for a particular day or a particular week at the workplace. Parking spaces are limited at most places of employment where parking is available. There could be reasons why parking is available for only certain days of the week and not others. There may be one week, out of the blue, when no parking is available. Would the employee who goes to the public parking place and pays for the privilege of parking be able to claim that as a deduction for expenses incurred in getting to and from work? Certainly this Bill and the explanatory memorandum do not tell us that.

I believe that this is very discriminatory legislation. One may ask why that is so. The main reason is that the employer is taxed differently depending on the location of the commercial car parking areas. The only criteria as to whether one is liable is exactly where those areas are located. It also depends on where the employer's work location is.

This is another tax on business. The coalition's Fightback package is all about taking tax off business rather than loading it up so that we can be competitive in world export markets. There will be a lot of expenses associated with this measure. If a car park is just out of the one kilometre range from an employer's business, the distance will have to be measured. The employer would probably need to get a surveyor in to do the measurement. If I had a business and a commercial parking area was 10 or 20 metres inside the one kilometre limit, it would be cheaper to shift the entrance into my parking area rather than pay the FBT. That sort of thing makes the Bill inequitable. We should either have an FBT on parking or we should not. The proposal in this Bill is quite stupid. Do not bet that the driveways will not be shifted. There is enough trouble administering FBT rules without adding this stupid one.

Employers will first have to establish where the public car parking areas are and then they will have to keep up surveillance of the area to see that one does not crop up. If employers are unaware that a car parking area has cropped up and they have not been paying FBT, I presume they will be in trouble. They will have to keep records of changes in charges at the public parking areas. In most cities, so many car parking bays have to be provided per the number of square metres of office space. The same applies to residential areas. Employers are forced by the council to provide parking. Then they are forced by the Commissioner of Taxation—in other words, the Government—to pay FBT. So it is a tax on top of a tax and nothing else.

What about the employer in an industrial area where there is no public car parking at a cost within one kilometre of his factory, for instance? What happens if there is a vacant lot up for sale next to his factory? If someone wanted to make a quick dollar, he or she could purchase that vacant lot and create a public parking area. That employer—businessman, manufacturer or whoever—would be quite anxious to deal with the purchaser, even to buy them out. Has the Government ever thought of anything like that? As I said, if we are to have FBT on parking, let us have it, but let us have it for everyone so that a person who gets the benefit is not treated differently from someone else who gets the same benefit.

Another question that I would like someone to answer is: when is a commercial parking station considered permanent? I can give plenty examples of what I am talking about, and plenty of honourable senators will know of them. For instance, the Royal Perth Hospital started building its north wing on the other side of Wellington Street. The skeleton for the wing was up, and then the hospital obviously ran out of money to finish it. It was turned into a public car parking station for which money was charged. In my belief, it was never intended to be a permanent parking station because the site was to be the north wing of the hospital when it was finished. To my knowledge, that site is now part of the hospital, but it was a car parking station for about 10 years. Would that parking station be considered permanent or not? I would like to know the answer to that question.

The point is that there is discrimination through this legislation because it is a benefit to have parking at a private hospital but it is not a benefit to have parking at a public hospital. The pretext for that discrimination is that one does not aim to make a profit and the other one does. It is a pity that the public hospitals do not try to cut costs to make a profit, because if they did we might have a better medical system in Australia. Senator Herron will probably enlarge on that point later, but I say that a person who works in a public hospital and a person who works in a private hospital get the same benefit: one car bay for that day from seven in the morning until seven at night. I cannot see why the fact that one hospital is private and one is public should make any difference. I reiterate that it is discriminatory, it is expensive to administer and it is plain stupid.

I go back to what Senator Button said. His and the Government's pretence was that everyone should be treated equally. But, far from being that, it is inequitable. I would like to know whose idea it was in the first place—it may have been the departing Commissioner of Taxation. Whoever it was, I think, could have thought it out more thoroughly. It ranks the same as that other Budget measure, which the Government has backed down on—the withholding tax on back interest. I reckon the measure is totally stupid; I will finish my remarks on that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —(7.03 p.m.)—The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 sets out to increase the low income thresholds below which people are not required to pay the levy, as announced in 1992-93 Budget. The Bill intends that individuals with taxable incomes of up to $11,887 and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $20,070 will not be required to pay the levy. As well, the income threshold is increased by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student. The shading-in provisions are also amended to reduce the levy where taxable income exceeds $11,887 but is less than $12,680.

PARA.TAB: This was not the only Budget measure affecting the Medicare levy. The rate of the Medicare levy is increased by 0.15 per cent to 1.4 per cent from 1 July 1993. This latter impost is expected to raise an additional $300m in 1993-94. One might well ask: why $300m? And why 0.15 per cent? Why not 2 per cent; why not 3 per cent? The reality is that the 1.25 per cent brings in only less than 18 per cent of the total Medicare expenditure.

It is a sham and a delusion because the majority of the population believe that they pay their Medicare levy and, therefore, they are entitled to health care. But why $300m? That intrigued me. I then looked up the figures and discovered that, over the last five years, two million people have actually shifted out of private insurance. The cost of those two million people going onto the Medicare system is—surprise, surprise—$370m a year. This increase in the Medicare levy is actually going to bring in less money than it is going to cost the system for the people dropping out of private insurance—that is, one and one would appear to make two.

But what is not recognised is that since the introduction of Medicare, health funds have actually consistently raised more money for health care than the Medicare levy itself. Indeed, we should bear in mind that the amount raised by the levy has actually decreased because of the recession.

So there are two avenues affecting it. One is the people who are dropping out of private insurance and therefore costing and being dependent on Medicare; and, on the other hand, less money is coming in from the Medicare levy because of the people who are out of work. So there is a double whammy going on, and the Government is looking for more funds.

In the last financial year, health funds paid out more than $3.3 billion in benefits. Of this, more than half a billion dollars went to the public sector and more than $1.5 billion went to private hospitals. The actual annual growth in benefits was 8 per cent. But, as I mentioned, the paradox is that the coverage of the population by private insurance is now down to 40.7 per cent. They are dropping out rapidly because of the increasing cost. Ninety per cent of contributors are now insured at the top level. So there is a paradox. More than 20 per cent of people on low incomes have health insurance—they are not prepared to trust the Medicare system—and 30 per cent of people on higher incomes are also not insured. So there is a gross inequity.

Honourable senators might think that I am a voice crying in the wilderness in relation to this, but I can quote no-one better than the Western Australian Labor Minister for Health, who resigned from his Ministry on 13 November and issued this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of hospital funding we have been left with a situation which I described at the hospital survival conference in Melbourne last May as the most inefficient and ramshackle hospital funding system one could imagine. It includes continuing the myth that the Medicare levy provides the funds.
The Labor Health Minister for Western Australia went on to say:

This has meant that hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians, including the 42 per cent of people over 65 who choose to be privately insured as a measure of securing ready access to hospital treatment without an undue wait for needed care, have been ignored. Ignored also is the majority of Labor supporters with private health insurance and the need to encourage people who could afford it to see the membership of private health funds as a means of supplementing scarce public funds needed to maintain high quality public hospital services.

It would be interesting to know how many Ministers of the Government have private health insurance. If they do not have it, they stand condemned as bludging on the public hospital system. They could afford it; they would be part of that 70 per cent of high income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawkes always go to private hospitals.
—Is that so? Mr Wilson also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government had slashed funding to West Australian public hospitals while its promises had created unprecedented extra demand. Federal Health Minister, Brian Howe, had failed to recognise the role of private health insurers.

It is interesting that, also from Western Australia, there is a report in the West Australian of 29 October relating how a 52-year-old man whose health had deteriorated in August was put on the urgent list for a triple by-pass procedure and was told that he would have to wait for three to five months. He secured private treatment and is alive and well, thank God, today. If honourable senators think that is a little unusual, I can tell them that that is going on throughout the county.

PARA.TAB: We are following the Canadian model. I received a letter today from a colleague of mine who is working in Canada, and he states:

SPEECH.PARA: I work with some Canadian anaesthetists and they tell me that waiting lists in Canada have become farcical. In Montreal urgent cardiac surgery has a waiting list of three weeks forcing many people to cross the border to Burlinton, Vermont, for necessary surgery. Much non-emergency surgery is done at Mt Sinai, Miami Beach, during Canadian winter holidays because they can be treated there.
He goes on:
Finally, I understand that the wait for urgent magnetic resonance imaging in many provinces is three months.

And we are heading, one might think, in the same direction. Yet, in Western Australia, we by-passed the three-month wait; it is now three to five months. The Canadian health system is held up as some model for us to follow.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that Medicare is bankrupt. It is not producing what it set out to do. Its basic principles were correct in the sense that it brought in the whole of the population compulsorily in relation to funding, and that is accepted by the Opposition. We have modelled that into our program.

The final matter that I wish to speak about, keeping in mind the time constraints, relates to what will occur tomorrow. Tomorrow the Australian Private Hospitals Association is launching a campaign under the banner, `Keep your health private'. Over 230 private hospitals will be carrying out a hospital audit to bring to the attention of the Federal Government the size and nature of the contribution made by private hospitals to the hospital systems of this country.

The Government has been deriding private insurance and the private hospital system, saying that they are not necessary. Yet 30 per cent of hospital occupants in this country are in private hospitals. I would like to see the private hospitals close their doors for one week and watch the government system cope with the extra 30 per cent. The only reason the private schools received their funding was that they closed their doors and demonstrated that those school children could not be managed by the public system. We are heading in that direction.

The Medicare system is broke. The Government is trying to prolong it by increasing the levy by 0.15 per cent—an extra $300m. As I have demonstrated, that figure represents less than the numbers that are dropping out of private insurance and going into the public system. The Government must recognise, when one of its own Labor health Ministers resigns over this particular topic, that the time has come to rethink the whole system. The Opposition has got an answer. We are incorporating the best features of Medicare. We recognise that it has good features, but because of the ageing population and the cost of technology, we must have a system that is based on freedom of choice and the opportunity for people to determine under which system they wish to be catered for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the hundreds of thousands of people who have tuned into the broadcast of the Senate's deliberations today are getting a bit confused as speakers in the debate have jumped from car parking to superannuation to Medicare. I say for their benefit that we are debating some cognate Bills. The one I want to refer to is the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill 1992. This is a matter which is of great concern to a number of my constituents in Western Australia and, in particular, to those who are either employers or employees in the central business district, and, of course, to car parking operators, of whom a number are friends and former business associates of mine, in the central business district of Perth.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza quite properly said that the real reason that this tax is being introduced has nothing to do with equity because this tax is not an equitable tax. There are very few that are. This is all about revenue raising. This Government, the Keating Labor Government, has one policy when it comes to tax reform—that is, to find new ways to tax people, to find new taxes to introduce and to raise more money.

The fringe benefits tax, when it was first thought up by this Government in 1986-87, brought in about $535m. In the year 1992-93 it is expected to raise about $1.38 billion. The explanatory memorandum to this Bill shows that in its first full year of income to the revenue—that is, for the year 1994-95—it will raise another quarter of a billion dollars or $240m. The point already made by Senator Panizza is that the tax has nothing to do with equity. In fact, if one looks at the Bill and at the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, one sees that it is an inequitable and iniquitous tax and it is another way for this Federal Government to try to rip more money out of the pockets of long suffering taxpayers.

There are a number of anomalies which I want to refer to very briefly today. Many employers insist that their employees need a car as a fundamental part of their employment. Many ads that we read in the employment sections of newspapers today show as a requirement of the employers that the employee have a car and be fit and able to drive a motor vehicle to be able to earn income. The provision of a car bay in that circumstance is certainly not a fringe benefit. That person is required to have a car. If he did not have a car or anywhere to park it he would not be able to be employed.

I suggest to the Government that to insist that a car bay provided to an employee who is required to use his car for work purposes is a fringe benefit is similar to suggesting that a desk, a PC, a pencil or anything else that the employer provides to his employee is also a fringe benefit. Indeed, the chair on which the employee sits could be considered to be a fringe benefit provided to that employee.

The next point, which was alluded to by Senator Panizza, is that the Perth City Council, for example—and, I expect, city councils and planning authorities around this nation—forces developers of buildings to provide car bays when they develop central city office buildings. We are now seeing a tax being introduced which will require sensible employers, sensible people who are trying to minimise the costs of doing business in this country, to analyse closely the number of car bays they provide and to whom in their organisations they provide car bays. We will find, as a natural consequence of supply and demand and the cost of supplying car bays, that the number of cars actually parked under central city buildings will diminish significantly and that the number of car bays that are required in the CBD is somewhat diminished because of this extra tax.

An accounting firm, Hooker Corporate Property Consultants, has estimated that in Perth the rates described in the Bill will add a cost of about $35 a month for each car bay—a massive expense for any business operating in the Perth central business district.

The Perth City Council, the Federal Government and the State governments have all been suggesting in the last few years that we need to bring more life, more vitality and more people into our cities. Virtually all of our cities have massive vacancies in central business district buildings. There has been a massive number of bankruptcies, so that many of the buildings are being emptied. There are not as many people in the cities. Small businesses in the cities are struggling—those which are still surviving. Yet here we have a pernicious taxation measure which will create an incentive for people to move out of our capital cities.

If the Government wants to create decentralisation and make sure that people move out of our cities, let us argue about that. But this measure will create an incentive for people who have leases expiring in a capital city in the next couple of years to look very closely at the options of moving out into suburban areas where they will not be slugged by this new fringe benefits taxation of car parking and the abolition of the exemption.

This tax really is a tax on employment. As we have said, in the case of Western Australia it adds about $35 a month to the cost of a car bay where an employee is required to have a car bay as part of his employment. This is another direct cost on employing Australians. This Government has an employment crisis, the like of which we have not seen in 60 years. Senator Button has called this tax an equitable tax. All it really does is to add $35 a month to the cost of employing someone in the Perth central business district.

The last point I want to make relates to the additional paperwork which the Government never seems to take into account when it brings in these brilliant new measures to rip money out of people's pockets—that is the paperwork that small business, medium business and large business will have to do—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just wait until they get the GST.

—I say to Senator Walsh that the paperwork they will do under the GST will be a fraction of what they have had to do under his Government, as we will abolish seven taxes. Small businesses and business around Australia are looking forward to the introduction of our tax reforms because the paperwork will be minimal. God help Australians when they see the work that has to be done to clock people in and out to see whether they have parked under a building for four hours or for 3 hours and 55 minutes. People will have to clock in and clock out of their car parks. An enormous amount of paperwork will be created. It would be fair to say that the paperwork involved in this one stupid, pernicious, iniquitous car parking tax around Australia in order to raise $230m of revenue in its first full year will be far more than the paperwork that anyone will ever have to do in relation to the GST.

PARA.TAB: It is an absolute disgrace. It is a joke. It shows how desperate this Government has become to rip out every last cent from the pockets of the long-suffering business people of Australia. If the Government wants to get serious about tax reform, it should do so, instead of just setting the bureaucrats and politicians to scraping around Australia trying to find the last inch of tax they can rip out of people.

We should have a sensible look at tax reform. That is what the Hewson Opposition has done. We have decided that there is a need for change in Australia. We have decided that there is a need to put in place a business tax system that encourages businesses and does not hit them over the head every time they try to do something. That is the policy I will be supporting. This policy of the Keating Government should be opposed. I look forward to fighting the next election on tax reform because, when the Opposition's tax policies get put up against the ad hockery of these people opposite, the Australian people will vote in droves for the Hewson alternative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak at length this evening on this particular matter, but I do want to follow on from Senator Campbell, Senator Watson and other senators who have raised the ludicrous nature of the car park tax. As Senator Watson and other honourable senators have pointed out, there is certain detail that one's car parking capacity needs to fit into before attracting this legislation—namely, that the car has to be parked in something owned, controlled or leased by one's employer within one kilometre of the workplace and the car needs to be parked there for greater than four hours between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. It is going to take an army of people to monitor that kind of stupid, petty, nit-picking little detail.

PARA.TAB: I recall Mr Keating saying when he organised the tax summit—I think it was in 1985—that the key element of all taxation reform should be to keep it simple. As you may well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the coalition's taxation reforms will make things much simpler than they are. As you well know, what we want to do is take seven taxes that are at the moment pre-point of sale and distribute them to post-point of sale to escape the inequity and lack of logic in the way that those taxes are now applied. So we will simply take them from the pre-point of sale and spread them out across all consumers post-point of sale.

Consumers are paying those taxes now and they are beginning to realise that. They are beginning to realise the lie that Labor tells when it says that the coalition wants to add another tax. The implication in that statement, of course, is that the GST, which we will impose when we win government, is an additional tax over and above existing taxes when in fact, by and large, it is a replacement of existing taxes and a reform that implements those taxes in a much more efficient way.

Senator Watson indicated in his speech that Qantas—one employer alone—has estimated the cost of this particular change to be the collection of $6m more, for no rational reason. As other senators have indicated, we believe that this nit-picking tax, by and large, will affect lower income earners more than higher income earners. But, of course, not only is it a cost on business; it affects a large number of workers—including, as I have said, low income workers—in many areas: in schools, TAFE colleges, railways; it affects building workers, public servants, police, and people who have disabled parking. The list is not endless but it is certainly very extensive.

The Government really needs to give an explanation as to how it can justify implementing this sort of change when the cardinal rule on taxation reform, as laid down by Mr Keating in 1985, was that taxation reform should make the system much more simple than it is now. This change simply does not do that. It seems to be nit-picking. It seems to have a detail in it that will require more people to be supervising the tax than should be necessary if the reform were to be done in a much simpler way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have only one major concern about the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill, which is the Bill I will concentrate on. My colleague Senator Kernot will deal with the other Bills in this package of legislation before the chamber this evening. My concern relates to clause 38, which I will deal with in a moment.

PARA.TAB: I begin by making some general comments about the Child Support Agency. My office is still receiving regular complaints about difficulties, particularly with access to the service—complaints about the telephones that forever seem to be engaged. The complaints also relate to problems with regard to overpayments and underpayments, and the fact that those matters are not easily sorted out, it seems. There are also difficulties in enforcing orders.

Despite these problems, I stress that we are supportive of the work of the agency. It is a very sensitive area, one where I do not think we can ever solve all of the problems. But I believe that in recent times people are beginning to have far more confidence in the work of the agency and the agency certainly is, it seems, quite cost-effective in its role of passing money on to the parent who is caring for the children, and so on to the children. It seems that the non-custodial parents are, by and large, meeting their obligations.

We have also seen a change in community attitudes: the community now expects the non-custodial parent to come up with their fair share of support and to accept their responsibilities. Mr Justice Fogarty, chair of the child support evaluation agency, recently pointed out that the scheme has challenged strongly the pre-scheme ethos of maintenance payments being a voluntary act. The community now expects that all parents will contribute to the support of their own children and they are now more likely to make arrangements for the payments of maintenance.

In the time remaining, I wish to go very briefly through what is in this Bill. It continues a process of improving the scheme and toughens up the powers of the registrar. There are two changes I particularly want to deal with. The first is the way in which it deals with what is substantial access to a child; in fact, the actual definition of what is `substantial access'. Previously, it was that the child had to be with the parent for at least 40 per cent of the time. That has now moved to between 30 and 40 per cent; in fact, for the purposes of actually determining maintenance payments, the definition of `substantial access' will be for 35 per cent of the time. This remedies a problem which was identified by the child support evaluation and advisory group as a major source of dissatisfaction for non-custodial parents. It is a change that represents a fairer and more flexible approach to the formula.

The second change deals with taxable income where the income test is not readily ascertainable. The child support formula is based on the historic taxable income of the parties plus an allowance for inflation. Where the taxable income is not available from the Tax Office or any other source, the legislation currently says that the registrar must in all cases select the figure of 2 1/2 times average weekly earnings and calculate the figure from that. That has caused major problems. It is generally termed a rather `blunt instrument' by which to determine the amount of money that is payable. This Bill allows the registrar to select an appropriate figure of up to 2 1/2 times the average weekly earnings. We certainly support this change. Indeed, these changes and all the other changes in the Bill are supported by the Democrats, but we look forward to even further improvements in the near future.

The only problem that we have with this Bill is clause 38. Clause 38 inserts into the Child Support Act 1988 a provision that a statement or averment will be allowed as prima facie evidence of a matter in a prosecution under the Act. At present, the onus of proof in prosecutions is on the registrar. The Bill seeks to change this by providing for the registrar to be able to aver or state from the bar or table that a particular matter is fact. Averments can, of course, be a useful prosecutory tool. However, it needs to be understood that they reverse the onus of proof.

They should, as a matter of legislative policy, be kept to a minimum. Both the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills have stated that on several occasions. While averments might be administratively convenient, they can pose significant difficulties for defendants. There is no obligation on the prosecution to confer with a defendant and, once a fact is averred, it stands as proof. The defendant then has to rebut it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1992CHILD SUPPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) BILL 1992MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (CAR PARKING) BILL 1992

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, instead of the prosecution having to provide evidence of the fact, it can simply aver or state that it is so from the Bar table and it is up to the defendant to disprove it.

PARA.TAB: Clause 38 also does not attempt to restrict the use of averment at all. For example, it makes no reference to the limiting of the proposed averment to matters particularly within the knowledge of the defendant. It does not restrict it to formalities or to the specific ingredients of the charge. All limitations which may have made its use more marginally acceptable are not in here. In fact, there is no compelling reason at all, other than convenience, advanced by the Government for having this clause in this Bill. The Democrats therefore foreshadow that, when we get to the committee stage of this Bill, we will be voting against clause 38.
