That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, as you know, there is some public perception that members of Parliament are dishonest. This is in part fuelled by the fact that sometimes there are different interpretations of the facts. What I want to speak about tonight is one of the most blatant examples of political dishonesty imaginable. The incident to which I refer is where a member of parliament has said not only something which is not substantiable but moreover something which is in direct contravention of the facts.

PARA.TAB: I refer to a press release issued on Friday by Mr Neville Newell, the honourable member for Richmond. Mr Newell fulminated over what evil people we were in the coalition and, in particular, he claimed that the coalition would starve the Skillshare program of funds. As I will demonstrate, this is totally without foundation, but I believe that this press release indicates that Mr Newell regards the unemployed of his electorate as people he can manipulate and exploit to his own advantage without any compunction about telling them the truth.

Given that the electorate of Richmond has one of the highest unemployment rates in New South Wales, what he has done is particularly distasteful. In the Tweed Shire alone, there are approximately 4,000 people on Jobsearch and Newstart allowances, but the real unemployment rate is higher. This is what Mr Newell said on Friday about the coalition's policy in relation to Skillshare:

SPEECH.PARA: Local employment boards would take the place of Skillshare. These boards would lack the co-ordination of a national scheme and would depend on community volunteers. The whole idea of local employment boards would be particularly worrying for small and provincial communities such as Ballina.
His press release continues:
The Opposition would get rid of Skillshare by running down funding to zero over a ten year period.

This came as something of a surprise to me, so I thought I would check the Fightback package documents. A perusal of the Fightback documents reveals that Mr Newell is wrong and that the coalition is committed to not only maintaining the Skillshare program but also strengthening it. Page 254 of Fightback refers to community based strategies to deal with unemployment, to humanise the problem. It says:

Such an approach was strongly recommended by the Kirby Committee's review of Labour Market Programs in the mid 1980s. The evidence suggests that community-based strategies are more effective in getting people back into the workforce than centrally run programs. About half of all participants in the existing community-based scheme, Skillshare, either obtained employment or continued in further education.

PARA.TAB: The Coalition will therefore build on the Skillshare program, while allowing local communities to determine the best means of spending funds allocated for labour market programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Fightback continues to elaborate on that by explaining how, with the input of departmental officers, businessmen and people involved in the community, the programs run by Skillshare will be tailor made to the particular circumstances of the area. It is very clear that the coalition will maintain Skillshare. That is a long term commitment because, on the empirical evidence, this scheme is one of the best ways of creating jobs. The basis of this absurd comment is beyond me.

PARA.TAB: It is also interesting to note that Skillshare at Coolangatta, which covers people both in the Coolangatta area and south of the border in Tweed Heads, runs exactly the sort of program to which we in the coalition refer in the Fightback documents. In fact, at Skillshare in Coolangatta one finds they are running courses to assist people to get jobs as taxi drivers and limousine drivers, because these are the occupations in high demand in the tourism industry.

There is not a shred of evidence to support Mr Newell's claim. Where he gets the idea that we will run down Skillshare to zero over a 10-year period is beyond me and anybody on this side of the chamber. What will really embarrass Mr Newell is the fact that just a couple of weeks ago after the Budget was brought down the Government cut back funding to some labour market programs, particularly Job Club in Murwillumbah, by 35 per cent.

It is not the coalition which is taking the funds away from programs to get people jobs but the Government. By this press release, Mr Newell has shown himself willing to say anything to anyone to score a few political points. Unfortunately, it is at the expense of the truth and also at the expense of the people who live in his electorate.

I am absolutely astounded that he would have the audacity to put out such unadulterated drivel. Either he is incapable of reading the Fightback package for himself and is relying on someone who is equally illiterate or he is simply not telling the truth to his electors. Either way he cannot be trusted and, frankly, people would have to be crazy to vote for him a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to comment very briefly on the issue raised by the High Court's stripping of the seat of Wills from Phil Cleary, MP. I still describe him as `Phil Cleary, MP' because I believe that a number of issues are raised by that High Court decision which this Parliament ought to at least consider. As we all know, the action in the court was taken ultimately as a result of the views of Mr Sykes, a candidate who received less than one per cent of the vote in that election. Also put in doubt by the High Court's decision is the position of candidates and members of parliament who, in one way or another, hold dual citizenship, having been born in another country.

PARA.TAB: Three issues are raised by the High Court's decision—what I would describe as a lamentable black-letter decision that has taken little account of true democratic principles. The first issue is the question of the democratic rights of the electorate to choose who should represent it in parliament. Phil Cleary won the seat of Wills fairly and squarely, beating the combined efforts—I might say the highly organised efforts—of both major political parties. We are all aware of the visits to Wills made by Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Liberal Party, and many members of his front bench and back bench. The Labor Party also ran a highly organised campaign and Mr Cleary won despite those efforts. Mr Cleary also represented very clearly to the electorate a particular view, for example, about tariff policy and industry development, which has a right to be heard in this place.

The ostensible grounds for invalidating Phil Cleary's election is the fact that he in theory was still an employee of the Crown, in this case the Victorian Education Department. He was, however, on unpaid leave—an employment situation, or an unemployment situation, that he genuinely thought did not prevent him running for the seat of Wills. He would not be the first who was either advised that way or believed that he was entitled to run by simply taking unpaid leave from a Crown employment position.

That raises a second issue—namely, whether or not our election system is simple, easy to understand and open to all Australian citizens. One should not need to be a legal eagle, particularly a constitutional legal eagle, or have a PhD in politics to understand one's rights as either a voter or as a candidate. This is particularly relevant in Mr Cleary's case and in the case of all independents who do not have the guiding and advisory assistance that most of us have from our major political parties.

We all know that if it were left up to every individual member of the Liberal Party, the Labor Party and the National Party to make sure that their nominations were in order, on time and appropriate, half this Parliament probably would not be here. But we all know the facts of life are that major political parties organise the tickets on behalf of their candidates, organise their nominations, ensure that the nominations are in on time and comply with what I might describe as the ever-changing electoral law. That is the reality. We all get assistance from our major political parties.

As Senator McMullan knows, as a former National Secretary of the Labor Party, an honourable, esteemed and most difficult position, and as I know as a former State Secretary of the Labor Party, it is our job as chief administrators of the Party to ensure that all of our candidates know what they need to do. In some cases we need to ensure that we work our way through some very complicated processes to ensure that we are able to pass onto our candidates the right advice. Independents do not have ready access to that type of organised advice.

Obviously I prefer Labor Party candidates to win all elections and by-elections, but in this case the electorate of Wills chose another candidate, and he won despite certain disadvantages that independent candidates have. It is not as though this Parliament is being inundated with independents in the House of Representatives.

The third issue raised by the High Court decision—this does not relate of course particularly to Mr Cleary—is the incapacity, I believe, of the High Court to understand that Australia is now a multicultural country. All of us who have visited the United States, for example, find it extremely unusual, first of all that they do not have compulsory voting, but secondly and more importantly that unless one has been born in the United States, one cannot run for its presidency. Again, this is a deliberate attack on the rights of those people who immigrated to the United States and who have become trustworthy, reliable and appropriate citizens of that country.

The High Court is taking us down that road. It is saying that there is a question mark over everyone who was not born in this country. I think that is an intolerable principle for the High Court to embed in stone. We are a multicultural country. We are a country where a significant percentage of our population was born overseas. There should at no time be a question mark over those citizens, especially those who have taken out citizenship in Australia and who are long term, permanent residents and citizens of this country entitled to vote.

The High Court has said that there are certain aspects of a person being born in another country which may preclude them from being members of either the Senate or the House of Representatives and, I presume for that matter, some other parliaments. In some countries—I believe Greece is one example—it is legally impossible for one to renounce one's citizenship. So if one emigrates to this country and says, `I want to be an Australian. I want to be naturalised here. I wish to give up all my rights and responsibilities to my native Greek country', it is impossible under Greek law for such a person to do so.

We have had occasions in the past, both in the Greek situation and in the situation relating to some of the Balkan countries, where people returning to those countries who were citizens of Australia and who lived here for many years were subjected, for example, to the question of conscription into the armies of their native countries. We found out very quickly, therefore, that those countries were determined not to allow their citizens to give up their Greek or Balkan citizenship but to maintain some form of dual citizenship.

If it is a person's wish to be a citizen of Australia, to become a true part of this multicultural society, then they ought to be given the right to run for parliament. What the Greek Government, or for that matter any other government overseas, happens to say about them ought to be irrelevant. They have left that country, they are now a citizen of Australia and they ought to be able to run for this Parliament. They ought not to worry about whether or not, for example, the Swiss law says that even if one has lived in Australia for 20 years or more, as the Liberal candidate in Wills had lived, one still has to do certain technical things in order to ensure that one is no longer a Swiss citizen. Even if that is the case, we should not be worrying about that here.

The High Court has taken a black letter approach to the Australian Constitution. That in itself is a dangerous approach because we are talking about a document that was written a long time ago, where the founding fathers were attempting to predict what Australia would be in 50 or 100 years time and were trying to deal with it in our Constitution. We should not be taking the Constitution and using it in a black letter way, as I believe the High Court has done today.

Most people would probably say, `What is a politician doing criticising the referee's verdict? What is a politician doing talking in derogatory terms about the High Court?' The answer is simply that we have a role to play in this Parliament representing the people of Australia—the electorate's voice. The High Court has a role in terms of interpreting the law, ultimately the Constitution. There is a balance in a sense between these two institutions, but I believe that, from time to time, that balance has been overturned or weighted down in favour of the High Court. The High Court is not a legislative body. It should not set the social direction of Australia and, for that matter, the electoral direction of Australia. That ultimately is a matter for the decision making processes and election processes of parliament—and, ultimately, of course, the people of Australia, the voters.

I believe that in many ways this is a sad day for this Parliament. A man who was plainly and clearly selected to represent the electorate in this Parliament was stripped of his powers and his right to represent the electorate—all because a person who received less than one per cent of the popular vote decided that he wanted to set things right.

I listened to Mr Sykes on television tonight. I heard him say that basically all of us here are do-nothings and that we all need to be given a boot up the backside, and making other implications. He said that he was the one who was going to morally set this Parliament right. The message that I am giving tonight to Mr Sykes and to other people, including a number of people in the High Court, is simply the fact that ultimately the electorate decides.

It will be very interesting to see what the electorate does when we hold the by-election. It may well be that the High Court has helped re-elect Mr Cleary. That may not be much help to some of my Labor colleagues in Victoria, but the simple fact is that its intervention in this process and its decision to overturn the will of the electors of Wills has now created a political martyr where one should never have been created.

Mr Cleary is entitled to sit in this place. There should be no question mark over the heads of those who are born in another country but who wish to be Australian citizens and represent Australians in this Parliament. The High Court needs to rethink some of its social engineering that I believe is underpinning many of its recent decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will respond very briefly. I will not enter into the very important debate that Senator Aulich raised. He has raised some very serious issues about Australia's democracy and the role of institutions in it. The consequences of today's decision will be thought about by many people for quite a long time. There will be some real concern about any process that means that the person chosen by the electors through a proper and fair process does not represent them in the Parliament. Everybody will be concerned about that and it is an important issue to have before us.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee came in here for the purpose of dropping a bucket on the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell). We all need to be fairly careful when we do that. We all live in glass houses, and stone throwing in that way leaves a little to be desired. Mr Newell is a big boy, he can take care of himself, and I will not go to the substance of the issue. However, it indicates that the National Party must be more worried than it pretends about the marginal seat of Richmond if it has to send in Queensland backbenchers to try to attack Mr Newell.

The honourable member for Richmond is perfectly entitled to have concerns about labour market programs under the Opposition. Every time we increase their funding, we get criticised for doing so. He is very reasonably concerned about the proposed role of local

SPEECH.PARA: employment boards under Fightback. It causes me significant concern as well. But I do not intend to traverse the issue beyond that. As I say, Mr Newell has his own chamber to respond in. I am sure that he is perfectly capable of taking care of Senator O'Chee. Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many staff are based in Torres Strait?
(2) How many staff are indigenous?
(3) What strategies are being implemented to ensure more Torres Strait Island staff move into senior positions?
(4) How is housing allocated to prevent discrimination against Torres Strait Islanders?
(5) What processes are in place to ensure regular communication and liaison between departments and with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Island Coordinating Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (3) The Torres Strait Aboriginal Employment Development Program (AEDP) Committee has developed a Torres Strait Public Sector Strategy. The main aim of the strategy is to identify Torres Strait Islanders already in the Public Service as well as Torres Strait Islanders wanting to enter the service. The strategy will develop specialised training programs for those identified with the aim of preparing them for higher appointments. People outside the Public Service will be given access to specific courses that will assist them prepare for placements.
The ATSIC Regional Office in the Torres Strait has been restructured to allow for more recruitment at the lower levels of the APS. This restructure will

ANSWER.PARA: mean the development of clearly defined career paths for all staff and should enhance the recruitment and promotion of Torres Strait Islanders to more senior positions.

PARA.TAB: On a broader scale and as part of the Government's commitment to a policy of overall equity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in public sector employment ATSIC has developed a strategy which seeks to increase the numbers of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people within ATSIC, their skills and the levels at which they are employed.

(4) The ATSIC Regional Office in the Torres Strait allocates all available staff houses to all staff, regardless of whether the staff member is indigenous and therefore race is not an issue in the allocation process. Six of the ten indigenous staff members and their families are housed; three have their own house; and one is housed by the Department of Family Services.

(5) Forums have been created by ATSIC to ensure that communications with and liaison between government agencies (including ATSIC) and the Island Coordinating Council, the Regional Council and Commonwealth and State Government agencies. The Committee meets on the last Friday of each month.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is a claim included on Meadow Lea margarine tubs correct in stating that "recent research undertaken by the CSIRO has proven that if a typical Australian diet includes bread, fruit, vegetables, lean meat and Meadow Lea margarine, then there will be a significant reduction of cholesterol levels for those people observing such diets"; if so, what are the details of the "recent research" referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Research conducted in 1990 by the CSIRO Division of Human Nutrition in collaboration with Meadow Lea has resulted in a healthier fat product for use in commercial biscuit and cake manufacture.
This new manufactured product contains a blend of fats which as part of a balanced diet can actually help to lower blood cholesterol levels.

The background diet in which this Meadow Lea margarine was tested (as well as the control standard saturated fat mix), comprised little fat and was therefore based on lean meats, low fat dairy products, fruits and vegetables, bread and pasta.

Therefore the statement within the Meadow Lea tubs is factual in every way. Because it also held a strong public health message, CSIRO allowed its name to be identified as having carried out this research.
Meadow Lea polyunsaturated margarine tubs carried the message for several months and discontinued it some time ago. (The new insert refers to the National Heart Foundation).

The research has been published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, the world's leading human nutrition journal: Nestel PJ, Noakes M, Belling GB, McArthur R, Clifton PM, Abbey A. Plasma cholesterol-lowering potential of edible oil blends suitable for commercial use. Am J Clin Nutr 1992;55:46-50

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government, upon notice, on 21 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will local authorities be required to pay wholesale sales tax on leased equipment under the Government's proposed wholesale sales tax provisions.
(2) What amount of revenue does the Government expect to raise from the wholesale sales tax on equipment leased by local authorities.
(3) As a result of the revised wholesale sales tax arrangements, how many local authorities does the Government expect will have to pay wholesale sales tax.
(4) What consultation, if any, did the Government conduct with Local Government on the revised wholesale sales tax arrangements prior to their introduction to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Generally local authorities will not be required to pay wholesale sales tax on leased equipment. Under the recently enacted sales tax law, leases of goods are categorised as either "long term" (i.e. for periods of at least 2 years or the effective working life of the goods, which ever is the shorter), or "short term" (i.e. periods of less than 2 years). Where a local council leases goods on a long term basis, a full exemption from sales tax is available on that lease. Where a local council leases goods on a short term basis, the lessor may enter into an agreement with the Commissioner under which the lessor is able to exclude from the taxable value of goods leased an amount calculated to equate to the proportion of the leases of those goods that he/she could reasonably be expected to make in "exempt circumstances" (e.g. to manufacturers and to councils and other exempt persons). The benefit of the reduced taxable value would then be expected to be passed on by the lessor to those exempt clients.
(2) The Government does not expect to raise any revenue from the wholesale sales tax on equipment leased by local authorities.
(3) The Government expects the liability to wholesale sales tax of local authorities to be unchanged under the new sales tax law.
(4) The Government did not conduct consultations with Local Government on this matter.

(3) Have any prosecutions for breach of air safety regulations been instigated against owners and/or operators of helicopters which crashed in Australia during: (a) 1990; (b) 1991; and (c) 1992.
(4) How many prosecutions mentioned in (3) have resulted in the conviction of the individuals who were charged.

(7) Are there any exemptions to these height restrictions; if so, what are they.

(9) Have any prosecutions for breach of air safety regulations been made against owners or operators of helicopters which crashed while operating under the exemptions.

(10) Has any Commonwealth Government agency that is involved in the investigation of helicopter crashes or the control and/or regulation of air safety recommended, during the aforementioned years, that the current regulations which control helicopter movements over built-up residential areas need to be improved or amended to further protect citizens on the ground.
(11) Have any recommendations been made that the exemptions mentioned in (7) be further restricted in any way; if so, what are these recommendations and have they been adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI), is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (c) To 27 October 1992—38
(c) To 27 October 1992—6
(3) (a) 1990—No prosecutions
(b) 1991—Two prosecutions were completed against pilots of helicopters which crashed.
(c) 1992—One prosecution has been instigated against the pilot of a helicopter which crashed.
(4) Both prosecutions referred to in (3)(b) resulted in convictions against the pilots of the helicopters.

(5) Of the two cases of prosecution referred to in (4), one pilot was fined $500, plus $46.75 court costs, in default 16 days imprisonment. The other pilot was prosecuted on two separate charges. The conviction recorded for the first charge was a fine of $300, in default 10 days imprisonment. On the second charge, the pilot was fined $750, in default 26 days imprisonment.

(6) Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR) 157 does not allow aircraft, including helicopters, to fly over built-up residential areas, such as cities, towns or populous areas, at a height lower than 1,000 feet.

Under subregulation (4) of CAR 157, and having regard for safety, the Civil Aviation Authority does issue specific and general permits for helicopter operations below 1,000 feet over built-up residential areas. For example, such general permits are usually granted to helicopters operated by the police and media.
(8) (a) An Air Ambulance helicopter struck a power line during a landing approach while responding to an emergency call in Victoria. The aircraft was damaged but the occupants were not injured.
(b) NIL.

(c) A media helicopter suffered a heavy landing when the engine lost power during an approach to a helipad at Perth. The aircraft struck the ground short of the helipad, and one of the occupants was seriously injured.
Both the above accidents occurred during the landing phase of the flight, thus the question of operations under the exemptions was not an issue.
(9) Not applicable.

(10) During the period 1990 up to the present time, the Civil Aviation Authority has not recommended any changes to the current regulations governing helicopter operations over built-up residential areas, in order to further protect citizens on the ground. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 21 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) report Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia (1992):

(1) Has the NHMRC report ignored extensive recent research into cyclodiene air residues in residences in New South Wales (NSW) in which treatment had been carried out in accordance with legal requirements, as reported in a Master of Science thesis by Mr Philip Cantrell of the NSW WorkCover Authority; if so, why has this research been ignored.

(2) With reference to the work carried out by Mr Cantrell: (a) are the results of critical importance to the assessment of the impact on human health of continued cyclodiene use, especially heptachlor/ chlordane; if so, will the NHMRC amend its evaluation of the cyclodienes so as to include the Cantrell results; if not, why not; and (b) are the results of vital interest to consumers who are still being exposed to these chemicals through contamination of their residences and to pest control operators who perform the treatments; if so, will the NHMRC immediately inform all Australian consumers and all pest control operators of the risk contaminating residences with these chemicals after routine use according to legal specifications and recommend to State authorities an immediate ban on the use of these chemicals, especially in established buildings; if not, why not.

(3) Is there an Australian guideline, standard or criterion according to which it is possible to assess safety of levels of cyclodiene insecticides in indoor air; if so: (a) what is the guideline, standard or criterion; (b) how, and on what basis, was the safety of the air residue levels established, especially to new born and crawling infants; and (c) does the guideline, standard or criterion take into account not only uptake through inhalation but also the accompanying uptake, for example, through skin; if not, does this mean that any cyclodiene level in the indoor air of residences is considered acceptable by the compiler(s) of the NHMRC report.

(4) If the compiler(s) of the NHMRC report consider any cyclodiene level in the indoor air of residences acceptable: (a) at what point do levels of cyclodiene air residues in domestic residences become not acceptable; and (b) how long must they prevail before they are considered unacceptable to the compiler(s) of the NHMRC report.

(5)Does the NHMRC report recommend an unequivocal ban on the use of cyclodiene in established residences; if so, when do the compiler(s) of the report expect this ban to be implemented; if not, what does recommendation 3 on page 11 of the report mean when it states `Chlordane and heptachlor should be permitted to be imported and registered for use only as termiticides in the construction of housing and buildings and that this use be restricted to underslab usage and in crawl space under and around housing in accordance with Standards Australia Code AS 2178 and AS 2057 and in accordance with proposed modifications to those standards'.

(6) With reference to the statement in the NHMRC report that physical methods of preventing termite attack require `much further evaluation as to their efficacy' (p. 271): (a) which physical methods require further evaluation as to their efficacy; (b) what is the nature of the evaluation that is required (please specify required tests); (c) what should be the evaluator's or evaluators' expertise; (d) have criteria been developed to assess physical methods of preventing termite attack; if so: (i) who developed them and what are they; and (ii) what is the durability expected of such methods; if not, are decisions about the need for evaluation of physical methods being made arbitrarily and/or for political reasons by the NHMRC or its committees and who is making these decisions; (e) is the committee compiling the NHMRC report or the NHMRC setting itself up as an arbitrator of efficacy of physical barriers above and beyond the technical advice and expertise of the Standards Association of Australia; if so: (i) on what basis; and (ii) with what expertise and advice; and (f) does the NHMRC report, which recommends `much further evaluation' of the efficacy of physical methods of preventing termite entry, conflict with the answer to Question on Notice No. 1905 (Senate Hansard, 3 June 1992, p. 3469) in relation to the evaluation of the efficacy of Termimesh, a stainless steel barrier method of excluding termites from structures; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Mr Cantrell's unpublished thesis was not ignored because it was not available when the NHMRC Report was being compiled. However the available published studies of post treatment indoor air contamination were reviewed and summarised in the Report.
(2) The significance of Mr Cantrell's work has yet to be assessed.
(3a) No.
(3b) Not applicable.
(3c) No. The compilers of the NHMRC Report drew no conclusions regarding the acceptability of any level of cyclodiene insecticide in indoor air.

(5) The NHMRC report recommends that the cyclodienes chlordane and heptachlor be permitted to be imported and registered for use only as termiticides in the construction of housing and buildings and its use be restricted to under slab usage and in crawl space under houses in accordance with the newly developed Standards Australia Code. The recommendation does not refer to Standards Australia Code AS 2178 and AS 2057. I am not able to anticipate when the recommendations in the report may be implemented. It will be for other agencies, including the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and individual States and Territories, to decide whether they wish to adopt the NHMRC recommendations and, if so, to decide on the timetable for the cessation of other current registered uses of the cyclodienes.

(6) It is not the intention of the NHMRC to make an expert assessment of the efficacy of physical methods of termite control. The NHMRC report does not conflict with the answer to Question on Notice No 1905 which also states that further appraisal is required before (the physical termite control) Termimesh can be considered to be sufficiently developed for national application to new construction.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the proposed arrangements for the construction of the Jindalee Project.
(2) What are the proposed arrangements for the staffing and operation of the project.
(3) Is the project likely to operate on a `fly in-fly out' basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telecom Australia has been awarded a contract for provision of the Jindalee Operational Radar Network. Site works for the radar transmitting and receiving installations have commenced at Longreach and will commence at Laverton in February 1993. Completion of the Queensland radar is scheduled for August 1996, the Western Australia radar for December 1996 and acceptance by the Commonwealth of the Network for June 1997.

(2) Maintenance and support for the Network will be provided under contract, with the first four years of maintenance and support being contracted to Telecom. Current planning is for five contractor staff to be employed at each transmitter site and ten at each receiver site.

(3) Telecom has assessed that, while non-technical staff might be recruited locally, technical staff would need to be provided on a fly in-fly out basis. However, it is expected that Telecom will keep this matter under review as planning for its maintenance commitments matures. There is currently no intention to have military personnel

ANSWER.PARA: permanently assigned at the radar sites; when required, military staff will be detached to the sites and will be housed in transit accommodation on site.
